**Non-IFRS Financial Measures**

We have presented certain information in this Offering Memorandum that is not required by, nor
presented in accordance with, IFRS to evaluate our operating and financial performance. Please see “Summary—
_Summary Historical and Other Financial Information.” As used in this Offering Memorandum, our key non-IFRS_
financial measures include:

    - Organic net sales growth/(decrease): Organic net sales growth/(decrease) presents a “like-for-like”
comparative growth rate, and represents the change in net sales for the current period compared to
the prior period, calculated on a constant currency basis and by eliminating any change in scope
between the relevant periods.

Such change in scope between periods may result from: (i) an acquisition, divestiture or disposal of
our business in a country or a major market or that of a business unit; (ii) changes to the business
model under which we operate in a specific market, or with respect to the manner in which a
particular product is (or particular products are) sold by us in that market (for example, if we change
our local operating model from a distributor model to a royalty model, or if we change from thirdparty manufacturing (wherein such third-party manufacturer typically sources raw materials) to toll
manufacturing (wherein we typically supply raw materials to a third party manufacturer) or (iii) the
adoption of an accounting standard or a change in the application of an accounting principle, if
applicable. We commenced calculating organic net sales growth/(decrease) beginning for the year
ended December 31, 2023. Accordingly, we present organic net sales growth/(decrease) for the year
ended December 31, 2023, the three months ended March 31, 2023 and March 31, 2024 and the
twelve months ended March 31, 2024 only.

The constant currency exchange rate is calculated using the measures described below under “—
_Constant Currency Exchange Rate Measures.”_

    - Constant currency net sales growth: Represents the change in net sales for the relevant period
compared to the prior period, calculated on a constant currency basis (as described under “—
_Constant Currency Exchange Rate Measures”). We present constant currency net sales growth for_
the years ended December 31, 2021 and December 31, 2022 only. We commenced calculating
organic net sales growth/(decrease) beginning for the year ended December 31, 2023. Accordingly,
we present organic net sales growth/(decrease) for the year ended December 31, 2023, the three
months ended March 31, 2023 and March 31, 2024 and the twelve months ended March 31, 2024.

    - Constant currency gross profit (decrease)/growth: Represents the growth rate of our reported gross
profit (which is our net sales minus cost of sales) calculated on a constant currency basis (as
described under “—Constant Currency Exchange Rate Measures”).

    - Gross margin: Represents net sales minus cost of sales divided by net sales, and expressed as a
percentage.

    - Constant currency gross margin (decrease)/growth: Represents the growth rate of our reported gross
margin calculated on a constant currency basis (as described under “—Constant Currency Exchange
_Rate Measures”)._

    - Normalized EBITDA: Represents net profit/(loss) before income tax expense, net finance costs,
depreciation of property, plant and equipment (including right of use assets) and amortization of
intangible assets, as adjusted for share-based payment expenses and certain non-underlying items
that we do not consider to be part of the Group’s daily business operations due to the nature,
frequency and predictability of their occurrence, in each case, as described under the section titled
“Summary—Summary Historical and Other Financial Information—Key Financial Data.”

xi


-----

    - Normalized EBIT: Represents our net profit/(loss) before income tax expense and net finance costs,
as adjusted for share-based payment expenses and other non-underlying items for which our
Normalized EBITDA is adjusted.

    - Constant currency Normalized EBITDA growth: Represents the growth rate of our Normalized
EBITDA calculated on a constant currency basis (as described under “—Constant Currency
_Exchange Rate Measures”)._

    - Normalized free cash flow: Represents cash generated from operating activities less net capital
expenditure, plus net cash inflows/outflows from non-underlying operating and capital items that
we do not consider to be part of the Group’s daily business operations due to the nature, frequency
and predictability of their occurrence, in each case, as described under the section titled “Summary—
_Summary Historical and Other Financial Information—Key Financial Data.”_

    - Normalized free cash conversion ratio: Represents normalized free cash flow divided by Normalized
EBITDA, expressed as a percentage.

    - Normalized EBITDA margin: Represents our Normalized EBITDA divided by net sales, expressed
as a percentage.

    - Constant currency Normalized EBITDA margin (decrease)/growth: Represents growth rate of our
Normalized EBITDA margin calculated on a constant currency basis (as described under “—
_Constant Currency Exchange Rate Measures”)._

    - Pricing contribution: Represents the relative contribution to organic net sales growth/(decrease)
and/or constant currency net sales growth of changes in product prices for the current period
compared to the prior period.

    - Volume/mix contribution: Represents the relative contribution to organic net sales
growth/(decrease) and/or constant currency net sales growth of changes in volume/mix for the
current period compared to the prior period.

    - Underlying volume/mix contribution: Represents the relative contribution to organic net sales
growth/(decrease) and/or constant currency net sales growth of changes in volume/mix, adjusted
for the impact of the product portfolio upgrade, rationalization, renovation and other self-directed
initiatives for the current period compared to the prior period, which we have calculated for the
years ended December 31, 2022 and 2023, and the twelve months ended March 31, 2024 only.

    - Historical leverage ratio: Our historical leverage ratio represents the ratio of our (i) net debt, which
is defined as our financial liabilities gross of unamortized financing fees less cash and cash
equivalents, excluding lease liabilities and derivative financial instruments to (ii) Normalized
EBITDA.

Our management believes that the foregoing non-IFRS financial measures are helpful indicators of the
underlying performance or liquidity of the business. Management believes that the foregoing non-IFRS financial
measures are meaningful for investors because they provide an analysis of our operating results, profitability and
ability to service debt and, because these measures are used by management to track business evolution, establish
operational and strategic targets and make important business decisions. In addition, these measures are commonly
used by investors, security analysts and other interested parties in our industry as supplemental measures of
operating performance or liquidity. Although we present these measures to enhance the understanding of our
historical operating performance, they should not be considered alternatives to operating profit as an indicator of
operating performance or profitability, or alternatives to cash flows from operating activities as measures of
liquidity.

performance determined in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, such as gross profit or

Revolving Credit Facility, the Senior Term Facilities, the Senior Notes outstanding following the
completion of the Transactions and lease liabilities under IFRS 16 (Leases). Adjusted net total debt
represents our adjusted total debt less adjusted cash and cash equivalents.

_This summary highlights selected information from this Offering Memorandum. The summary below_

_“Risk Factors” section and our financial statements and the notes to those statements. In addition, certain_
_statements include forward-looking information that involves risks and uncertainties. See “Forward-Looking_
_Statements.”_

**Overview**

We are a global leader in plant-based food, established in 2018, as a purpose-driven company with a
clear vision: “To make people healthier and happier with nutritious and delicious, natural, plant-based food that
is good for you and good for our planet.”

We develop, produce, distribute and market plant-based dairy alternative products in over 100 countries
across four core categories: Butters and Spreads, Creams, Liquids and Cheeses. Backed by a rich heritage and a
global scale, we are highly differentiated in the plant-based sector. Our reinvigorated iconic power brands reflect
over 150 years of product expertise and brand heritage and are trusted by consumers globally. Our scale, culture
and capabilities, including extensive food technology and innovation expertise, our community of dedicated
“Upfielders,” consisting of our management team and employees, and our 14 manufacturing facilities across five
continents, provide a strong value proposition for our customers and consumers, and ensure we are well positioned
to advance the future of food.

Our products are marketed under a family of historic and iconic brands with strong recognition in their
target markets. Our products are made with natural and sustainably sourced ingredients. Our carefully selected
ingredients come from a diversified supply chain to minimize risk and environmental impact and maximize taste,
functionality, health, affordability and sustainability for our consumers.

Our operations are diversified across three regions, namely Europe, the Americas and AMEA. We hold
leadership positions in the global butter and spreads, and plant cheese segments, with leadership positions in
creams in Germany and the United Kingdom, our key creams markets. We sell our products across these regions
primarily through retail channels, such as supermarkets, hypermarkets, convenience stores and other outlets. In
addition, through our professional foodservice channel, we sell our products to commercial outlets, such as quick
service restaurants, bakeries, pizza and pasta outlets, hotels, catering and industrial kitchens, and to the social
sector, such as educational institutions, workplaces and hospitals.

During the years ended December 31, 2021, 2022 and 2023, our net sales were €2,793 million, €3,375
million and €3,275 million, respectively. During the same periods, our operating profit was €288 million, €453
million and €570 million, and our Normalized EBITDA was €666 million, €749 million and €831 million,
respectively. During the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, our net sales were €3,209 million, our operating
profit was €604 million and Normalized EBITDA was €862 million.

**_Our Successful Transformation_**

Following the acquisition of our business by KKR in 2018, we began a journey to separate, transform
and reinvent our business, building on our existing strong foundations: a global platform with iconic power brands
and world-class knowledge.

Our journey took more than four years, with the wholescale transformational part of our journey
completed in 2022. To become an independent business, we focused on separating and stabilizing our business,
simplifying, renovating and innovating our product portfolio, expanding into new product categories, investing in
R&D through the opening of a new Food Science Centre, optimizing our supply chain, building an end-to-end
globally scaled and digitally-enabled platform and building a new IT infrastructure. See “Business—History” for
a detailed description of our transformation journey.

Building on our existing strong foundations and as a result of the significant industrial, digital and cultural
transformation undertaken since 2018, we believe we are well positioned to advance the future of food.

1


-----

**Strengths**

**_We are well positioned to advance the Future of Food in a large and growing TAM_**

We believe that the future of food lies in tasty, high-quality, responsibly made, plant-based food.
Transforming the food system by increasing the consumption of plant-based foods in our diets is the key to address
the impact of what we eat on climate, nature and health. As a global leader in plant-based food, offering our
products in four large and growing categories and selling into over 100 countries worldwide, we are well
positioned to advance the future of food and to meet the growing shift in consumer preferences to plant-based
eating. To inspire more people to eat plant-based alternatives, we focus on delivering tasty, high performing,
healthy, sustainable and affordable products. We believe that there should be no compromise for consumers when
they change to plant-based products as compared to dairy alternatives.

We benefit from a senior management team with significant experience in the consumer-packaged goods
industry. A majority of our current senior management team has been with us since our acquisition by KKR in
2018, and has been critical in our successful transformation. Under their leadership, we have separated,
transformed and reinvented our business as a global leader in plant-based food and strongly positioned our
business to drive conversion to plant-based alternatives. We believe that our senior management team has also
been instrumental in developing a strong and motivated organization with a purpose- and performance-driven
culture, which is carried by a passionate and engaged community of “Upfielders.” We believe that our community
of “Upfielders” are aligned with our purpose, and are highly motivated to make an impact, deliver sustainable,
purposeful long-term growth and advance the transition to a plant-based food future.

Our ability to advance the future of food is further strengthened by our portfolio of Plant Butter and
Spreads, Plant Creams, Liquids and Plant Cheeses products, sold through our reinvigorated and iconic brands, our
global scale and manufacturing footprint, our food technology and innovation expertise which together provide a
strong value proposition for our customers and consumers.

We offer these plant-based products in our four core categories: Butters and Spreads, Creams, Liquids
and Cheeses, which provide us access to a large and growing TAM (across both dairy and non-dairy) of
approximately €151 billion as of 2022, which is 15 times larger than our TAM of approximately €11 billion in
2017 under our previous ownership (which was focused on plant-based spreads (margarines)). Our expansion into
the Butter, Creams, Liquids and Cheeses categories, in addition to Spreads, resulted in an expansion of our TAM.
While currently the penetration of plant-based products in the Butters, Creams and Cheeses categories is low, and
estimated at less than 1%, there is a potential opportunity of approximately €23 billion (based on an incremental
€7 billion opportunity in the above categories when assuming a 5% plant-based penetration) or €38 billion (based
on an incremental €22 billion opportunity in the above categories when assuming a 16% plant-based penetration)
(see also “Industry—Upfield’s TAM”). We believe that our global footprint and renovated and innovative product
portfolio provide a significant growth opportunity in our TAM. Within our TAM (which covers both dairy and
non-dairy products), given the growing consumer preference for plant-based diets in the backdrop of
environmental, sustainability and health concerns, there is potential for increased rate of conversion to plant-based
products, which we are well positioned to leverage, especially given our strong position globally and in the key
markets in which we operate. For instance, according to NielsenIQ measurement data, within our Plant Butter and
Spreads core category, which contributed 81% of our net sales for the year ended December 31, 2023, we are the
largest producer globally in terms of market share and hold leading positions across some of the largest butter and
spreads markets globally, including North America, Germany and the United Kingdom. In addition, according to
NielsenIQ measurement data, we are the global leader in the plant cheese segment, and have leadership positions
in creams in Germany and the United Kingdom, our key creams markets.

**_A reinvigorated portfolio of brands reshaping the future of food_**

With our portfolio of trusted brands we believe we can drive conversion to plant-based food and leverage
our strong market positions going forward. Our brand platforms are led by our power brands, our most iconic
brands, which have a long history and heritage. We believe that our power brands are deeply rooted and trusted
by our consumers and customers across a number of our markets and have high brand awareness in their respective
markets. These brands include, for example, Flora (launched in 1964), Country Crock (launched in 1954), Becel
+ProActiv (Becel launched in 1962 and ProActiv launched in 2000), Rama (launched in 1924), BlueBand
(launched in 1916) and Violife (acquired in 2020). In addition to our power brands, we also have a number of
country or region specific brands with a strong local heritage and brand awareness, such as Lätta in Sweden, Stork
in the United Kingdom and Tulipan in Spain.

2


-----

Following our acquisition by KKR, we have also reorganized and reinvigorated our brand portfolio since
2018. We refreshed our brands around our end-to-end brand platforms, so as to provide for better harmonization
and efficiencies across our R&D and innovation pipeline, sales and marketing and supply chain activities. Our
brand platforms are founded upon key prerequisites of taste and affordability, but each platform serves a distinct
consumer need and is mapped against the key usage occasions and growth opportunities across our categories and
markets.

We also organize our brands across three different price tiers: “good,” (targeting price sensitive
customers) “better” (targeting customers looking for additional product benefits at a more affordable price than a
dairy alternative) and “best” (targeting customers seeking premium products with multiple features, such as
lowering cholesterol). We assign our brands and products across these tiers which are each designed to meet
distinct consumer needs and cater for certain price sensitivities, thereby catering to various social demographic
needs. We believe that such categorization simplifies consumer decision-making and helps us strategically
position each tier to appeal to a different array of consumers.

**_Well-invested end-to-end platform_**

We operate an end-to-end globally scaled and digitally-enabled platform, in which we have made
significant investment in recent years, and through which we produce and sell our products to retail and
foodservice partners in over 100 countries globally. We operate a global network of manufacturing facilities and
regional cold chain distribution centers with capabilities to support growth. Our historic strong cash generation
has enabled us to invest significantly in our global operations, ensuring we have the latest manufacturing
innovations at our disposal. We own a total of 14 manufacturing facilities, comprising seven in Europe, four in
the Americas and three in AMEA. These facilities produced approximately 91% of our total production volume
for the year ended December 31, 2023. Our comprehensive manufacturing network with a globally scaled and
digitally-enabled supply chain, is well positioned for future growth. Our end-to-end platform is supported by our
general ERP system and our SAP4Hana ERP system, which enable us to make data-driven operational decisions.

Our robust in-house manufacturing capabilities allow for complete control and flexibility in the
manufacturing process, through which we can (i) maintain a closer level of control over our robust quality and
safety standards, (ii) better establish and control cost savings, (iii) limit and control manufacturing disruptions,
(iv) reduce our carbon footprint and (v) manage the manufacturing process more efficiently.

Our products and customers further benefit from our internal centralized procurement function designed
to leverage our purchasing expertise and maximize scale efficiencies across the regions where we operate. Our
procurement function has a deep understanding of commodity cycles and risk management, and many years of
experience in the oils market. See “Business—Procurement” for a detailed description of our procurement
function.

**_An industry leading R&D expertise delivering innovation and driving conversion to plant-based food_**

Our strong innovation pipeline underpins our mission to revolutionize the plant-based ecosystem by
delivering tastier, high-quality products with natural ingredients. That pipeline is driven by our investment in
R&D, oils & fats and plant-based proteins amongst other enabling technologies, with food science at its core. We
believe that we have an industry leading R&D expertise that enables us to produce new and innovative products
using key ingredient know-how, technically sophisticated equipment and processes across our core categories and
products. As an insights-driven organization we seek to continually enhance consumer experience with respect to
taste, functionality, health and nutrition, sustainability and affordability by developing relevant product and
packaging innovation.

We continuously invest in food innovation and food technology expertise from our new state-of-the-art
food science centre in Wageningen, the Netherlands (“Food Science Centre”), which we have developed with an
investment capital of approximately €38 million. Our Food Science Centre focuses on plant-based food innovation
and it aims to pioneer the development of plant-based foods, enabling technologies including oils and fats as well
as proteins, and sustainable packaging solutions. Our team of more than 150 food scientists, food and packaging
technologists and specialists focus on the development of plant-based foods and sustainable packaging solutions.
We are also a leading filer of plant-based patents, and hold 656 patents and patent applications. In 2023, we
applied for a further ten patents across our categories and core technologies.

With our deep expertise in plant-based and natural ingredients and proprietary knowledge of plant-based
food manufacturing, we have implemented a significant product portfolio overhaul since 2018, focused on taste,

3


-----

clean label and naturalness, where possible. For instance, we developed our first-generation Plant Butter product
between 2018 and 2020, which we have since then further evolved, offering products we aim to achieve taste
parity as compared to dairy butter. We have also developed new recipes and ingredients for our products, for
example to provide consumers with palm oil-free options through our patented technology. In 2023, we
successfully launched our paper tub packaging technology in Austria under our Flora Plant brand, with similar
launches in the United Kingdom and the Netherlands in early 2024. Our R&D and innovation roadmap is centered
on continuous improvement and innovation within our core categories, to attract more and more consumers and
broaden the appeal of our products. Key areas of focus include further improving our Plant Cheese product range,
in particular in cold applications to further improve our Plant Cheese offering and applying some of our developing
technology to further improve our Plant Butters and Plant Creams products. In addition, we continue to develop
our packaging technology to create sustainable packaging and achieve our goal to reduce the environmental impact
of our packaging through reduced plastic usage and increased recyclability of our packaging. As well as innovating
internally to achieve these goals, we partner with academia, established ingredients and packaging players, startups and scale-ups whose differentiated propositions we believe can complement our R&D capabilities and our
ability to scale through our distribution channels, platform and growth levers.

**_Growth levers underpinned by a resilient, attractive financial profile with high cash generation_**

Our growth levers are centered around driving conversion from dairy products to our plant-based
products and involve:

    - Creating the best-ever products made by us: delivering tastier, high-quality products with natural
ingredients in our four core categories, underpinned by a strong innovation pipeline;

    - Deploying our power brands: leveraging our iconic power brands, recognized and trusted across
markets, with clear propositions;

    - Executing in multiple channels: reaching as many people as possible by executing well within our
channels: retail and foodservice; and

    - Driving and leveraging our scale: leveraging our digitally enabled end-to-end platform and scale.

Our transformation journey since 2018 has taken place against a turbulent and volatile backdrop of events
including a global pandemic, associated supply chain challenges, commodity inflation and the ongoing cost-ofliving crisis. However, during this period, by leveraging our growth levers, we have demonstrated a track record
of stable financial performance, in particular delivered strong growth in organic net sales, gross profit and
Normalized EBITDA. Between the year ended December 31, 2021 and the twelve months ended March 31, 2024,
our reported net sales increased at a CAGR of 6.4%, our gross profit increased at a CAGR of 11.4% and our
Normalized EBITDA increased at a CAGR of 12.1%.

We have also demonstrated strong cash generation, and generated a normalized free cash flow and
normalized free cash conversion ratio of €702 million and 81.4%, respectively, in each case, for the twelve months
ended March 31, 2024. We believe this compares favorably with our peers and is supported by, among other
things:

    - our flexible cost base, which allows for a sustainable gross margin. We have clear, consistent and
well-established supply chain, and hedging policies with respect to our major inputs and foreign
exchange exposures, which has allowed us to maintain strong levels of profitability in periods of
fluctuations and under high inflationary conditions;

    - our sustained profitability, with a Normalized EBITDA margin of 23.8%, 22.2%, 25.4% and 26.9%,
in the years ended December 31, 2021, 2022 and 2023, and the twelve months ended March 31,
2024, respectively, largely attributable to our flexible cost structure, our powerful brands, our
revenue growth management capabilities and our track record of operational cost savings;

    - a favorable working capital position, as we benefit from a negative cash conversion cycle. This
largely is a structural feature of the payment terms customarily available in the raw material and
finished product markets in which we operate and our operational efficiency with respect to our
inventory management; and

4


-----

    - our comprehensive manufacturing network with a globally scaled and digitally-enabled supply
chain and significant spare capacity. This allows for increased net sales volumes without
incremental capital expenditure resulting in strong cash generation.

Our strong cash generation and resulting Normalized EBITDA growth has helped us to progressively
deleverage. For the years ended December 31, 2021, 2022 and 2023, and for the twelve months ended March 31,
2024, our historical leverage ratio was 8.4x, 7.2x, 6.5x and 6.5x, respectively. Our historical leverage ratio
represents the ratio of our (i) net debt, which is defined as our financial liabilities gross of unamortized financing
fees less cash and cash equivalents, excluding lease liabilities and derivative financial instruments to (ii)
Normalized EBITDA.

**Strategies**

Our strategies are focused on the continued implementation of our growth levers to capture the key
opportunities across our core categories and markets. Our clear mission and purpose forms the cornerstone of our
strategy to deliver long term sustainable, profitable and purposeful growth by bringing tasty plant-based foods to
people all over the world, and achieve our purpose “to make people healthier and happier with nutritious and
delicious, natural, plant-based food that is good for you and for our planet.”

**_Our growth levers_**

_Creating the best-ever products made by us: delivering tastier, high-quality products with natural ingredients in_
_our four core categories, underpinned by a strong innovation pipeline_

Since 2018, we have reinvented our product portfolio, investing significant resources to create the bestever products made by us, including by harmonizing and simplifying our ingredients list and moving towards
fewer, natural and fully plant-based ingredients. We are focused on delivering our best-ever products that are
designed to have the same or superior taste, versatility and performance (cooking, baking, and spreading) as dairy
products. We believe that there should be no compromise for consumers when they change to a plant-based butter
or spread, liquid, plant-based cream or plant-based cheese, as compared to dairy alternatives. For example, our
Plant Butter is specifically formulated with the aim to match the performance and taste of dairy butter. Based on
more than 50 taste profiles, we created a series of plant butters which we strive to taste and perform just like dairy
butter and that match the specific taste preferences of different consumer profiles in key markets. Also, our knowhow and expertise of natural ingredients has enabled us to simplify our Plant Butter to contain just six or seven
natural ingredients (including certain Plant Oils, water, plant protein and, in some cases, salt) and enable
consumers to swap it directly for dairy butter in any recipe.

Consumers are also increasingly focused on clean label and naturalness, and 99% of all our ingredients
by volume are natural in origin. We continue to invest in R&D to deliver products using recipes made from natural
ingredients or products that are free from artificial colors, flavors and preservatives, and without compromising
on food safety, quality and performance. In addition, as part of our commitment to be 100% plant-based by the
end of 2030, we are continuously reviewing our use of dairy ingredients where there is no compromise in taste or
performance.

Aside from taste and performance, we focus on the nutritional benefits of our products, as well as their
positive contribution to health. Health is a high priority for consumers and a key reason why people choose our
products. In 2022, our team of nutritionists and product developers created the Upfield nutritional benchmarking
program, based on what science tells us is required for each different product proposition and which introduced
saturated fat and trans-fat targets for plant creams and plant cheeses. This helps us ensure that we meet nutritional
targets in our products and are aligned with international dietary guidelines and regulations. Our plant-based
products contain zero trans-fats and lower saturated fats compared to dairy alternatives.

So, whether consumers are looking for a product to bake a cake, help lower their cholesterol or containing
the nutrients to support a growing family, our products strive to provide a “no compromise” choice, that is better
for consumers and better for the planet.

_Deploying our power brands: leveraging our iconic power brands, recognized, trusted and loved over the world_
_with clear propositions_

Our business traces its origin and heritage back over 150 years and, as a result, many of our reinvigorated
iconic power brands, including BlueBand and Rama, have a brand heritage spanning over 100 years. Our power

5


-----

brands, including as an example, Flora, Country Crock, Becel +ProActiv, Rama, BlueBand and Violife, are trusted
in their key markets globally and are at the heart of our future growth strategy and success.

Our power brands are well-known and have a high brand awareness amongst consumers in our markets.
They represent the platform from which we have successfully launched our product innovations and portfolio
renovation. Through our power brands we engage with both loyal and new consumers, offering people a positive
choice, both as a plant-based alternative to dairy and also for less competitive brands and private label. Based on
independent brand research, many of our power brands are among the best-performing FMCG/packaged grocery
brands across our key markets in terms of brand awareness. We believe that the high score of our power brands
indicate that consumers are more likely to choose our brands over others, which is a strong indicator of increasing
brand influence and share. To further support our power brands, we complemented the ongoing innovation across
our portfolio with an increase in strategic advertising and promotion investment. For the year ended December
31, 2023, our advertising and promotion expenses amounted to €173 million (equalling 5.3% of our net sales for
the year ended December 31, 2023 and an increase of 22.7% compared to the year ended December 31, 2022).
For example, in 2023, we launched our “Skip the Cow” campaign aimed at informing and driving consumers
towards more plant-based products. Our “Skip the Cow” campaign pushed the uptake of Flora Plant and has
proved to be a valuable resource in boosting consumer awareness of our Plant Butter offering and also contributed
to a strong positive consumer net sentiment of 86% towards our overall Flora brand. Furthermore, following the
“Skip the Cow” campaign, Flora Plant Butter experienced growth in household penetration and share of segment
in the United Kingdom. Following the success of the “Skip the Cow” campaign in the United Kingdom, we
launched similar campaigns across European markets, such as Germany and Austria, and intend to also roll it out
to other key markets such as the Netherlands, Poland or Spain, and also across other brands. To further leverage
the strength of our brands, we have from time to time considered, and continue to consider and evaluate,
modifications to our corporate branding and identity to more closely align with our key brands.

_Executing in multiple channels: reaching as many people as possible through our channels: retail and foodservice_

We also differentiate ourselves through our retail and professional foodservice channels, which enable
us to reach consumers directly through both industry channels. We sell our products to retail outlets, including to
many of the world’s largest retailers, as well as to wholesalers. We also enhanced our e-commerce capabilities by
developing relationships with various online retailers and e-commerce platforms, such as Ocado, Tesco, Amazon
and Carrefour online, which have seen an increase in retail market share in recent years and which we believe
represent a significant growth opportunity in the regions in which we operate, especially in Europe and the
Americas. In addition, in emerging markets in which we operate across our regions, we have established a strong
market channel based on deep relationships with well-known and reputable distributors. Through our foodservice
channel, we also supply the professional channel, including restaurants, hotels and industrial kitchens. This multichannel approach gives us access to a broad and diverse customer base, which enhances our position as a leader
in many of our core categories. Because of our strong relationships with leading global and regional retailers, we
operate as the supplier of choice and/or “category captain” for certain strategic retailers, providing in-depth
knowledge and consumer insight for particular product categories to our retailer customers.

Moreover, we believe there is considerable potential to introduce and expand our core product categories
in the foodservice channel given our current portfolio’s appeal across high-end clients who lead and influence the
menu adoption cycle to large quick-service restaurants, bakery chains and other national accounts where mass
adoption occurs. Our growth strategy in foodservice is focused on selling value-added branded products with
high-demand applications to commercial customers and driving customer acquisition through our chef-led sales
approach (see also “—Sales and Marketing”).

_Driving and leveraging our scale: leveraging our digitally enabled end-to-end platform and scale_

Through our end-to-end globally scaled and digitally-enabled platform we produce and sell our products
to retail and foodservice partners in over 100 countries globally. Our global footprint, scale and expertise along
the value chain allow us to leverage efficiencies through which we can derive significant advantages compared to
other plant-based competitors and dairy players. Since 2018, we have demonstrated a track record in driving
efficiencies for example by establishing product portfolio efficiencies (through the retirement of SKUs that are
less profitable or of low productivity and the simplification of our recipes), procurement efficiencies (by sourcing
most of our ingredients and packaging materials from global suppliers who can deliver locally), supply chain
efficiencies (through our established local retail and distribution network) and by maintaining a continued focus
on operational efficiencies in line with our value creation program. Establishing such efficiencies allows us to
offer affordable products.

6


-----

**_Continuously delivering our Purpose_**

Our purpose is “to make people healthier and happier with nutritious and delicious, natural, plant-based
food that is good for you and for our planet” and it shapes how we approach the sourcing of our ingredients, the
development of our recipes, our relationships with retailers and how we communicate with consumers. We intend
to continue fulfilling our purpose with our commitment and initiatives across our four pillars: (i) plant-based, (ii)
healthier lives, (iii) happier people and (iv) better planet, which are at the heart of our business with tangible
programs and milestones.

_Plant-Based_

Actively helping the food transition and building a better, plant-based future is at the heart of what we
do. Our plant-based commitment pillar seeks to help inspire and encourage consumers to switch from dairy to
plant-based options. As we continue to improve our product portfolio, we aim to reach one billion consumers with
our products by 2030. We believe we can achieve that goal by offering consumers a range of products that meet
their needs, which also includes making sure our products taste great, perform well, and are made with simple,
natural ingredients.

We believe we are in a strong position to support the transition to a plant-based diet by offering tasty,
affordable, nutritious and more sustainable products. From our Food Science Centre, we continuously invest in
high performance product formulations and reformulations to keep up with consumer needs and trends. For
example, in 2023, we launched the Violife cream cheese block in the United States which has been developed
specifically to compete with leading dairy cream cheeses on the market, following a completely new formulation
and format.

To spread awareness around our plant-based products, we frequently launch retail consumer advertising
campaigns with slogans aimed at informing and driving consumers and professionals towards more plant-based
products. Other efforts to boost our brands’ and products’ visibility include, for example, sponsorship of sporting
events and partnerships with celebrities and influencers.

In addition, we are also working to support the industry moving forward in terms of plant-based
innovation, which includes establishing standard parameters for plant-based products. For example, we are
currently leading the development of a new ISO standard that we expect will specify technical definitions of, and
criteria for, plant-based foods. We believe that this new ISO standard will help align the global food industry
around a single terminology approach.

_Healthier Lives_

The second pillar focuses on the nutritional benefits of our products as well as their positive contribution
to health. Health is a high priority for consumers and we believe is a key reason why people choose our products.
We aim for our products to outperform their dairy counterparts with respect to levels of saturated and trans-fats.
We take a science-based approach to establishing criteria and targets for each product type we sell, considering
who uses them, how frequently and in which applications. These targets are based on recognized external
international standards and official dietary recommendations, including those from the World Health
Organization. Moreover, we have set additional targets that ensure we can deliver the desired nutritional
composition. These include considerations on how we can limit nutrients of concern and provide essential
nutrients that target some of the greatest public health areas of concern, such as heart health and children’s growth
and development. Our brands BlueBand and Becel +ProActiv are our global brands focused on positively
impacting lives across the world by offering healthy, affordable and nutritious options. In 2023, approximately
30% of our net sales came from products providing health and nutrition benefits and that can be labelled as such,
in compliance with regulation.

Additionally, we believe the future of food lies in quality, responsibly made, plant-based foods. To realize
this future and provide consumers with healthier options, we intend to continue implementing rigorous quality
and safety standards at both our and third-party facilities, including for product design, formulation, raw material
sourcing, packing, manufacturing, storage, transport, display, marketing, communication, sales and product
disposal. Moreover, we intend to continue ensuring that our products are accessible to as many people as possible,
which includes ensuring our products come in at affordable price points. In this regard we intend to maintain a
portfolio of products designed for budgetary brackets across the market spectrum and which are more affordable
than dairy alternatives, without compromising on quality.

7


-----

_Happier People_

We believe that people are happier when they are engaged and we actively promote a culture of active support.
We are committed to our community of dedicated “Upfielders.” Our approach to employee engagement is driven
by three core values: performance, care and passion. To nurture an engaged workforce, we complete an annual
survey to gauge employee sentiment and opportunities for progress. In addition, diverse businesses are likely to
be more successful and we are committed to creating a diverse and inclusive working environment. Across our
supply chains, we are connected to thousands of farmers and plant-based entrepreneurs who grow our ingredients
and chefs who create and prepare millions of meals every day. In support of farmers and plant-based entrepreneurs,
we maintain several partnerships, enabling and encouraging them to improve agricultural practices and access to
markets.

In addition, we seek to reach as many chefs and food service professionals as possible to encourage the
adoption of our products into their cooking, thereby engaging chefs in the plant-based revolution. We do this by,
for example, hosting cooking workshops for chefs or participating in trade fairs where we can reach out and
educate professionals on the advantages of plant-based cooking.

_Better Planet_

With an environmental footprint significantly smaller than that of dairy products, our products can help
consumers reduce their impact, and we ensure our operations do so as well. We are committed to responsibly
sourcing ingredients, developing sustainable packaging and addressing our carbon emissions to enhance
sustainability.

Our better planet commitments include our environmental targets to address our material environmental
impacts on the climate, on packaging and on responsible sourcing. For the year ended December 31, 2023, we
committed to Science Based Target Initiative (“SBTi”) and have worked on redefining our targets in line with the
newly published Forest, Land and Agriculture (“FLAG”) guidance to align with limiting global warming to 1.5
degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels. In this respect, we are making multiple efforts towards reducing our
emissions and reducing environmental impact through waste and water management at our manufacturing
facilities. In addition, we are committed to providing packaging that protects products and the planet. We delivered
a milestone packaging achievement with the launch of the world’s first paper-based tub for plant-based butters
and spreads, our Flora Plant paper tub at the end of 2023, starting our journey towards our target of reducing
plastic across our portfolio by 80% by 2030 (compared to a 2020 baseline). In addition, we are committed to
responsible and sustainable sourcing of our ingredients (including our Plant Oils) and packaging materials
(including paper and pulp) and our “Responsible Sourcing Policy” and “Business Partner Code of Conduct”
applies to all our suppliers. Where key ingredients are identified as potentially high risk, we maintain strong
individual policies designed to address the potential risks inherent in these supply chains, particularly focussing
on deforestation and exploitation. See also “Business— Environmental, Social, Governance (“ESG”).”

(1) As we are a geographically diversified business with global operations, we undertake transactions in various currencies. As a result, a
number of our subsidiaries report their financial results in currencies other than the euro, which is the reporting currency of our
consolidated financial statements. So as to enhance comparability of some of key financial metrics, including net sales growth, gross
profit growth, gross margin growth, Normalized EBITDA growth and Normalized EBITDA margin growth, we present such metrics on
a constant currency basis. The exchange rates used for the calculation of such constant currency exchange rate metrics for a particular

21


-----

period represent the average exchange rates of the relevant currency for the prior period. By presenting such metrics on a constant
currency basis, we exclude the impact of foreign currency fluctuations such that both the current and prior period local currency values
are translated into euro using prior year average exchange rates. See “Presentation of Financial and Other Information—Non IFRS
_Financial Measures—Constant Currency Exchange Rate Measures” for the exchange rates used by us to calculate constant currency_
exchange rate measures in respect of our principal currencies for the relevant periods. For each such period, the exchange rates mentioned
under “Presentation of Financial and Other Information—Non IFRS Financial Measures—Constant Currency Exchange Rate
_Measures” represent the average exchange rates of the relevant currency for the prior period._

(2) Organic net sales growth/(decrease) presents a “like–for-like” comparative growth rate, and represents the change in net sales for the
current period compared to the comparable prior period, calculated on a constant currency basis and by eliminating any change in scope
between the relevant periods. Such change in scope between periods may result from: (i) an acquisition, divestiture or disposal of our
business in a country or a major market or that of a business unit; (ii) changes to the business model under which we operate in a specific
market, or with respect to the manner in which a particular product is (or particular products are) sold by us in that market (for example,
if we change our local operating model from a distributor model to a royalty model, or if we change from third-party manufacturing
(wherein such third-party manufacturer typically sources raw materials) to toll manufacturing (wherein we typically supply raw
materials to a third party manufacturer) or (iii) the adoption of an accounting standard or a change in the application of an accounting
principle, if applicable. We commenced calculating organic net sales growth/(decrease) beginning for the year ended December 31,
2023. Accordingly, we present organic net sales growth/(decrease) for the year ended December 31, 2023, the three months ended
March 31, 2023 and March 31, 2024 and the twelve months ended March 31, 2024 only. See also “Management’s Discussion and
_Analysis of Financial Condition and Our Results of Operation—Results of Operations” for a discussion on the reasons for the change_
in organic net sales growth/(decrease) and/or constant currency net sales growth (as described below), including in our operating
segments, for the periods presented in this Offering Memorandum.

(3) Constant currency net sales growth presents the change in net sales for the relevant period compared to the prior period, calculated on a
constant currency basis. We present constant currency net sales growth for the years ended December 31, 2021 and December 31, 2022
only.

(4) Represents the growth rate of our reported gross profit (which is our net sales minus cost of sales) calculated on a constant currency
basis.

(5) Represents our reported gross margin (calculated as our net sales minus cost of sales divided by net sales, and expressed as a percentage).

(6) Represents the growth rate of our reported gross margin calculated on a constant currency basis.

(7) Normalized EBITDA is a non-IFRS metric which is defined as net profit/(loss) before income tax expense, net finance costs,
depreciation of property, plant and equipment (including right of use assets) and amortization of intangible assets, as adjusted for sharebased payment expenses and certain non-underlying items that we do not consider to be part of the Group’s daily business operations,
due to the nature, frequency, and predictability of their occurrence. While the amounts included in Normalized EBITDA have been
derived from our consolidated financial statements or management accounts, they are not financial measures calculated in accordance
with IFRS. Accordingly, they should not be considered as alternatives to net profit/(loss) or operating profit/(loss) as indicators of our
performance, or as alternatives to operating cash flows as a measure of our liquidity. Our management uses Normalized EBITDA to
assess our operating performance. In addition, we believe that Normalized EBITDA is a measure commonly used by investors.
Normalized EBITDA, as presented in this Offering Memorandum, may not be comparable to similarly titled measures reported by other

_The order in which the risks are presented is not an indication of the likelihood of the risks actually materializing,_

**Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry**

**_Fluctuations in the price and availability of raw materials, as well as increases of supply chain costs, may have a_**
**_material adverse effect on our results of operations._**

The principal ingredient in our Plant Butter and Spreads, Plant Creams, Liquids and Plant Cheeses are refined
Plant Oils. Aside from Plant Oils, additional key inputs used in our production process include other natural ingredients,
packaging materials and utility inputs such as water and energy. We obtain substantially all of our raw materials from
third-party suppliers, with cost of such materials (which includes Plant Oils, other ingredients, flavors, finished goods
from third-party manufacturers and packaging materials) representing 67% and 68% of our total cost of sales, for the year
ended December 31, 2023 and the three months ended March 31, 2024, respectively.

The availability and cost of Plant Oils and other ingredients used in our products can fluctuate substantially over
relatively short periods of time due to a number of factors beyond our control, such as general economic conditions,
agricultural policies, government programs, weather conditions such as frosts, drought and floods, and plant diseases,
pests and other acts of nature. In particular, price volatility has increased since the outset of the COVID-19 pandemic, as
well as due to the ongoing conflicts between Russia and Ukraine and in the Middle East. For example, although we do
not source sunflower oil from Ukraine directly, as Ukraine is the world’s biggest exporter of sunflower oil, beginning the
first quarter of the year ended December 31, 2022, the war in Ukraine caused a global shortage of sunflower oil, which
in turn led to a rise in the price of sunflower oil during the year ended December 31, 2022. Although, in response to
possible disruptions in the supply chain, we created a formula that allows us to substitute and swap ingredients within our
Butters and Spreads (such as sunflower oil for rapeseed oil), without any impact on the taste, texture or functionality of
our products, such substitution of our recipes to prevent any supply chain disruptions may result in a higher cost base as
this generally results in incremental R&D costs and a need to adjust packaging. The increase in sunflower oil prices has
also had a knock-on effect on the prices of other Plant Oils, including palm, rapeseed and soybean oil, which have seen a
further spike in demand as a result of their growing use as biofuel. The price of palm oil has also increased in recent years
due to slower production by the main producer nations, and the recently adopted domestic market obligation policy in
Indonesia, which is the world’s largest palm oil producer. Pursuant to this policy, palm oil producers in Indonesia had to
set aside a certain quantity of palm oil for local buyers, thereby limiting the amount available for export. In addition, the
increase in inflation globally since 2022 has further increased our costs of acquiring ingredients and the contributed to
general volatility of commodity prices, and this inflationary impact continues. We may not be able to preserve our gross
profit margin if such volatility, fluctuations and high inflationary conditions were to persist, as we may have limited
ability to flow through our increased commodity cost in our pricing, which in turn could have a material adverse effect
on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

The past years’ significant volatility in commodity prices, the significant surge in energy and transportation
prices, as well as the supply chain interruptions caused by recent geopolitical and economic events, adversely impacted
our inputs suppliers’ cost base which they subsequently passed on to us. For example, because of the energy intensive
nature of the refinery process to turn crude oils into refined oils, our Plant Oils suppliers have sought to pass on their
heightened energy costs to us. All of this has exposed us in turn to significantly higher Plant Oils, packaging, energy
costs, and as a consequence thereof, higher manufacturing, logistics and transportation costs, which we may not be able

25


-----

to effectively hedge or fully pass on to our customers. There can be no assurance that we or our third-party manufacturers
will be able to obtain alternative sources of raw materials or packaging materials at reasonable prices, or at all, should
there be shortages or other unfavorable conditions.

To manage our input costs, we regularly monitor global market prices and enter into hedging arrangements,
principally in respect of the major Plant Oils we purchase as well as utilities. We use a combination of fixed contracts and
commodity derivatives (futures, over the counter and tradable forward contracts) to hedge against commodity price risk.
Our policy is to hedge the majority of the risk within the relevant pricing window, and typically on a three to six months
rolling basis. However, there can be no assurance that such hedging transactions will successfully reduce our exposure to
price volatility in the long term and, given our limited customer negotiation windows, there may be a time lag between
the implementation of our pricing initiatives and the impact of inflation across our key inputs.

Our inability to obtain adequate supplies of raw materials for our products or other supply chain inputs at
reasonable prices, or at all, as a result of any of the foregoing factors or otherwise, could cause an increase in our cost
of sales and a corresponding decrease in our gross profit margin, or cause our net sales to fluctuate from period to
period. Such fluctuations may result in a decrease in gross profit margin and could have a material adverse effect on our
business, financial condition and results of operations.

**_Changes in food trends and consumer preferences may have a material adverse effect on our results of operations._**

Trends within our industry change often and our failure to anticipate, identify or react to changes in these trends
could, among other things, lead to reduced demand and price reductions and could have a material adverse effect on our
business, financial condition and results of operations.

There are a number of changing consumer trends, demands and preferences which have an effect on both our
Group and the industry in which we operate. These include dietary, health and environmental concerns and trends, such
as increasing awareness of different nutritional aspects of foods and the health effects and sourcing practices relating to
specific ingredients, an increasing preference for dairy-free, vegan and organic food ingredients, trends towards eating
outside of home and concerns regarding public health consequences associates with obesity and increasing awareness of
the environmental and social effects of production (in particular those related to palm oil, which is a key ingredient in
many products across our portfolio). Currently, there is an increasing trend of consumers across markets preferring nondairy, plant-based products as a result of the increasing awareness of lactose-intolerance health issues, high carbon
footprint and the environmental impact of dairy consumption. However, this growing trend towards plant-based
alternatives may be adversely impacted by a number of factors, such as misconceptions about “highly processed” plantbased foods, perceived “naturalness” of dairy and increased regulatory control of the plant-based sector. In addition, there
has been negative press coverage in recent years as regards products made from palm oil due to both health and
environmental concerns. For example, among our key markets, Spain and the Netherlands in particular, have seen a
greater negative press coverage and perception as regards use of palm oil based products. In response thereto, we created
a patented palm oil-free technology and we have shifted our focus on offering alternatives to palm oil in some of our
markets. Although we source certified (segregated and mass balance) palm oil and offer palm oil-free options in several
markets, there is a risk that additional press coverage and the resulting negative consumer perception of products made
from palm oil further escalates. Although we recognize the controversy around palm oil as an ingredient and continue to
innovate and create new recipes both with sustainable palm oil and alternatives to palm oil through our patented palm oilfree technology, some of our products contain palm oil and switching to exclusively palm oil-free products may not be
currently technically feasible.

Following the COVID-19 pandemic, Russia’s invasion of Ukraine in February 2022 and the conflict in the
Middle East, the global markets and economy have experienced significant uncertainty. There has been a sharp rise in
energy and food costs, resulting in inflationary macroeconomic conditions across most major economies and markets
where we operate. Given these economic conditions, there has been a significant decline in disposable incomes of many
households, creating a cost of living crisis, that has altered the purchasing habits of consumers. In these circumstances,
consumers may choose to economize by purchasing non-branded or private–label brands, which may be cheaper than
our products. A reduction in consumer disposable income could foster a move by our customers towards discounters
and non-branded products, which would impact our market share and adversely affect our net sales. For example, during
the year ended December 31, 2023, there has been a slowdown in the growth of our Plant Cheeses driven by the cost-ofliving crisis, higher prices and increased competition in certain key markets, especially in the United Kingdom. The plant
cheese segment is a strategic segment for us and we intend to launch a variety of new plant cheese products and continue
to further improve the nutritional value and taste of our Plant Cheeses. However, any decrease in demand could have a
material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

26


-----

Our success will be impacted by our ability to anticipate and identify consumer trends and preferences, and to
offer a portfolio of relevant products that appeal to consumer needs and preferences on a timely and affordable basis.
In doing so, we may also be required to leverage our research and development capabilities, and to utilize management’s
ability to launch new or improved products quickly, successfully and on a cost-effective basis. A decrease in demand for
our products due to a shift in consumer tastes or preferences to which we are unable to respond in a timely and costeffective manner may have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

**_Economic and political instability and/or unfavorable economic and political conditions may have a material adverse_**
**_effect on our results of operations._**

Our business may be negatively affected by a number of factors that are beyond our control, such as general
macroeconomic conditions, volatility in the global capital and credit markets, geopolitical events, a public health crisis
and other general political and economic developments globally and in the markets in which we operate. The years ended
December 31, 2021, 2022 and 2023 were characterized by macroeconomic, geopolitical and supply chain issues on a
global scale, due in part to political turmoil or upheaval in a number of regions and the COVID-19 pandemic. Despite an
improvement in global economic conditions in 2021 and 2022 following the sharp global economic downturn in 2020
resulting from the first waves of the COVID-19 pandemic, the outlook for the global economy remains highly uncertain,
and certain of our key markets, including Europe and the United States, may not achieve the growth rates that they have
forecasted or historically observed.

Such uncertainty has been exacerbated by the global turmoil resulting from the ongoing war in Ukraine, which
resulted in severe sanctions being imposed on Russia (including certain Russian entities and individuals). Examples of
such sanctions include a prohibition on doing business with certain Russian companies, large financial institutions,
officials and oligarchs and a commitment by certain countries and the European Union to remove selected Russian banks
from SWIFT, the electronic banking network that connects banks globally. The ongoing war in Ukraine has been a driver
behind severe market disruptions, including significant volatility in commodity prices, volatility in credit and capital
markets, a significant surge in energy and transportation prices, as well as supply chain interruptions, which all have been,
and may continue to be, key factors in driving inflationary pressure and which may ultimately adversely affect general
economic conditions. Commodities and energy are the two key elements in our input cost base. Therefore, any fluctuation
and volatility can have an material adverse impact on our gross profit margin. We shut down our operations in Russia in
the first quarter of 2022 before Russia’s invasion of Ukraine due to strategic reasons. In 2022, we experienced minor
supply chain disruptions for sunflower oil due to the war in Ukraine. In addition, tensions between China and Taiwan and
the conflict in the Middle East have further enhanced the unstable geopolitical environment globally, and particularly in
AMEA. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, none of our suppliers are based in Russia or Ukraine. However,
further intensification of those geopolitical conflicts or its spread to other parts of the world, including certain parts of
Europe, the Americas or other parts of AMEA, could cause supply chain and logistic disruptions and financial market
volatility globally. Moreover, market uncertainty and volatility have also been magnified, and may continue to be
impacted by, the upcoming 2024 United States presidential and congressional elections, resulting in uncertainties
regarding actual and potential shifts in the United States and foreign trade and economic policies.

In addition, general elections in numerous EU countries could lead to the exit of one or more other countries
from the eurozone or other potential developments, which could be an additional source of instability in international
markets. Further, some EU Member States within the eurozone could decide to discontinue their use of the euro as their
functional currency. The exit of another country from the EU, or prolonged periods of uncertainty relating to this could
result in significant macroeconomic deterioration, including, but not limited to, decreases in global stock exchange
indices, increased foreign exchange volatility (in particular a further weakening of the pound sterling and euro against
other leading currencies), and decreased GDP in the European Union. Any of these events or market perceptions
concerning these and related issues, could undermine confidence in the overall stability of the EU, have adverse
consequences for us with respect to our overall performance in the European Union.

For example, after the withdrawal of the United Kingdom from the EU on January 31, 2020, the EU treaties
ceased to apply to the United Kingdom. Following the end of the transition period on December 31, 2020, there were
changes in the legal rights and obligations among commercial parties in the United Kingdom and the EU, including
(among others) financial institutions, suppliers and service providers and their respective customers. In addition, there
were changes in import, tax and employment laws and regulations after the end of the transition period, resulting in an
increase in the cost of importing goods from EU countries and adversely affecting our and our contractors’ and supplier’s
ability in the United Kingdom to retain and recruit employees from the wider European labor market, leading to labor
shortages and higher costs. Additionally, the rate of exchange of the pound sterling vis-à-vis other currencies has been
very volatile since the Brexit referendum.
