Any of the foregoing events, individually or in the aggregate, could have a material adverse effect on our
business, financial condition and results of operations.

**_An inability to pass on price increases for raw materials or other inputs to our customers may have a material adverse_**
**_effect on our results of operations._**

Our ability to pass through increases in the prices of raw materials and other inputs, such as packaging
materials and energy costs, to our customers depends, among others, on prevailing competitive conditions and pricing
methods in the markets in which we operate, and we may not be able to pass through such price increases to our customers.
For example, we took significant pricing actions in 2021 and 2022 to pass price increases to our customers. However, we
may not always be successful in passing price increases to our customers or the actions we take may not be sufficient.
Moreover, following price increases implemented by us in 2021 and 2022, we may face pressure from our customers to
reduce pricing from current levels. Such demands could potentially strain our profit margins and necessitate strategic
adjustments in pricing strategies to maintain our competitive position in the market. Even if we are able to pass through
price increases, there is typically a time lag between cost increases affecting our business and the implementation of
product price increases, which are ultimately within the discretion of the retailer, during which time our gross profit
margin may be reduced. A time lag in the recovery of cost inflation, driven by either cost increases in raw materials or
changes in the foreign exchange rate of the currency the raw material is denominated in, can also negatively impact
our margins. In addition, during negotiations to increase prices to recover cost increases in raw materials, retailers may
take actions, which exacerbate the impact of such cost increases. Our inability to pass through price increases in raw
materials and other inputs and preserve our profit margins in the future could adversely affect our business, financial
condition and results of operations.

**_We operate in a highly competitive market and our failure to compete may have a material adverse effect on our results_**
**_of operations._**

The categories and markets that we operate in are highly competitive globally, particularly in Europe and the
United States, which account for the majority of our net sales. Our competitors include well-established branded
producers that operate on both a national and an international basis across single or multiple dairy and non-dairy
categories as well as retailers who promote private label products within these categories. Our competitors generally
compete with us on the basis of price and promotional strategy, actual or perceived quality, health benefits and
“naturalness” of products, brand recognition, consumer loyalty, product variety, new product development and
improvements to existing products. In addition, we may face increased competition from new entrants in the markets
in which we operate.

We cannot predict the pricing or promotional actions of our competitors or their effect on consumer perceptions
or the success and timing of our own advertising and promotional efforts. For example, during 2023, we saw strong
competition in the Netherlands, Germany and Poland which was largely pricing and promotionally driven and
contributed to a negative volume/mix contribution for the year ended December 31, 2023. Our competitors have
developed and launched products targeted to compete directly with our products. Our retail customers generally control
the shelf space allocations within their stores and may allocate more shelf space to generic or private label products or
to our branded competitors’ products in accordance with their respective promotional strategies. Decreases in shelf
space allocated to our products, increases in competitor promotional activity, aggressive marketing strategies by
competitors or other factors may require us to reduce our prices or invest greater amounts in advertising and promotion
of our products to ensure our products remain competitive. In addition, given recent economic uncertainty and conditions,
there has been a significant decline in disposable incomes of many households, creating a cost of living crisis, that has
altered the purchasing habits of consumers, and may adversely impact the price competitiveness of our products. See
also “—Changes in food trends and consumer preferences may have a material adverse effect on our results of
_operations.”_

Furthermore, some of our competitors may have substantially greater financial, marketing and other resources
than those of ours in certain markets. This creates competitive pressures that could cause us to lose market share or require
us to lower prices, increase advertising expenditures or increase the use of discounting or promotional campaigns. These
competitive factors may also restrict our ability to increase prices, including in response to commodity and other cost
increases. Any inability to continue to respond effectively to these and other competitive pressures could negatively
impact our net sales and gross profit margins, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial
condition and results of operations.

We believe that we have a major business opportunity by highlighting the lower climate impact of our products
(vs their dairy equivalents) as the global dairy and meat sectors face pressure on this point and will need to reduce carbon
emissions to meet future legal climate targets in multiple geographies. For example, in 2023, we launched our “Skip the

28


-----

Cow” campaign to inspire the shift to plant-based alternatives and promote the benefits of Flora Plant in the United
Kingdom, which directly competes with dairy butter and which has approximately 75% less climate impact than dairy
butter. However, there is a risk we will be unable to fully leverage this opportunity because of the lobbying we face from
the dairy and meat industries in certain markets. For example, the EU and the United Kingdom adopted restrictive labeling
rules and banned plant-based products including terms like “milk,” “not milk,” “alternative milk” on their packages.
While we have clear processes in place to refute certain pro dairy and meat proposals, we cannot guarantee that we will
be successful in doing so. In addition, in some markets we are subject to increased government scrutiny regarding
allegedly misleading packaging as well as complaints made by the dairy industry at advertising self-regulating entities.
Although we have been successful in refuting certain of these claims, we cannot guarantee that we will continue to be
successful in doing so. Moreover, historically the dairy industry has successfully convinced many consumers that butter
products are more “natural” and hence healthier than plant-based dairy alternatives. This perception of naturalness
combined with certain customers’ taste preferences could enable dairy manufacturers to increase their market share
relative to ours and other manufacturers of butters and spreads.

Any of the foregoing events, individually or in the aggregate, could have a material adverse effect on our
business, financial condition and results of operations.

**_If we do not manage our supply chain adequately and effectively, our operating results may be adversely affected._**

The inability of our manufacturing facilities, as well as any supplier of raw materials, third-party manufacturer,
distributor or warehouse, to deliver or perform in an adequate and timely or cost-effective manner could cause our
operating costs to increase and our gross profit margins to decrease.

As we own a total of 14 manufacturing facilities across our operating regions, we are subject to the risks
associated with operating and maintaining our manufacturing facilities, as well as relying on third-party manufacturing
facilities. Our manufacturing facilities produced approximately 91% of our total production volume for the year ended
December 31, 2023, with the remaining sourced from third-party manufacturers. We are therefore subject to the risks
associated with operating, and must incur potentially significant capital and other expenditures necessary to maintain, our
manufacturing facilities, machinery and equipment. We must maintain our manufacturing facilities in order to, among
other things, keep up with demand for our products, retain sufficient capacity to manufacture new products and increase
our margins. If we are unable to maintain sufficient manufacturing capacity to keep up with demand for our products
and ensure that our sales and production teams adequately coordinate their planning and production efforts, we risk losing
potential product sales.

We have relationships with multiple third-party manufacturing facilities, which produced approximately 10% of
our total production volume in 2023. We currently rely on and may continue to rely on third-party manufacturers to
produce our products in certain smaller volume or more emerging markets, which we would not be able to service
otherwise. For example, GrainCorp Foods Australia Pty Limited (“GrainCorp”) is the only manufacturer of our products
that are sold within Australia and New Zealand. If GrainCorp had a material issue or delay in their manufacturing process
or if our contract was terminated without finding a substitute manufacturer, our business may be adversely affected. Our
third-party manufacturers are required by us to maintain the quality of our products and to comply with our product
specifications and requirements for certain certifications. However, we have less control over third-party manufacturing
facilities when compared to directly owned facilities. As a result, the failure of any third-party manufacturer to produce
products that conform to our standards could materially and adversely affect our reputation and result in product recalls,
product liability claims and economic loss. We also face risks of competitive access to our intellectual property when
third-party manufacturers require access to our formulas and trade secrets as a condition to doing business with us.

Any loss of the use of all or a portion of our own or contracted third-party facilities due to accidents, fires,
explosions, labor issues, supply interruptions, transportation interruptions, human error, mechanical failure, terrorist
acts, power outages, discharges or releases of hazardous substances and other environmental issues, or otherwise,
whether short- or long-term, could have a material adverse effect on our operations. Increased frequency or duration of
extreme weather conditions, natural disasters such as floods, tornadoes, hurricanes, ice storms and earthquakes could also
damage our facilities, impair production capabilities, and disrupt our supply chain for commodities or packaging
materials, significantly impact the availability of our raw materials and the costs thereof, or impact demand for our
products. Our sole manufacturing plant in Kansas, United States, produces the substantial majority of all our products
sold in the United States and the vast majority of our global volumes of cream are produced at the Kleve manufacturing
facility in Germany. Our manufacturing facilities in Corlu, Turkey and Drama, Greece produce a substantial part of our
Plant Butter and Spreads and Plant Cheeses, respectively; they are, however, located in a seismic zone and therefore
subject to a significantly higher risk of negative impacts resulting from earthquakes in particular. Any loss of the use
of all or a portion of any of such key facilities could result in substantial business losses, production delays, third
29


-----

party lawsuits and significant repair costs, as well as personal injury and/or loss of life, which could materially and
adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Moreover, while we have insurance coverage in place, unexpected failures of our equipment and machinery
could result in production delays, turnover loss and significant repair costs, as well as injuries to our employees. In some
cases, manufacturing facilities are designated for certain types of products based on the unique equipment involved and
it is more difficult, or impossible, for us to shift production of these products among our facilities. Any interruption in
production capability may require us to make large capital expenditures to remedy the situation and could require
significant lead time replacing, which could have a negative impact on our gross profit margin and cash flows. A loss
or interruption in production at certain of our facilities could disrupt our operations and affect a large number of
customers, decreasing our net sales. The operation of manufacturing facilities also requires us to hire, train and evaluate
large numbers of production employees, which involves additional labor and employment related risks and uncertainties.

We and our third-party manufacturers are also subject to losses associated with equipment shutdowns, which
may be caused by the loss or interruption of electrical power to manufacturing facilities due to unusually high demand,
blackouts, adverse weather, equipment failure or other catastrophic events. Losses caused by disruptions in the supply of
electrical power could materially and adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations.

In addition, we are dependent on third-party suppliers of raw materials and packaging for our products. Our
suppliers may fail to meet timelines or contractual obligations or provide sufficient products, which may adversely affect
our business. Failure to appropriately structure or adequately manage our agreements with third parties may adversely
affect our availability of supply, which in turn affects our ability to manufacture our products.

We are also dependent on third parties for most of our warehousing and substantially all of our transportation
requirements. Certain factors affecting distribution costs, including oil prices, are either subject to market fluctuations or
controlled by our third-party carriers. For example, fuel prices have been high in recent years and have fluctuated as a
result of various factors, many of which are beyond our control, such as global and regional supply and demand.
Moreover, geopolitical and economic uncertainties due to the ongoing conflict between Russia and Ukraine and the
conflict in the Middle East, which have threatened supply lines and resulted in embargoes of certain supply sources, as
well as pricing and availability of fuel supplies.

Moreover, temporary or long-term disruption of transportation services due to weather-related problems, strikes,
lockouts or other events could impair our ability to supply products affordably or in a timely manner. If we are unable to
timely receive raw materials or produce and effectively distribute sufficient quantities in response to demand for our
products, consumers may look to purchase alternative or competitive products. Moreover, if we are unable to manage
our supply chain efficiently, our operating costs could increase, adversely affecting our business, financial condition and
results of operations.

Additionally, in some markets we rely on a small number of distributors to satisfy demand from numerous, small,
traditional trade outlets. Also in Brazil and Peru we serve the market with only one major distributor for each of those
countries. The failure of any of these distributors could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition
and results of operations in such market. This could, in turn, also have a material adverse effect on the Group’s business,
financial condition and results of operations.

**_An inability to invest in the image of our brands to prevent erosion of the reputation or appeal of one or more of_**
**_our leading brands may have a material adverse effect on our results of operations._**

We are a global organization, with different strategies in place with respect to marketing, pricing and pack size
across different markets. Strategic decisions taken for any particular market that turn out to be unsuccessful can create a
public backlash and have an unfavorable impact across the Group. A significant majority of our net sales derives from
sales of our power brands, and the success of our business has resulted from the strength of our brands. Our financial
success is directly dependent on consumer and customer perception of such key brands, including as an example, Flora,
Country Crock, Becel+ProActiv, Rama, BlueBand and Violife. The success of our brands may suffer if our marketing
plans, marketing spend levels or product initiatives do not have the desired impact on a brand’s image or our ability to
attract consumers or if consumer or customer perceptions of our brands or products change unfavorably. In particular,
our investments in marketing activities for any new brands and projects may divert resources from our existing brands
and products, and there can be no assurance that such investments will be successful or that consumer or customer
perceptions of our existing brands will not suffer as a result. In addition, our results of operations could be negatively
affected if the reputation of one or more of our brands suffers damage due to real or perceived quality issues with our
products, unsuccessful marketing campaigns or if we have found to have materially violated any applicable laws or
regulations. We have limited control over third-party manufacturers, distributors and other commercial partners. Any

30


-----

failure of such third parties to comply with applicable laws and regulations could materially and adversely affect our
reputation and result in product recalls, product liability claims and economic loss.

In addition, unsuccessful interactions with governments and NGOs of the countries we are operating in may
also affect the perception of the Group by our investors, cause reputational damage and adversely affect our results of
operations. Any circumstances which publicly damage our customer goodwill, injures our reputation or damages our
business relationships may lead to a broader adverse effect on our business and prospects by way of loss of business,
goodwill, customers and employees beyond the monetary liability arising directly from the damaging events.

**_Fluctuations in energy and freight costs may have a material adverse effect on our results of operations._**

In addition to our dependence on primary raw materials, due to the energy intensive nature of our manufacturing
process and the critical importance of transportation to our manufacturing, supply and logistics processes, we rely on a
number of different energy sources, including oil, electricity and natural gas. If, for any reason, certain of our energy
supply contracts were terminated in a country where we have major operations, or were not renewed upon expiration, or
if market conditions were to substantially change resulting in a significant decrease in energy supply in the European
Union or a significant increase in the price of oil, electricity or natural gas, including as a result of the heightened energy
prices following the war in Ukraine, we may not be able to find alternative, comparable suppliers or suppliers capable of
providing oil, electricity or natural gas on pricing, terms or volume satisfactory to us, or we may be forced to change our
manufacturing practices, thereby increasing our operational costs and potential carbon footprint. As a result of any of
these events, our business, financial condition and results of operations may be negatively affected.

We also heavily rely on third parties for the transportation of our raw materials, as well as for the products we
manufacture and sell. In certain jurisdictions, we are exposed to import duties and freight costs. Freight costs are
influenced by carrier availability and fluctuating oil prices, which, in turn, have been impacted by the ongoing inflationary
surge and related supply chain disruptions. Major global events such as fluctuating commodity prices, geopolitical
conflicts, new regulations like the new EU mobility package (which aims to promote road safety and better working
conditions for drivers through the adoption of certain limitations like drivers’ driving times and rest period) may increase
the cost base of our carriers or cause interruptions in our transportation operations. For instance, the recent military conflict
between Israel and Hamas and its spillover effects throughout the Middle East, including the Red Sea, has led to delays
and increased freight rates due to the rerouting of ships around South Africa. Such events could adversely affect our
business, financial condition and results of operations. We believe that our strong brands and presence in the markets we
operate in provides us the ability to pass on such input prices to our customers, however, such ability is limited and we
may not be able to agree price adjustments to effectively cover our energy costs with our customers, or may only be able
to pass them through on a delayed basis. Moreover, an increase in the selling prices for our products resulting from an
attempt to pass through increased energy or freight costs may decrease the price competitiveness of our products, which
may negatively impact the volume of our sales, and in turn adversely affect our business, financial condition and results
of operations. While we have hedging arrangments in place and manage risks related to transportation through our
monitoring systems and a tailored procurement process with respect to our third-party logistics providers, our current
policies and precautionary actions cannot fully eliminate any of the above risks.

**_Our future results and competitive position are dependent on the successful development of new products and_**
**_improvement of existing products, as well as the implementation of other growth and business development initiatives,_**
**_which are subject to a number of difficulties and uncertainties._**

Our future results and ability to maintain or improve our competitive position depend on our ability to identify,
develop, manufacture, market and sell new or improved products successfully. A key element of our growth strategy is
to introduce new products and continue to upgrade, re-launch and extend existing product lines in each of the markets
in which we operate to increase overall sales of our products. We will also seek to expand our distribution channels.
There can be no assurance that any new product line or channel which we might expand into will develop into a viable
offering, or that any investment made in expanding into such adjacent product categories or distribution channels will be
adequately rewarded.

By 2050, our global food system is expected to need to feed nearly 10 billion people worldwide. We believe that
this requires a shift to predominantly plant-based diets with lower consumption of animal derived foods. To meet this
challenge, we aim to be 100% plant-based by 2030, which requires continued active innovation and reformulation of our
products. However, the launch and success of new or modified products are inherently uncertain, and there can be no
assurance as to our continuing ability to develop and launch successful new products or variations of existing products.
The success of our product development is affected by our ability to anticipate changing consumer trends and preferences,
to leverage our research and development capabilities, and to utilize management’s ability to launch new or improved
products quickly, successfully and on a cost-effective basis. If we are unsuccessful in developing new products in an

31


-----

efficient and economical manner and we do not achieve the desired results from our strategic partnerships, demand for
our products may decrease, which may have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of
operations.

Moreover, our business can be affected by risks related to expansion into new international markets, particularly
emerging markets. We are also exposed to reputational risks connected to a potential failure to manage and properly
implement these growth initiatives. New international markets could develop more slowly than we expect at any given
time. Entry into a new market may require a local manufacturing or distribution partner, which may be difficult to obtain
or slow down the speed of expansion. Should further expansion into international markets not be successful or not be as
successful as planned, the investments made might not result in the desired growth in revenue, which could have a material
adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Growth can carry risks relating to the adequacy of our resources and the capacity of management and employees
to properly manage all critical issues, resulting in a focus on certain initiatives to the detriment of others and a failure
to properly anticipate risks to our global supply chain. Growth risks also include risks related to potential mergers and
acquisitions, including potential liability under acquisition agreements, product liability and environmental responsibility
risks as well as reputational and personnel related risks. The success of any merger or acquisition is also dependent on
our management’s ability to successfully integrate such companies into existing operations. Any failure to manage risks
related to potential mergers and acquisitions could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or
results of operations.

**_Our international operations are subject to various risks that may have a material adverse effect on our results of_**
**_operations._**

Globally we currently own 14 manufacturing facilities, 38 offices and one research and development center and
our brands are sold and distributed in more than (either directly or indirectly via distributors) 100 countries across five
continents.

As part of our strategy, we will continue to seek to expand our sales and market share in various international
markets, including by acquiring new companies to enable us to expand our product offering. The economies of some of
the countries in which we operate in Eastern Europe, Asia, LatAm and Africa differ from the economies of Western
Europe, the United States and Canada and in some cases present a greater risk profile. Many of these countries have
implemented measures aimed at improving the business environment and providing a stable platform for economic
development. However, the political, economic and legal reforms necessary to complete such a transformation may not
be implemented fully or may not be successful, and the governments of these countries may implement policies, measures,
controls or other actions which could restrict our business operations, acceptance of our products or harm our financial
results. The risks inherent in the countries where we operate include, but are not limited to:

    - political, social and economic instability;

    - fluctuations in currency exchange rates and currency devaluations;

    - government policies and regulations, including more stringent regulation on labelling, packaging, including
the use of plastic, deforestation, payment terms or in respect of labor laws;

    - more stringent reporting requirements, including, but not limited to, supply chain due diligence reporting
requirements and ESG reporting requirements;

    - tariffs, duties, export controls and other trade barriers;

    - varying tax regimes that could harm our results of operations, including withholding and other taxes on
remittances and other payments by our subsidiaries;

    - longer account receivable payment cycles and difficulty in collecting accounts receivable;

    - foreign exchange controls or restrictions on profit repatriation;

    - nationalization or expropriation of property without fair compensation;

    - recessionary trends, inflation and instability of the financial markets;

    - the introduction or application of more stringent restrictions on investments;

32


-----

    - the possibility of natural disaster (including the earthquake in Turkey in 2022), war (including the ongoing
war in Ukraine and conflict in the Middle East), civil disturbance, acts of terrorism or other social conflicts;

    - any epidemics or pandemics, ineffective and varying responses from local governments and competent
authorities;

    - unfair competition, in certain markets in which we compete;

    - changes in the interest rate environment; and

    - fluctuations in local economic growth.

We are exposed to these risks in all of our operations to some degree, and such exposure may reduce demand
for our products and as a result negatively impact our financial condition and results of operations, especially in emerging
markets where the political and legal environment is less stable. Although we have monitoring practices and policies in
place to tackle risks that arise during the course of our business, the systems, policies and practices we implement may
not be sufficient to fully anticipate these risks before they arise or we may not be able to effectively manage these risks.
As a result, we may be subject to material adverse developments with respect to our international operations or incur
additional costs while managing these risks and ensuring compliance with all applicable laws and regulations. If we are
unable to expand our businesses across both developing and emerging markets, effectively operate, or manage the risks
associated with operating, in these markets, or achieve the return on capital we expect from our investments in these
markets, our business, financial condition or results of operations could be adversely affected.

**_Potential future impairments of intangible assets may have a material adverse effect on our results of operations._**

Goodwill is a significant asset of the Group. As of March 31, 2024, the book value of our goodwill amounted to
€3,827 million, while our other intangible assets amounted to €3,307 million. In accordance with IFRS, we evaluate
goodwill and indefinite life intangible assets for impairment annually, or earlier in the case of a triggering event. Goodwill
impairment is indicated and indefinite life intangible assets are impaired when their carrying amount exceeds their
estimated recoverable amount, which is the greater of their value in use and their fair value less cost to sell. A decrease
in expected cash flows, changes in market conditions, loss of key customers or a change in our imputed cost of capital
may require potential impairment of recorded goodwill and/or other intangible assets. Weakness in the global economy,
including due to the ongoing conflicts in Ukraine and the Middle East and the recent inflationary surge, also may cause
us to make impairment charges. The amount of any impairment must be expensed immediately as a charge to the income
statement. Although the Group has not recorded any charges for goodwill impairment during its most recent year, there
can be no assurance that goodwill impairment charges will not be incurred in the future. Any future impairment could
have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

**_We are exposed to foreign exchange rate risks and such may have a material adverse effect on our results of_**
**_operations._**

We operate internationally and, as a result, we have considerable cash flow, revenue, costs, assets and liabilities
in foreign currencies and are exposed to changes in various currency exchange rates. We have exchange rate exposure
in our key markets particularly in relation to fluctuations of the U.S. dollar, the pound sterling, the Polish zloty, the
Canadian dollar, the Mexican peso, the Indonesian rupiah and the Turkish lira against the euro. Our exposure to changes
in exchange rates can mainly be described in terms of translation exposure and transaction exposure.

To prepare our consolidated financial statements, we must translate our assets, liabilities, net sales and costs
into euro. Consequently, increases and decreases in the value of the euro against these other currencies will affect the
amounts attributed to these items in our consolidated financial statements, even if their value has not changed in their
original currency. These translations could result in changes to our results of operations from period to period. For
example, the significant Turkish lira depreciation was a main contributor in the decline of net sales in AMEA, as reported
in euro, for the year ended December 31, 2023. In addition, the euro to pound sterling and the euro to U.S. dollar
exchange rates have been volatile during recent years due to various factors including the war in Ukraine, the conflict
in the Middle East, Brexit and the COVID-19 pandemic. Unfavorable fluctuations in foreign currency exchange rates
could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operation.

In addition, our exchange rate transaction risks principally relate to purchases of raw materials including Plant
Oils, which have underlying global commodity price indexes denominated in U.S. dollar or may have a degree of
correlation with the U.S. dollar (despite underlying indexes being priced in euro or other currencies). As a result hereof,
we are exposed to a transaction risk since such U.S. dollar denominated raw materials are mainly invoiced to us in euro.

33


-----

Other ingredient and packaging costs (apart from certain commodity inputs) are generally denominated in the functional
currencies of the jurisdictions in which our operations (including manufacturing plants and distribution hubs) are located,
which in most cases correlate to the markets and currencies in which sales are made. Therefore, to the extent we incur
costs that are not denominated in the same currency as the related net sales, exchange rate fluctuations could cause our
costs to increase as a percentage of net sales, affecting our gross profit margin.

Any of these developments could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results
of operations.

**_We are exposed to the risk of violations of anti-corruption laws, sanctions or other similar regulations applicable in_**
**_the countries in which we operate or in which we may operate in the future._**

We sell and distribute our brands in more than 100 countries across five continents and we, our business partners,
our agents, employees must comply with applicable local laws, as well as certain anti-corruption laws, sanctions or other
similar regulations. For example, the U.S. Foreign Corrupt Practices Act of 1977, the U.K. Bribery Act 2010, the European
Anti-Bribery Conventions and other similar worldwide anti-corruption laws generally prohibit companies and their
intermediaries from making improper payments to foreign officials for the purposes of obtaining or retaining business.
We are also subject to a number of modern slavery, human trafficking and forced labor reporting, training and due
diligence laws, such as the UK’s Modern Slavery Act 2015 and similar legislation in various jurisdictions and additional
statutory regimes to fight these crimes may be enacted in the future.

Due to the global scale of our business, some of our operations may be conducted in jurisdictions that lack a
developed legal system or have experienced widespread corruption. Under certain circumstances, strict compliance with
anti-corruption laws may conflict with local customs and practices. While we have a robust compliance framework in
place that is spread across our key regions to identify and mitigate the risks of breach of local laws, fraud, bribery,
corruption and any incidents involving ethics and integrity, and conduct regular trainings with different parts of the
business on regional laws and regulations, we cannot guarantee that we can detect or prevent every instance of fraud,
bribery, corruption or breaches of ethics or integrity involving our employees, business partners or agents.

Furthermore, operating under multiple jurisdictions adds complexity in relation to tracking, understanding and
abiding to laws and regulations. We have domestic distribution channels (i.e., our retailers and distributors) in our markets
and our products meet our end-consumers through these intermediaries. There is a risk that such distribution channels
may take misaligned decisions that would violate local laws or may be involved in illegitimate activities in local markets
that are unknown to us. If we fail to adequately monitor them or maintain an adequate compliance program, we may be
liable for their actions.

Violations of anti-corruption laws can result in civil penalties, fines, denial of export privileges, injunctions,
asset seizures, debarment from government contracts, termination of existing contracts, revocations or restrictions of
licenses, criminal fines or imprisonment. In addition, such violations could also negatively impact our reputation and
consequently, our ability to enter into new contracts or renew our existing contracts. On the other hand, any such violation
by our competitors, if undetected, could give them an unfair advantage when bidding for contracts. The consequences
that we may suffer due to the foregoing could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and
results of operations.

**_Climate change and extreme weather conditions may have a material adverse effect on our results of operations._**

The impact of climate change may materially and adversely impact the cost, production and financial
performance of our business. There is an increasing concern that a gradual increase in global average temperatures due
to increased concentration of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases in the atmosphere have caused and will continue
to cause significant changes in weather patterns around the globe and an increase in the frequency and severity of extreme
weather events. Any impacts on our business and financial condition as a result of climate change are likely to occur over
a sustained period of time and are therefore difficult to quantify with any degree of specificity. We have partnered with
climate experts to conduct a climate scenario analysis aligned with the recommendations of the Task Force on Climaterelated Financial Disclosures (“TCFD”). Our analysis has shown that with a potential temperature increase of 3 degrees
Celsius, there will be a risk of more frequent severe weather events such as floods and heatwaves.

Severe weather events may result in adverse physical impacts on our sites, natural resources on which we use in
our production process, such as water, or portions of our infrastructure, which could disrupt our supply chain and
ultimately our business operations. Major weather phenomena like El Niño and La Niña may have a dramatic effect on
agricultural activities and crops. The El Niño weather phenomenon has now returned and is expected to last at least
through the first half of 2024, resulting in further temperature increases both on land and at sea. This may result in seasonal

34


-----

drought and harm agriculture in certain regions. For the year ended December 31, 2023, we sourced the majority of our
palm oil (which counts for approximately 36% of our total Plant Oils volume) from Indonesia and Malaysia, so the
growing climate concerns in these countries carry heightened importance. Decreased agricultural productivity in certain
regions as a result of changing weather patterns may affect the quality, limit the availability or increase the cost of key
raw materials and cause delays or disruptions in our production and logistics. Although we have developed procedures to
respond to the effects of such events, including our ability to flex and change our recipes and pivot to alternative
ingredients, where appropriate, and our overall analysis aligned with the recommendations of the TCFD indicated a low
financial risk on gross revenue, our efforts may not be sufficient. As a result, the effects of climate change could have a
material adverse impact on our business and results of operations.

**_We rely substantially on sales to large food retailers and in the event they give higher priority to private label_**
**_or other branded products, or if the concentration and buying power of these large retailers increase, our business_**
**_could be adversely affected._**

Our customers include supermarkets and large chain food retailers across Europe and the Americas and
merchants in AMEA. Throughout our markets, and particularly in Europe and the United States (where we derived the
majority of our net sales for the year ended December 31, 2023), the food retail segments are highly concentrated. In
recent years, the major retailers in many of our key markets have increased their share of the grocery market through
consolidation, pricing initiatives (such as discounts and promotions) or other measures. Many retailers have also formed
or joined buying groups and buying alliances, including a number of European based groups such as Epic Partners,
Everest, Eurelec and Eureka amongst others, and price competition between retailers has intensified. This price
competition has led retailers, buying groups and alliances to seek lower prices from their suppliers, including us, and in
some cases to protracted negotiations. The strength of the major retailers’ bargaining position gives them significant
leverage over their suppliers in negotiating pricing, product specification and the level of supplier participation in
promotional campaigns and offers, which can reduce our gross profit margins. Further consolidation among the major
retailers or disproportionate customer growth in relation to their competitors could increase their relative negotiating
power and allow them to force a negative shift in our trade terms. Our results of operations could also be adversely
affected if we are required to reduce our prices or increase our promotional spending activity as a consequence of an
increase in the strength of the major retailers’ bargaining position, if we lose business from a major retail customer or if
our relationship with a major customer deteriorates.

Food retailers, including mainstream grocery chains which carry our products as well as discount chains (such
as Aldi and Lidl) which tend not to carry major brands, also offer generic or private label products that compete directly
with our products for retail shelf space and consumer purchases. There is a risk that our customers may give higher
priority to private label products or the branded products of our competitors, which would adversely affect sales of our
products. In addition, given the growth in market share of discount grocery chains, there is a risk that consumers could
increasingly shop at discount chains offering only private label products, which would adversely affect sales of our
products and put increasing pressure on our mainstream grocery chain customers. In these circumstances, consumers
may choose to economize by purchasing non-branded or private label brands. In the event our tenders to supply private
label products to certain retailers, we may win back some volume but at the expense of lower net sales and gross profit
margins. We may be unable to adequately respond to these trends and, as a result, the volume of our sales may decrease
or we may need to lower the prices of our products, either of which could adversely affect our business, financial condition
and results of operations.

**_We depend on information technology (“IT”) systems to operate our business. Any failure, data security breach or_**
**_technological changes may have a material adverse effect on our results of operations._**

Our business activities rely to a significant degree on the efficient and uninterrupted operation of our various
computer and communication systems, including IT platforms such as our fully digital, cloud-based Enterprise Resource
Planning (ERP) system SAP4Hana. Any failure of our IT systems or any ineffective digital transformations (including
upgrades and/or migrations to new suppliers, new systems or applications) or system designs could impair our ability to
receive, process and reconcile transactions, manage supply chain and manufacturing functions, manage compliance and
risk functions, and conduct other day-to-day operations of the business. Such digital transformations also rely on effective
master data management and business change management, in combination with overall IT systems. In addition, our
computer and communications systems are vulnerable to damage or interruption from a variety of sources, including
attacks by computer malware, electronic break-ins or cyber-attacks, theft or corruption of confidential data or other
unanticipated problems. We have implemented backup and restoration solutions to ensure speedy recovery across our key
IT platforms, improved our disaster recovery plans around critical processes during crisis and entered into improved
service level agreements with third-party suppliers. However, any significant disruption of our computer or
communication systems could affect our ability to manage our IT systems or lead to recovery costs, litigation brought by

35


-----

customers or business partners, reputational damage or a diminished ability to operate the business, which in turn could
have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Additionally, if we enter into acquisition transactions in the future, the process of integrating the information
systems of the businesses we acquire may be complex and exposes us to additional risk as we might not adequately
identify weaknesses in the targets’ information systems. For example, we acquired Arivia in 2020 and successfully
completed Arivia’s IT integration to our IT platform in the year ended December 31, 2023. During the integration process,
we were exposed to risk of disruption of our IT systems. Such disruption could ultimately prevent us from meeting our
strategic objectives and have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

As part of our business, we collect, retain and process certain confidential information, including the personal
data of consumers, customers and employees. As a result, our operations are subject to data protection and privacy laws,
including the EU General Data Protection Regulation (the “EU GDPR”). Further, the General Data Protection Regulation
(EU) 2016/679 as it forms part of domestic law by virtue of the EUWA (the “UK GDPR” and together with the EU
GDPR, “GDPR”) came into effect on January 1, 2021, and, together with the amended UK Data Protection Act 2018,
retains the EU GDPR in UK national law following the United Kingdom’s withdrawal from the EU. The relationship
between the United Kingdom and the EU in relation to certain aspects of data protection law remains uncertain. Therefore,
compliance with the GDPR may require us to modify our data processing practices and policies and incur compliancerelated costs and expenses and these changes may lead to other additional costs and increase our overall risk exposure.
Moreover, the GDPR may lead to significant financial penalties if we breach the requirements thereof. In addition, noncompliance or technical defects resulting in a leak or the misuse of personal data could also result in damage to our
reputation and otherwise harm our business. Moreover, we do not currently have specific data security insurance coverage
and we cannot guarantee that our general liability insurance coverage will be sufficient to cover all or any liabilities in
the event of a breach of our data security systems. Should one or more of these risks materialize, it could have a material
adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

**_We are subject to credit risk with respect to our customers and suppliers._**

Our business is subject to the risks of non-payment and non-performance by our customers. We manage
our exposure to credit risk through credit analysis, monitoring procedures, credit insurance, factoring and sometimes uses
of letters of credit, prepayments and guarantees. However, these procedures and policies cannot fully eliminate customer
credit risk, and to the extent our policies and procedures prove to be inadequate, it could negatively affect our financial
condition and results of operations. In addition, some of our customers, particularly in emerging markets, may be subject
to their own operating and regulatory risks and, even if our credit review and analysis mechanisms work properly, we
may experience financial losses in our dealings with such parties. If our customers fail to fulfil their contractual
obligations, our business, financial condition and results of operation may be materially adversely affected.

Moreover, countries in which we operate may enact new laws that limit payment terms, which may have an
adverse effect on our business. For example, the European Union has proposed a new regulation on late payments on
September 12, 2023 that aims to limit payment terms to small and medium enterprises (“SMEs”) to 30 days to ensure
fairness in commercial transactions. Should the scope of application of such regulation be extended beyond small and
medium enterprises to also include large companies (from whom we source a majority of our Plant Oils and other key
ingredients), such regulation may have an adverse effect on our cash flow and our profitability or may lead to
renegotiations with some of our suppliers.

We are also subject to credit risk with respect to our third-party suppliers. If any such suppliers become insolvent,
an appointed trustee could potentially ignore the service contracts we have in place with such party, resulting in
increased charges or the termination of the service contracts. We may not be able to replace a service provider within a
reasonable period of time, on as favorable terms or without disruption to our operations.

Any of the foregoing factors, individually or in the aggregate, could have a material adverse effect on our
operating cash flow and liquidity (especially since we historically managed our trade payables typically on 90 to 120 day
terms), as well as our business, financial condition and results of operations.

**_Our business depends on our ability to protect our intellectual property effectively and any inability to protect our_**
**_intellectual property could harm the value of our brands and adversely affect our business._**

Our business depends substantially on the legal protection of proprietary rights in intellectual property that we
own or license. We also claim proprietary rights in various patented technologies, know-how, trade secrets (including
formulas), trademarks and service marks relating to our products and manufacturing processes. Our ability to implement
our business plan depends in part on our ability to expand brand recognition using trademarks, service marks and other

36


-----

proprietary intellectual property, including for our brand names and logos, and on our ability to exploit our proprietary
knowledge with respect to manufacturing processes. If existing contractual measures fail to protect our proprietary rights,
or if any third party misappropriates or infringes our intellectual property, any advantage those proprietary rights provide
may be negated and the value of our brands may be harmed, which could have a material adverse effect on our business
and might prevent our brands from achieving or maintaining market acceptance.

Monitoring infringement of intellectual property rights is difficult and we cannot be certain that the precautions
we have taken will prevent the unauthorized use of our intellectual property (including trade secrets and know-how),
particularly in countries where we do not have trademarks or patents at all or where the laws of such country may not be
a member of the Paris Convention for the Protection of Industrial Property, an international treaty that provides a
framework for mutual recognition of patents and trademarks among member countries, and thus we may not have the
desired level of protection of our proprietary rights. As we expand our operations into new markets, we become
increasingly exposed to intellectual property laws, which may prove to be inadequate for protecting our rights.
Accordingly, other parties, including competitors, may duplicate our products using our proprietary technologies.

Pursuing legal remedies against persons infringing our owned or licensed intellectual property rights or otherwise
improperly using our proprietary information is a costly and time-consuming process that could divert resources from the
conduct of our business. When we or our licensor seeks to enforce their respective intellectual property rights, defendants
are permitted to challenge the validity of the relevant intellectual property, which could have the impact of invalidating
or limiting the scope of our owned or licensed intellectual property, which may cause harm to our image, brand or
competitive position. In addition, patent infringement cases can involve hearings in which the court determines the
boundaries of the patent in dispute, which could limit the utility of our or our licensor’s patents.

**_Costs or liabilities relating to compliance with applicable directives, regulations and laws may have a material adverse_**
**_effect on our results of operations._**

As a producer of food products for human consumption, we are subject to extensive regulations in the countries
in which we operate, in particular Europe, the United States and the United Kingdom, which govern production,
composition, manufacturing, storage, transport, advertising, packaging, health, quality, labelling, safety and distribution
standards. There is a risk that any of the countries in which we operate enact unfavorable regulations, which may have an
impact on our business growth, including regulations concerning packaging, raw materials or reformulation requirements.
Moreover, any failure to comply with applicable laws and regulations could subject us to civil remedies, including
fines, injunctions, product recalls or asset seizures, as well as potential criminal sanctions, any of which may have a
material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Our industry also faces increasing public and community pressure to consume energy more efficiently, including
through the use of renewable fuels, and to reduce waste. For example, the European Union’s Deforestation Regulation
(Regulation (EU) 2023/1115) (the “Deforestation Regulation”), came into force on June 29, 2023 and bans import of
certain commodities, including palm oil, soy and paper, if they are produced by contributing to deforestation of lands. We
have sustainable palm oil, soy and paper policies in place and, on the basis thereof, we have taken measures to ensure our
suppliers adhere to our commitment to no deforestation. For the year ended December 31, 2023, 100% of our palm oil
and soybean oil were sustainably sourced and 100% of our paper and pulp supply was sustainably sourced. Even though
we have taken measures to ensure transparency, and have a strong level of due diligence in monitoring our supply chains,
with stricter environmental policies being implemented in the regions in which we operate, we may fail to fully adhere to
these heightened regulatory requirements. Not adhering to the Deforestation Regulation may cause material disruptions
in our supply chain, which may have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of
operations.

In addition, on January 5, 2023, EU Directive No 2464/2022 on Corporate Sustainability Reporting (the
“CSRD”) was adopted and entered into force. The CSRD introduces new mandatory reporting obligations that will require
the publication of sustainability information. Further reporting standards are due to be adopted by June 2026, including
for in-scope non-EU entities. Companies that fall under the scope of the CSRD have to report in their annual reports to
what extent their activities are covered by the Regulation (EU) 2020/852 on the establishment of a framework to facilitate
sustainable investment (the “EU Taxonomy Regulation”) and comply with the criteria set in the EU Taxonomy
Regulation delegated acts. Following the coming into force of CSRD, we expect to cover any additional reporting required
by CSRD and not already covered in our reporting for the period beginning with the year ended December 31, 2025.

Moreover, regulators may impose heightened disclosure requirements concerning our supply chain or ESGrelated matters, such as the proposed EU Corporate Sustainability Due Diligence Directive (CSDDD), or may impose
further restrictions that may affect how we conduct our business, such as the proposed EU regulation on late payments
on September 12, 2023 that aims to limit payment terms to SMEs to 30 days to ensure fairness in commercial transactions.

The execution of our ESG strategy to achieve these goals, commitments, and targets are subject to risks and

Food safety, and the public’s awareness that our products are safe and healthy, are essential to our image
and business. We sell food products for human consumption, which subjects us to safety risks such as product
contamination, spoilage, misbranding or product tampering. Product contamination, including the presence of a foreign

object, substance, and chemical or other agent or residue could require product withdrawals, recalls, or the destruction

We may be harmed by publicity concerning any assertion that our products caused illness or injury, and
could become subject to claims or lawsuits relating to an actual or alleged illness stemming from product contamination

We could also be subject to claims or lawsuits relating to an actual or alleged illness or injury or death stemming
from the consumption of a mislabeled, misbranded, altered, contaminated or spoiled product, which could negatively

public relations implications of any such claims could have an adverse effect on our business, financial condition and

and time consuming, increase our insurance premiums and divert management’s time and resources towards defending
them rather than operating the business. In addition, any adverse publicity concerning such claims, even if unfounded,
could cause customers to lose confidence in the safety and quality of our products and damage our reputation and brand
image.

Evolving nutritional and health-related concerns have led to negative publicity in the food industry concerning
the health implications of genetically modified organisms (“GMOs”), obesity, trans-fat and diacetyl. In particular, the
food industry has been experiencing a significant trend in which an increasing number of consumers are requiring only
non-GMO and other specialized ingredients in their foods. Part of our contribution to the shift towards more plant-based
diets is our 100% plant-based target by 2030, which requires active innovation and reformulation of several of our
products. In order to replicate the texture of animal-derived foods using dairy-free ingredients, we sometimes rely on the
use of enzymes or other proteins produced by GMOs to replace animal proteins, just as genetically modified enzymes are
used in the production of many foods (for example, chymosin is an enzyme used to produce some dairy cheeses, it can
be obtained from animal and from GMO sources). We seek to control any potential risks of using GMOs in our products
by following all regulatory requirements to ensure our products are safe, including the sourcing of GMO and non-GMO
ingredients. Sourcing non-GMO and other specialized ingredients increases costs because such raw materials are
generally less widely available and therefore more expensive and we may not be able to increase our prices to reflect
this increased cost. As additional retailers require or consider requiring all of their products to be non-GMO, additional
pressure may come to bear on manufacturers to find sources of raw materials which are non-GMO and to assure
absence of GMO from their respective supply chains. This may be particularly difficult in the United States, where most
farmers produce genetically modified foods, making it difficult to source and assure non-GMO ingredients and raw
materials. Companies that fail to source and assure non-GMO and other specialized ingredients could, over time, lose
market share, suffer harm to their brand images and face decreasing sales. Consumers may increasingly require that foods
meet stricter standards than are required by applicable governmental agencies, which would further increase the cost of
manufacturing such foods and ingredients. In addition, legislation could also require companies to move to GMO-free
labelling or other higher cost ingredients, which could result in changes to our labelling, advertising and/or packaging.

Any of the foregoing factors, individually or in the aggregate, could have a material adverse effect on our
business, financial condition and results of operations.

**_Significant disruption in our workforce, increasing labor costs or work stoppages by unionized employees may have a_**

We have in the past, and may in the future, experience labor disputes and work stoppages at one or more of our

been involved in negotiations on collective bargaining agreements. A labor stoppage or other interruption at one of our

and have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

**_Seasonal fluctuations in product demand may have a material adverse effect on our results of operations._**

Our sales have historically been affected by seasonal cyclicality in customer orders in various markets. The
extent and impact of such seasonal variations varies among the countries in which we operate. For example, the U.S.
business typically experiences a spike in the fourth quarter of the year which is driven by Thanksgiving and Christmas
baking. Similarly, there can be some seasonality in sales in Europe and the Americas owing to Easter, which can occur
during the first or second quarter of the year. Similarly, in Indonesia there is a peak in butter and spreads usage for cooking
and baking during the Ramadan festival season, which can occur in various quarters from year to year. Furthermore,
across all the countries in which we operate, the timing of product promotions drives volatility from normal consumption.
While our sales are seasonal, many of our costs, such as personnel costs, are incurred more evenly throughout the year,
which could affect measures of profitability in the short term and put pressure on our working capital position. In addition,
for these reasons, sequential quarterly comparisons may not be a reliable indication of the performance of our business
or how we may perform in the future.

**_Potential liabilities and costs from litigation may have a material adverse effect on our results of operations._**

From time to time, in the ordinary course of business, we are subject to various claims, lawsuits and other legal
proceedings brought or threatened against us, including but not limited to, claims brought by third parties. These actions
and proceedings may seek, among other things, compensation for alleged breach of contract or violation of consumer
protection statutes and other regulations, punitive damages and civil penalties or other losses, liquidated damages,
consequential damages, or injunctive or declaratory relief. There is no guarantee that we will be successful in defending
ourselves in civil, criminal or regulatory actions. These actions may relate to commercial, employment, environmental,
food quality, food safety, food labelling, anti-trust, international trade, taxation, intellectual property, advertising and
similar matters. For example, our marketing could face allegations of false or misleading advertising or other criticisms
which could result in litigation and potential liabilities or costs in certain jurisdictions. For example, since 2022 a series
of alleged putative class action lawsuits have been brought or threatened against Upfield US Inc., which generally allege
that Upfield US Inc. has engaged in misleading labelling and advertising of its products and violated various state
consumer fraud and deceptive business practice acts. The plaintiffs seek to certify classes of individuals who have
purchased the named products in certain states within the United States. See “Business—Litigation.” In addition, we
could incur substantial costs and fees in defending ourselves or in asserting our rights in these actions or meeting
new legal requirements. The costs and other effects of pending and potential litigation and administrative actions against
us, and new legal requirements, cannot be determined with certainty and may differ from expectations. Furthermore,
because litigation is inherently uncertain, the ultimate resolution of any such claim, lawsuit or proceeding through
settlement, mediation, or court judgment could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or
results of operations.

In the event we are unsuccessful in any litigation, proceedings or other disputes, we could be exposed to the risk
that the provisions for associated costs and fees, if any, may be insufficient or that, even if we are not impacted monetarily,
we could face the imposition of more stringent regulatory requirements or inspections and/or could suffer damage to our
image and reputation, which in turn could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results
of operations.

We must comply with complex and evolving tax regulations in the various jurisdictions in which we operate,

**_Loss of our key management and other personnel, or an inability to attract new management and other personnel,_**

Our success depends, in part, upon the continued services of key members of our management. Our executives’
and managers’ knowledge of the market and our business represent a key strength of our business, which cannot be

There can be no assurance that we will be able to hire or retain experienced, qualified employees to carry out

Our facilities and operations are subject to numerous health, safety and environmental regulations, including

**_Due to restrictions on the deduction of interest expenses or forfeiture of interest carry-forwards under Dutch law, we_**
**_may be unable to fully deduct interest expenses on our financial liabilities._**

The proceeds of this Offering will be utilized by us in connection with the partial redemption of the Senior
Notes. The Issuer will pay interest on the Notes semi-annually in arrears. Dutch tax law does provide for interest
deduction restrictions with respect to third-party debt taken up by the Issuer, the proceeds of which are used to grant
interest-bearing loans. Interest payments to the holders of the Notes are not subject to Dutch dividend withholding tax.

In 2019 and in accordance with the EU Anti-Tax Avoidance Directive, the Netherlands introduced an interest
deductibility limitation rule effective from January 1, 2019 (the “Dutch Fiscal EBITDA Rule”). Under the Dutch Fiscal
EBITDA Rule, net interest due in excess of 20% of the Issuer’s Dutch tax EBITDA is not deductible in that calendar
year. Net interest due means interest income minus interest expenses. If the Issuer is affected by the aforementioned
provision, the Issuer may no longer be able to (fully) deduct the interest expenses due to the holders of the Notes as a
result of which the Dutch corporate income tax burden may increase, until such time as interest is permitted to be
deducted in accordance with the Dutch Fiscal EBITDA Rule. The Dutch tax rate is currently 25.8% (a reduced rate
of 19% applies to the first €200,000 of taxable profit).

In addition, deemed interest payments to an affiliated (gelieerde) entity of the Issuer may be taxed with Dutch
withholding tax to a rate of 25.8% if the beneficiary (voordeelgerechtigde) of the payment is (i) an entity tax resident in
a low-tax jurisdiction or the benefit of the payment is attributable to an entity / permanent establishment in a low-tax
jurisdiction, or (ii) an entity not tax resident in a low-tax jurisdiction but established in a jurisdiction receiving the payment
with the aim to avoid taxation (subjective test) and the construction should be considered artificial (objective test), all
within the meaning of the Dutch Withholding Tax Act 2021 (Wet bronbelasting 2021). A jurisdiction is qualified as ‘lowtax’ if (i) the entity is not subject to tax or to a tax rate of less than 9%, or (ii) if the jurisdiction is included in the EU-list
of non-cooperative jurisdictions in the year of the payment.

**_Transfer pricing rules may have a material adverse effect on our results of operations._**

Certain of our subsidiaries have business relationships with other companies of the Group. Under certain
(corporate) income and trade tax law, such intra-group relationships are required to meet arm’s length terms. If intragroup relationships are not agreed on an arm’s length basis, certain tax authorities may in particular accept the
deduction of business expenses for tax purposes only to the extent the business expenses would have been incurred
in case of an arm’s length relationship. Under certain circumstances, intra-group performances that do not meet arm’s
length terms may also be re-qualified as deemed dividends. These consequences would negatively impact our financial
condition and results of operations.

With respect to business relationships between companies of the Group established in different jurisdictions,
certain tax authorities may request proper transfer pricing documentation from the relevant Group company. Such transfer
pricing documentation may also be requested by certain tax authorities with respect to the allocation of profits between

the tax authority in a timely manner upon such request, the tax authorities may adjust the taxable income of the relevant

**Risks Relating to the Senior Secured Notes, the Guarantees and the Collateral**

**_The Issuer is a holding company that has no independent business operations and no material assets and will depend_**
**_on cash from its operating subsidiaries to make payments on the Senior Secured Notes._**

The Issuer is a holding company and has no independent business operations or revenue-generating operations.
As of the Issue Date, the Issuer’s only material assets will be its equity interest in its subsidiaries. The Issuer’s ability to
make payments on or to refinance the Senior Secured Notes or other debt obligations will depend upon the availability of
cash on hand, the Group’s ability to generate and upstream cash from our operating subsidiaries to the Issuer and upon
the Group’s operating performance, which is affected by all the factors discussed in this “Risk Factors” section and
elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. We will only be able to pay interest, or principal, on the Senior Secured Notes
from funds received from the operating subsidiaries of the Group. Our subsidiaries’ ability to make distributions to us
will depend on our ability to generate substantial operating cash flow and to upstream distributions to the Issuer in the
form of dividends. Dividend payments are not mandatory or guaranteed, and we may decide not to, or be unable to,
declare a dividend. Additionally, the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement and the Indenture, as well as future debt, may
prevent or restrict our ability to upstream cash or to make distributions or payments of capital or income or use cash or
other assets to make principal or interest payments when due on our indebtedness, including the Senior Secured Notes.
The terms of the Intercreditor Agreement (as described under “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—
_Intercreditor Agreement”) and the terms of existing and future debt of certain of the Group subsidiaries may also prohibit_
the payment of dividends or the making, or repayment, of loans or advances to the Issuer and restrict certain intra-group
payments.

In addition, the ability of the Issuers’ direct or indirect subsidiaries to make certain distributions may be limited
by the laws of the jurisdictions in which the subsidiaries are organized or located, including financial assistance rules,
corporate benefit laws and other legal restrictions which, if violated, might require the recipient of unlawful payments to
refund any amounts received. See “—The Guarantees and the security interests in the Collateral will be subject to certain
_limitations on enforcement and may be limited by applicable laws or subject to certain defenses that may limit their_
_validity and enforceability.” There can therefore be no assurance that there will be sufficient assets or income available_
to enable the Issuer to pay interest or principal on Senior Secured Notes and there can be no assurance that any of their
subsidiaries will be able to make distributions or other payments.

**_The Senior Secured Notes will be structurally subordinated to the liabilities of non-guarantor subsidiaries and_**
**_effectively subordinated to liabilities that are secured on assets that do not secure the Senior Secured Notes._**

Certain of our subsidiaries will not guarantee the Senior Secured Notes. Unless a subsidiary is or becomes a
Guarantor, our subsidiaries will not have any obligations to pay amounts due under the Senior Secured Notes or to make
funds available for that purpose unless they guarantee the Senior Secured Notes or grant security interests in this respect.
Generally, holders of debt of, and trade creditors of, non-guarantor subsidiaries, including lenders under bank financing
agreements, are entitled to payment of their claims from the assets of such subsidiaries before these assets are made
available for distribution to the Issuer or any Guarantor, as a direct or indirect shareholder.

Accordingly, in the event that any non-guarantor subsidiary becomes insolvent, is liquidated, reorganized or
dissolved or is otherwise wound up other than as part of a solvent transaction:

    - the creditors of the Issuer and the Guarantors (including the holders of the Senior Secured Notes) will
have no right to proceed against the assets of such subsidiary; and

    - creditors of such non-guarantor subsidiary, including trade creditors, will generally be entitled to payment
in full from the sale or other disposal of the assets of such subsidiary before the Issuer or any Guarantor,
as a direct or indirect shareholder, will be entitled to receive any distributions from such subsidiary.

As such, the Senior Secured Notes and each Guarantee will be structurally subordinated to the creditors
(including trade creditors). As of March 31, 2024, on a consolidated basis, excluding items such as trade payables, our
subsidiaries that will not guarantee the Senior Secured Notes (excluding the Issuer), had no third-party borrowings. The

43


-----

Indenture, subject to certain limitations, will permit these non-Guarantors to incur additional indebtedness, which may
also be secured.

**_The Issuers and the Guarantors will have control over the Collateral securing the Senior Secured Notes, and the sale_**
**_of particular assets could reduce the pool of assets securing the Senior Secured Notes._**

The Security Documents will, subject to the terms of the Indenture, allow the Issuer and the Guarantors to remain
in possession of, retain control over, freely operate, and collect, invest and dispose of any income from the Collateral
securing the Senior Secured Notes. So long as no default or event of default under the Indenture is occurring or would
result therefrom and subject to the restrictions in the Indenture, the Issuer and the Guarantors may, among other things,
without any release or consent by the Security Agent, conduct ordinary course activities with respect to the Collateral,
such as selling or otherwise disposing of such Collateral and making ordinary course cash payments, including repayments
of indebtedness.

**_If a “Priority Facility” is introduced in accordance with the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement, creditors under such_**
**_facility, counterparties to certain hedging obligations and creditors under certain operating facilities could rank in_**
**_priority over the Senior Secured Notes._**

The Intercreditor Agreement provides that, in the context of a debt refinancing, and upon the satisfaction of
certain conditions, the Group may introduce a “Priority Facility” (as defined in the Intercreditor Agreement) which would
be entitled to rank in priority over the Senior Secured Notes. See “Description of Other Indebtedness—Intercreditor
_Agreement—Debt Refinancing.” Although the Intercreditor Agreement provides that such a Priority Facility cannot rank_
in priority to obligations under the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement without consent of the lenders thereunder, there is
no such protection for the holders of the Senior Secured Notes, and a Priority Facility may rank in priority over the Senior
Secured Notes, including with respect to payments, ranking of security or the application of proceeds from the
enforcement of Collateral. The Intercreditor Agreement includes provisions governing the sharing of proceeds from

Collateral, investors may not benefit from such recoveries if the then outstanding claims under such priority obligations

**_The Senior Secured Notes will be secured only to the extent of the value of the Collateral that has been granted as_**

portion of its assets in the event of an enforcement action. In addition, the Collateral may also secure additional debt, to

The value of the Collateral may be subject to significant changes in value over time due to, among other factors,
