**Overview**

We are a global leader in plant-based food, established in 2018, as a purpose-driven company with a clear vision:
“To make people healthier and happier with nutritious and delicious, natural, plant-based food that is good for you and
good for our planet.”

We develop, produce, distribute and market plant-based dairy alternative products in over 100 countries across
four core categories: Butters and Spreads, Creams, Liquids and Cheeses. Backed by a rich heritage and a global scale, we
are highly differentiated in the plant-based sector. Our reinvigorated iconic power brands reflect over 150 years of product
expertise and brand heritage and are trusted by consumers globally. Our scale, culture and capabilities, including extensive
food technology and innovation expertise, our community of dedicated “Upfielders,” consisting of our management team
and employees, and our 14 manufacturing facilities across five continents, provide a strong value proposition for our
customers and consumers, and ensure we are well positioned to advance the future of food.

Our products are marketed under a family of historic and iconic brands with strong recognition in their target
markets. Our products are made with natural and sustainably sourced ingredients. Our carefully selected ingredients come
from a diversified supply chain to minimize risk and environmental impact and maximize taste, functionality, health,
affordability and sustainability for our consumers.

Our operations are diversified across three regions, namely Europe, the Americas and AMEA. We hold
leadership positions in the global butter and spreads, and plant cheese segments, with leadership positions in creams in
Germany and the United Kingdom, our key creams markets. We sell our products across these regions primarily through
retail channels, such as supermarkets, hypermarkets, convenience stores and other outlets. In addition, through our
professional foodservice channel, we sell our products to commercial outlets, such as quick service restaurants, bakeries,
pizza and pasta outlets, hotels, catering and industrial kitchens, and to the social sector, such as educational institutions,
workplaces and hospitals.

During the years ended December 31, 2021, 2022 and 2023, our net sales were €2,793 million, €3,375 million
and €3,275 million, respectively. During the same periods, our operating profit was €288 million, €453 million and €570
million, and our Normalized EBITDA was €666 million, €749 million and €831 million, respectively. During the twelve
months ended March 31, 2024, our net sales were €3,209 million, our operating profit was €604 million and Normalized
EBITDA was €862 million.

**_Our Successful Transformation_**

Following the acquisition of our business by KKR in 2018, we began a journey to separate, transform and
reinvent our business, building on our existing strong foundations: a global platform with iconic power brands and worldclass knowledge.

Our journey took more than four years, with the wholescale transformational part of our journey completed in
2022. To become an independent business, we focused on separating and stabilizing our business, simplifying, renovating
and innovating our product portfolio, expanding into new product categories, investing in R&D through the opening of a

62


-----

new Food Science Centre, optimizing our supply chain, building an end-to-end globally scaled and digitally-enabled
platform and building a new IT infrastructure. See “Business—History” for a detailed description of our transformation
journey.

Building on our existing strong foundations and as a result of the significant industrial, digital and cultural
transformation undertaken since 2018, we believe we are well positioned to advance the future of food.

**Factors Affecting Comparability**

**_Fluctuations in Exchange Rates_**

We operate internationally and, as a result, are exposed to changes in various currency exchange rates. We have
exchange rate exposure in our key markets particularly in relation to fluctuations of the U.S. dollar, the pound sterling,
the Polish zloty, the Canadian dollar, the Mexican peso, the Indonesian rupiah and the Turkish lira, in each case against
the euro, which is the Group’s reporting currency. As a consequence, we have considerable cash flow, revenue, costs,
assets and liabilities in foreign currencies. Our exposure to changes in exchange rates has affected our results of operations
for the periods under presentation, and can mainly be described in terms of translation exposure and transaction exposure
affecting the comparability of results. For instance, the significant Turkish lira depreciation was one of the main
contributors in the decline of net sales in AMEA, as reported in euro, for the year ended December 31, 2023. In addition,
the euro to pound sterling and the euro to U.S. dollar exchange rates have been volatile for the periods under presentation
due to various factors including the war in Ukraine, the conflict in the Middle-East, Brexit and partially the COVID-19
pandemic. As a result, we also present certain metrics, such as our net sales growth, gross profit growth, operating profit
growth and Normalized EBITDA growth on a constant currency basis, such that these metrics are calculated by excluding
the impact of foreign currency fluctuations and both the current and prior periods local currency values are translated into
euro using prior year average exchange rates. See “Presentation of Financial and Other Information” and “Summary—
_Summary Historical and Other Financial Information.”_

_Translation Exposure_

Translation exposure describes the risk of impact that exchange rates could have on the value of sales, costs,
assets and liabilities reported in euro on our consolidated income statement and balance sheet. For example, a weakening
of the euro against the U.S. dollar will result in an increase in net sales as reported in euro and, conversely, the
strengthening of the euro against the U.S. dollar will result in a decrease in net sales as reported in euro. As 25.7% and
25.3% of our net sales for the year ended December 31, 2023 and for the three months ended March 31, 2024, respectively,
comes from the United States, these effects may be significant. We are primarily subject to translation effects with respect
to non-euro revenues, costs and liabilities, as well as, non-euro goodwill and intangible assets.

_Transaction Exposure_

Our exchange rate transaction risks principally relate to purchases of raw materials including Plant Oils, which
may have underlying global commodity price indexes denominated in U.S. dollar or may have a degree of correlation
with the U.S. dollar (despite underlying indexes being priced in euro or other currencies). We are exposed to a transaction
risk since such U.S. dollar denominated raw materials are mainly invoiced to us in euro. Other ingredient and packaging
costs (apart from certain commodity inputs) are generally denominated in the functional currencies of the jurisdictions in
which our operations (including manufacturing plants and distribution hubs) are located, which in most cases correlate to
the markets and currencies in which sales are made. To hedge against foreign currency risk, we use forward foreign
currency exchange contracts and cross currency interest rate swaps. We also manage our foreign currency risk by
implementing the natural hedge of incurring indebtedness in the various principal currencies in which our turnover is
denominated. As a result, we have debt service obligations denominated in U.S. dollars, pound sterling, polish zloty and
euro. See also “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—We are exposed to foreign exchange rate
_risks and such may have a material adverse effect on our results of operations.”_

**_Hyperinflationary Economies_**

As the cumulative inflation in Turkey over the past three years has exceeded 100%, we applied hyperinflationary
accounting under IAS 29 Financial Reporting in Hyperinflationary Economies for the years ended December 31, 2022
and December 31, 2023 and for the three months ended March 31, 2024. IAS 29 requires that the results of our Turkish
subsidiary be reported as if these were hyperinflationary as of January 1, 2022. The application of IAS 29 includes: (i)
adjustment of historical cost non-monetary assets and liabilities for the change in purchasing power caused by inflation
from the date of initial recognition to the balance sheet date, (ii) adjustment of the statement of profit or loss for inflation
during the reporting period, (iii) the statement of profit or loss is translated at the period-end foreign exchange rate instead

63


-----

of an average rate and (iv) adjustment of the statement of profit or loss to reflect the impact of inflation and exchange rate
movement on holding monetary assets and liabilities in local currency. As a result, a net monetary loss of €4 million for
the three months ended March 31, 2024 and of €4 million for the year ended December 31, 2023 (as compared to nil for
the three months ended March 31, 2023 and €7 million for the year ended December 31, 2022, respectively) for Turkey
has been recognized in net finance costs in our consolidated statement of profit or loss.

**Factors Affecting Results of Operations**

Our operating results are affected by a combination of economic, regulatory, industry-specific and companyspecific factors. The following is a description of the key factors affecting our results of operations in prior periods and
which are expected to affect our results going forward.

**_Input Prices_**

The principal ingredient in our Plant Butter and Spreads, Plant Creams, Liquids and Plant Cheeses are refined
Plant Oils. Aside from Plant Oils, additional key inputs used in our production process include other natural ingredients,
packaging materials and utility inputs such as water and energy. We obtain substantially all of our materials (which
includes Plant Oils, other ingredients, flavors, finished goods from third-party manufacturers and packaging materials)
from third-party suppliers, with the cost of these materials representing 67% and 68% of our total cost of sales for the
year ended December 31, 2023 and the three months ended March 31, 2024, respectively.

Plant Oils and other ingredients prices can fluctuate substantially over relatively short periods of time. In
particular, price volatility has increased since the outset of the COVID-19 pandemic with prices remaining relatively high
compared to pre-pandemic levels, as well as due to the ongoing conflicts between Russia and Ukraine and in the Middle
East. Although we do not source sunflower oil from Ukraine directly, as Ukraine is the world’s biggest exporter of
sunflower oil, beginning the first quarter of the year ended December 31, 2022, the war in Ukraine caused a global
shortage of sunflower oil, which in turn led to a rise in the price of sunflower oil during the year ended December 31,
2022. In response to potential sunflower oil supply chain disruptions, we utilized our “Blendflex” capability, that allows
us to substitute and swap ingredients within our Plant Butters and Spreads, such as switching sunflower oil for rapeseed
oil, without any impact on the taste, texture or functionality of our products. However, sunflower oil remains an important
ingredient for our product portfolio. The increase in sunflower oil prices has also had a knock-on effect on the prices of
other Plant Oils, including palm, rapeseed and soybean oil. In addition, palm oil has witnessed significant price swings in
recent years, resulting in historically high prices during the year ended December 31, 2022. This increase was mainly due
to slower production by the main producer nations and the adoption of a domestic market obligation policy by Indonesia,
which is the world’s largest palm oil producer, in February 2022. Under the domestic market obligation policy, producers
had to set aside 450,000 tonnes a month of their shipments for local buyers. This was followed by an export ban in late
April 2022. Although the ban was lifted three weeks later, it created significant uncertainty in the market. Effective from
May 2023, Indonesia agreed on lowering its mandatory domestic sales threshold for palm oil producers from 450,000 to
300,000 tonnes a month, allowing for more export, however volatility in the palm oil market has persisted.

Other factors which have impacted the prices of Plant Oils, include their growing use as biofuel and the impact
of weather patterns, in particular, El Niño (a climate pattern that is declared when sea temperatures in the tropical eastern
Pacific rise 0.5 degrees Celsius. El Niño has now returned and is expected to last at least through the first half of 2024,
according to the latest United Nations forecasts. Historically, times of El Niño have generally seen a decline in Plant Oils
production growth.

In addition to significant volatility in Plant Oils prices, recent periods have also seen a significant surge in energy
and transportation prices, as well as the supply chain interruptions, caused by recent geopolitical and other events,
including the ongoing conflicts between Russia and Ukraine and in the Middle East, and the COVID-19 pandemic. In
particular, our inputs suppliers’ cost base has seen an adverse impact in recent periods, which they have subsequently
sought to pass on to us. For example, because of the energy intensive nature of the refinery process to turn crude oils into
refined oils, our Plant Oils suppliers have sought to pass on their heightened energy costs to us. All of this has exposed
us in turn to significantly higher Plant Oils, packaging, energy costs, and as a consequence thereof, higher manufacturing,
logistics and transportation costs, which we may not be able to effectively hedge or fully pass on to our customers.

To manage our input costs, we regularly monitor global market prices and enter into a combination of fixed
contracts and commodity derivatives to protect against volatility. With this approach, through a combination of hedging
and fixed price contracts, we generally had price visibility on approximately 77% of our total cost of sales on a rolling
six month basis, or 49% of our total cost of sales on a rolling 12 month basis, in each case as of March 31, 2024. We use
commodity derivatives (futures, over the counter and tradable forward contracts) to hedge against commodity price risk
in respect of the major Plant Oils we purchase, as well as certain packaging materials and utilities. Our policy is to hedge

64


-----

the majority of the risk within the relevant pricing window. The extent of hedging is determined on an ongoing and on a
country and/or region basis, depending on hedging volumes and the pricing horizon. Our hedging ratio increases when
the exposure/volatility is higher and the pricing window is shorter. All of our commodity derivative contracts hedge future
purchases of Plant Oils, certain packaging materials and utilities on a three to six months rolling basis. This hedging
policy allows us to weather short term price movements and gives our sales teams time to price accordingly, taking into
account the typical cycle of customer negotiation windows (typically, annually and semi-annually in Europe and North
America, and less then semi-annually in LatAm and AMEA). Our hedging policy is implemented by our in-house
commodity risk management team, and while we do not take speculative views on the market, we monitor our position
regularly in line with our in-house team’s assessment. While we generally operate within this policy, in circumstances
where it is recommended by our specialist commodity risk management team and approved by our executive risk
committee, which consists of senior members of management, we can take longer hedging positions in exceptional
circumstances. Due to our Plant Oils inventories and hedging arrangements, a change in the cost of our Plant Oils can
take between three to six months to be fully realized in our cost of sales.

In response to the significant inflation experienced across our primary inputs in Plant Oils, packaging materials,
energy, manufacturing and logistics over the reporting period, particularly in 2021 and 2022, we also increased our pricing
through a number of pricing waves, with the last such pricing wave implemented in July 2022. We typically seek to
negotiate our pricing with our customers in Europe and North America on an annual basis, and we do so in LatAm and
AMEA on a semi-annual or more ad-hoc basis, depending on the increase in cost base and the relationship with retailers
and distributors in such market. In addition, with a view to maintaining our profitability and margins, which were impacted
as a result of such inflation, we continued other value protection measures such as our value creation program, which
focuses on making our business more efficient from an operational perspective and in particular through supply chain
areas including, amongst others, procurement, manufacturing and portfolio simplification. Pursuant to the value creation
program, we achieved approximately €90 million of savings measured at constant currency, representing 4.4% of our cost
of sales for the year ended December 31, 2023. Since the inception of Upfield in July 2018, we have achieved a total of
approximately €415 million in savings measured at constant currency through our value creation program and similar
initiatives. The continued recovery of our margin throughout 2022 and 2023 reflects the time lag between the
implementation of our pricing initiatives (particularly during the year ended December 31, 2022) and the impact of
inflation across our key inputs. Inflationary pressures have persisted throughout 2022 and 2023, and we remain exposed
to fluctuations in the prices of our key inputs. Our ability to mitigate the impact of such fluctuations through the pricing
of our products will need to be balanced against competitive dynamics in our various regions. See also “—Quantitative
_and Qualitative Disclosures about Liquidity Risk, Credit Risk and Market Risk—Market Risk.“_

**_Changes in Food Trends and Consumer Preferences_**

There are a number of changing consumer trends, demands and preferences which have an effect on both our
Group and the industry in which we operate. These include, dietary, health and environmental concerns and trends, such
as increasing awareness of different nutritional aspects of foods and the health effects and sourcing practices relating to
specific ingredients, an increasing preference for dairy-free, vegan and organic food ingredients, trends towards eating
and baking outside of home and concerns regarding public health consequences associated with obesity and increasing
awareness of the environmental and social effects of production (in particular those related to palm oil, which is a key
ingredient in many products across our portfolio). The food industry, particularly in developed markets and with respect
to unhealthier foods and high-fat, sweet and salty options, could also face a softer demand in the coming years because
of obesity medicines decreasing appetite and reducing daily calorie intake. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our
_Business and Industry—Changes in food trends and consumer preferences may have a material adverse effect on our_
_results of operations.”_

Currently there is an increasing trend of consumers across markets preferring non-dairy plant-based products as
a result of the increasing awareness of lactose-intolerance health issues, high carbon footprint and the environmental
impact of dairy consumption. Consumers are increasingly prioritizing environmentally friendly product choices due to
heightened concerns about climate change, with plant-based options being favored for their lower CO₂ emissions,
reduced resource consumption, and longer shelf life. Environmentally friendly packaging is also gaining importance,
with a preference for all-paper solutions to reduce plastic usage. With initiatives like the world’s first plastic-free,
recyclable tub for our Flora Plant brand and patented palm-oil free products, we believe that our product offering
strongly aligns with these consumer trends. In the dairy category, health-conscious consumers are also increasingly
turning to low-cholesterol, trans-fat-free options like our plant-based products. For example, our Plant Butter and
Spreads have a number of health and environmental advantages over dairy butter, such as higher Omega 3 and 6 fatty
acid concentrations, zero trans-fat and lower saturated fat content. See also “Industry—Key Trends.”

However, this growing trend towards plant-based alternatives may be adversely impacted by a number of factors,
such as misconceptions about “highly processed” plant-based foods, perceived “naturalness” of dairy and increased

65


-----

regulatory control of the plant-based sector. In addition, there has been negative press coverage in recent years as regards
products made from palm oil due to both health and environmental concerns. For example, among our key markets, Spain
and the Netherlands in particular, have seen a greater negative press coverage and perception as regards use of palm oil
based products. In response thereto, we created a patented palm oil-free technology and we have shifted our focus on
offering alternatives to palm oil in some of our markets. Although we source certified (segregated and mass balance) palm
oil and offer palm oil-free options in a number of markets, there is a risk that additional press coverage and the resulting
negative consumer perception of products made from palm oil further escalates. Although we recognize the controversy
around palm oil as an ingredient and continue to innovate and create new recipes both with sustainable palm oil and
alternatives to palm oil through our patented palm oil-free technology, some of our products contain palm oil and
switching to exclusively palm oil-free products may not be currently technically feasible.

In addition, following Russia’s invasion of Ukraine in February 2022 and the conflict in the Middle East, the
global markets and economy have experienced significant uncertainty. There has been a sharp rise in energy and food
costs, resulting in inflationary macroeconomic conditions across most major economies and markets where we operate.
Given these economic conditions, there has been a significant decline in disposable incomes of many households, creating
a cost of living crisis, that has altered the purchasing habits of consumers. In these circumstances, consumers may choose
to economize by purchasing non-branded or private–label brands, which may be cheaper than our products. A reduction
in consumer disposable income could foster a move by our customers towards discounters and non-branded products,
which would impact our market share and adversely affect our net sales.

Aside from affecting our net sales, lower sales volumes also reduce the rate of cost absorption, meaning that in
periods where key input costs are higher, margins are adversely impacted to a greater degree than would otherwise be the
case. We have consistently operated with a clear approach to fluctuations in commodity and packaging costs in regards
to procurement and hedging policies and, as a result, have been able to maintain strong levels of profitability after direct
costs in changing cost environments. Moreover, our ability to effectively leverage our product development expertise to
continually update our portfolio in response to changing consumer tastes, especially with the development of innovative
premium products, is a key element of our strategy.

**_Customer Pricing_**

“Customer pricing” refer to prices that we charge to retailers. We do not set the prices that retailers charge to
end-use consumers.

The prices paid by our customers for our products are a key driver of our financial results and are affected by a
number of external factors. Pricing is mostly driven by the terms we agree with our major retail customers. We typically
conduct annual negotiations with most of our large retail customers in key markets in Europe and North America in
respect of the supply and pricing of our products in the first quarter of the year. Negotiations in AMEA and LatAm can
take place semi-annually or more frequently in some cases. These agreements, often referred to as “joint business plans,”
usually encompass pricing, trade terms, support for new innovation, assortment, distribution and shelf space. In some
markets, the agreements also include promotional activity for the year, although in most markets it is still possible to
change promotional activity and pricing during the year. In 2021 and 2022, on the back of the COVID-19 pandemic and
the associated supply chain disruption and the inflationary environment, these discussions took place on a more frequent
basis and in some cases pricing negotiations were prolonged. The impact of such prolonged negotiations saw us stop
shipments to certain customers during the discussions, which had an impact on financial performance during such period.
While there was no material lasting impact on financial performance, there can be no assurance that similar issues will
not arise in future years given the competitive dynamics of our industry. In territories where resale price maintenance is
not permitted, retailers remain free at all times to set levels of retail pricing, which depends on a number of factors,
including retailer margin, demand for our products among consumers and the relative affordability of our products as
compared to competing products (which may be particularly relevant given the ongoing cost of living crisis in a number
of markets where we offer our products). In particular, the consumer prices of and demand for our Plant Butter and
Spreads, Plant Creams, Liquids and Plant Cheeses products may also be influenced by a substitution effect with the market
price of competing dairy products including butter, cream and cheese. Butter price increased significantly between 2021
and 2023, driven by factors including higher costs of energy and fertilisers, which we believe has had a positive effect on
the relative prices of our products.

**_Seasonality_**

Our sales have historically been affected by seasonal cyclicality in customer orders in various markets. The
extent and impact of such seasonal variations varies among the countries in which we operate. For example, the U.S.
business typically experiences a spike in the fourth quarter of the year which is driven by Thanksgiving and Christmas
baking. Similarly, there can be some seasonality in sales in Europe and the Americas owing to Easter, which can occur

66


-----

during the first or second quarter of the year. Similarly, in Indonesia there is a peak in butter and spreads usage for cooking
and baking during the Ramadan festival season, which can occur in various quarters from year to year. Furthermore,
across all the countries in which we operate, the timing of product promotions drives volatility from normal consumption.
While our sales are seasonal, many of our costs, such as personnel costs, are incurred more evenly throughout the year,
which could affect measures of profitability in the short term and put pressure on our working capital position. In addition,
for these reasons, sequential quarterly comparisons may not be a reliable indication of the performance of our business
or how we may perform in the future.

**Explanation of Certain Income Statement Items**

**_Net Sales_**

Net sales comprise sales of goods (across our core categories: Butters and Spreads, Creams, Liquids and Cheeses)
after the deduction of discounts, sales taxes and estimated returns. It does not include sales between Group companies.
Discounts given by the Group include rebates, price reductions and incentives given to customers and promotional
couponing. Net sales from contracts with customers is recognized when control of the goods or services is transferred to
the customer at an amount that reflects the consideration to which the Group expects to be entitled in exchange for those
goods or services. Transfer of control is generally on delivery to the customer but depending on individual customer
terms, this can be at the time of dispatch, delivery or upon formal customer acceptance. Payment of the transaction price
is due immediately at the point where control passes to the customer. For the periods under presentation, net sales also
included royalty income from external customers.

**_Cost of Sales_**

Cost of sales includes raw and packaging material costs, cost of conversion (including the depreciation of related
fixed assets), logistics and warehousing costs, business waste and other supply chain costs. In particular, other supply
chain costs, or supply chain overheads, includes expenses relating to supply chain personnel that are not reported under
production, logistics or warehousing expenses, such as demand and supply planning personnel, quality assurance
personnel and supply chain leadership.

**_Selling, General and Administrative Expenses_**

Selling, general and administrative expenses include (i) advertising and promotion expenses, (ii) certain research
and development costs, which are not capitalized in our statement of financial position data, (iii) indirect central costs and
(iv) general corporate expenses, as further discussed below:

    - advertising and promotion expenses include: (i) advertising expenses (including media spend on traditional
and digital media spots, as well as agency fees and production costs for traditional and digital media), (ii)
promotional expenses (including the costs of promotion packs and samples, communication material and
promotion agency costs) and (iii) point of sale investment (including costs of third-party merchandisers and
point of sale materials);

    - research and development costs primarily relate to the maintenance and expansion of our research and
development facilities as well as certain salary and materials expenses. Expenditures for research activities
are recognized as an expense in the period in which they are incurred. Expenditures incurred during the
development phase of an internal project are capitalized in our statement of financial position data, if the
following conditions are met: (i) the technical feasibility of completing the intangible asset so that it will be
available for use or sale, (ii) the intention to complete the intangible asset and use or sell it, (iii) the ability
to use or the intention to sell the intangible asset, (iv) how the intangible asset will generate probable future
economic benefits, (v) the availability of adequate technical, financial and other resources to complete the
development and to use or sell the intangible asset and (vi) the ability to measure reliably the expenditure
attributable to the intangible asset during its development.

    - indirect central costs primarily relate to our sales force, merchandising activities, general management,
marketing teams and general marketing costs; and

    - general corporate and local market expenses primarily relate to the finance, legal, IT, HR, communications
and internal audit functions.

67


-----

**_Net Finance Costs_**

Net finance costs are comprised of finance costs and finance income. Finance costs include interest costs in
relation to our financial liabilities (including in relation to the Existing Notes, the Senior Term Facilities, the Revolving
Credit Facility and the lease liabilities pursuant to the application of IFRS 16 (Leases), bank charges and fees, net
monetary loss arising from application of IAS 29 (Financial Reporting in Hyperinflationary Economies) and net foreign
currency exchange losses. The costs of issuing borrowings is expensed over the period as they accrue, based on the
effective interest method. Finance income includes interest income on cash and cash equivalents, interest income on
other financial assets and net foreign currency exchange gain.

**_Income Tax Expense_**

Income tax expense comprises current income tax expense and deferred income tax expense. Income tax expense
is recognized in the income statement except to the extent that it relates to items recognized directly in equity or other
comprehensive income. Current income tax expense comprises the expected tax receivable/payable on the taxable income
or loss for the year, using tax rates enacted or substantively enacted at the balance sheet date and any adjustments to tax
receivable/payable in respect of previous years. Current tax assets and current tax liabilities are offset if there is a legally
enforceable right to set off the recognized amounts and if we intend to either settle on a net basis or to realize the asset
and settle the liability simultaneously. We operate in multiple jurisdictions which are subject to the application of complex
tax laws. Application of these complex tax laws may lead to uncertainties on tax positions. Management aims to resolve
these uncertainties in discussions with the tax authorities. When there is uncertainty over income tax treatments,
management is required to consider the effect of the uncertainty in determining taxable profit (tax loss), tax base, tax
losses and tax credits and tax rates.

**Segment Reporting**

Operating segments are based on geographical areas, which are Europe, the Americas and AMEA. So as to align
with our internal reporting and management structure, beginning the year ended December 31, 2022, we changed our
operating segments from “Developed Markets” and “Emerging Markets” to Europe, the Americas and AMEA. We review
the performance of segments based on the measures of net sales and Normalized EBIT, and resources are allocated
accordingly. Additionally, Normalized EBITDA is used by us within our internal reporting process. Global corporate
expenses are proportionately allocated to Europe, the Americas and AMEA based on net sales. The comparative segment
information for the year ended December 31, 2021 in our consolidated financial statements of the Company as of and for
the year ended December 31, 2022, has been restated as if the operating segments were changed as of January 1, 2021.

**_Net Sales_**

sales growth was 18.5%.

Our constant currency net sales growth represents the change in net sales for the relevant period compared to the
prior period, calculated on a constant currency basis. See “Presentation of Financial and Other Information.” Our
management believes for the periods under discussion, the drivers of our constant currency net sales growth (which are
discussed below) were the key indicators as to the underlying performance of our business. For the periods under
discussion, the difference between our constant currency net sales and reported net sales is due to movements in foreign

**Liquidity and Capital Resources**

**_Liquidity_**

Liquidity describes our ability to generate sufficient cash flows to meet the cash requirements of our business
operations, including working capital needs, debt service obligations, capital expenditures, contractual obligations and
other commitments, as well as acquisitions. Our primary sources of liquidity are provided by our cash from operating
activities, including our net negative working capital position, and our financings. Our principal liquidity requirements
arise from the need to settle supplier payables and fund our ongoing operations. During the periods under review, the

77


-----

liquidity needs of the business were mainly funded from cash from operations (including our net negative working capital
position) and borrowings under the Senior Term Facilities and the Revolving Credit Facility. Our business is cash
generative and during the periods under review we benefited from a negative cash conversion cycle, driven by longer
credit terms received on purchases from our suppliers compared to those offered to our customers.

After the consummation of the Transactions, we will continue to have a substantial amount of indebtedness. As
of March 31, 2024, on a pro forma basis, after giving effect to the Transactions, we would have outstanding €5,768 million
(equivalent) in aggregate indebtedness (excluding the principal amount of lease liabilities recognized by us under IFRS
16 (Leases)), with an additional €567 million of borrowing capacity available under our Revolving Credit Facility.

To meet these additional liquidity needs going forward, we expect our sources of liquidity will consist mainly
of the following:

    - cash generated from our operating activities;

    - borrowings under the Revolving Credit Facility;

    - issuances of debt securities; and

    - borrowings under other loan facilities.

Although we believe that our expected cash flows from operations, together with available borrowings, will be
adequate to meet our anticipated liquidity needs, working capital requirements and debt service obligations for the next
twelve months, we cannot assure you that our business will generate sufficient cash flows from operations or that future
debt and equity financing will be available to us in an amount sufficient to enable us to pay our debts when due, including
the Notes, or to fund all of our other projected liquidity needs.

We believe that the potential risks to our liquidity include:

    - a reduction in operating cash flows due to a lowering of net income from our operations, which could be
due to downturns in our performance or the industry as a whole;

    - increased commodity costs which we cannot pass onto customers;

    - exposure to increased interest rates in relation to our borrowings which bear interest at a variable rate,
including our Senior Term Facilities and our Revolving Credit Facility;

    - changes in trade terms, consumer preferences or market conditions which might imperil our ability to
maintain a net negative working capital position consistent with past practice; and

    - higher capital expenditure, such as due to higher than expected expenses incurred in connection with our
product innovation and growth strategies.

If our future cash flows from operations and other capital resources (including borrowings under the Revolving
Credit Facility) are insufficient to pay our obligations as they mature or to fund our liquidity needs, we may be forced to:

    - reduce or delay our business activities and capital expenditure;

    - sell assets;

    - obtain additional debt or equity capital; or

    - restructure or refinancing all or a portion of our debt, including the Notes, on or before maturity.

We cannot assure you that we would be able to accomplish any of these alternatives on a timely basis or on
satisfactory terms, if at all. In addition, the terms of our existing debt, including the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement,
limit, and the terms of the Notes, will limit our ability to pursue any of these alternatives, as may the terms of any future
debt.

**_Changes in Working Capital_**

Our working capital consists of the sum of our inventory, trade receivables, other current receivables, trade
payables and other current liabilities. The Group benefits from a negative cash conversion cycle, driven by longer credit
terms received on purchases from its suppliers compared to those offered to its customers. Particularly in Europe and
North America, trade receivables are net of trade term rebates and trade payable days are significantly longer than
inventory and receivables days. Historically, we have managed our trade payables on typically 90 to 120 day terms and
managed our receivables on typically 30 day terms. We also offer additional discounts to customers in many markets for
“prompt payment,” which is defined as payment in less than 30 days. Our negative cash conversion largely is a structural
feature of the payment terms customarily available in the raw material and finished product markets in which we operate,
and while there are some risks to our ability to maintain our working capital cycle on precisely these terms going forward
this cycle is not expected to shift fundamentally in the future. This cycle is also a result of our operational efficiency with
respect to our inventory management. See also “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—We are
_subject to credit risk with respect to our customers and suppliers.”_

The change in working capital for the three months ended March 31, 2024, was an outflow of €114 million,
compared to an outflow of €117 million for the three months ended March 31, 2023, driven by a combination of typical
seasonal effects, deflationary effects on payables, alongside some timing impacts on receivables.

The change in working capital for the year ended December 31, 2023 was an outflow of €71 million, compared
to an inflow of €44 million in the year ended December 31, 2022. The outflow in 2023 was driven by a decrease in
payables reflecting deflationary effects, the impact of commodity hedging, and, to a lesser extent, bonus impacts.

The change in working capital for the year ended December 31, 2022 was an inflow of €44 million, compared
to an inflow of €86 million for the year ended 31 December 2021. The lower inflow in 2022 was driven by a combination
of higher inventories, reflecting the decision to carry higher safety stocks, and higher receivables, reflecting inflationary
effects. The working capital inflow of €86 million for the year ended 2021 is as derived from our consolidated statement
of cash flows, and consists of a sum of inventories (negative €18 million), trade receivables (€73 million), other
receivables (€79 million), trade payables (€54 million) and other liabilities (negative €85 million), and, to align with the
presentation adopted by us for periods subsequent to the year ended December 31, 2021, further considering the outflow
for the increase in provisions for the year ended December 31, 2021 (€17 million).

**Analysis of Certain Consolidated Balance Sheet Items**

**_Inventories_**

Inventories are valued at the lower of weighted average cost and net realizable value. Cost comprises direct costs
and, where appropriate, a proportion of attributable production overheads that have been incurred in bringing the
inventories to their present location and condition. Net realizable value is the estimated selling price less all estimated
costs of completion necessary to make the sale. Our inventories are comprised of (i) raw materials and consumables, (ii)
work in progress, (iii) finished goods and goods for resale and (iv) engineering spare parts.

**_Trade and Current Receivables_**

Our trade receivables principally comprise payments due from customers for the supply of our products.
Concentrations of credit risk with respect to trade receivables are limited as our customer base is large and diverse on a
global basis. As of December 31, 2023, we had over 2,590 customers across 56 subsidiaries with the top 50 customers

80


-----

accounting for approximately 48% of all the receivables outstanding. Not one of our individual customers had a
concentration of more than 4% of the outstanding trade receivable balance.

Trade and other receivables are recognized initially at fair value plus any directly attributable transaction costs
and subsequently measured at amortized cost. The fair values of trade and other current receivables are not considered to
be significantly different from their carrying values. We have a non-recourse factoring arrangement with a financial
institution. As part of the arrangement, we transfer our eligible trade receivables to the financial institution and receive
an initial part of the transferred receivables. The legal title and rights to the factored receivables have been passed to the
financial institution, therefore the control of the factored receivables has been transferred. The transferred receivables are
derecognized for the amount that is initially factored with the remaining amounts of the transferred receivables maintained
on our balance sheet. The financial institution charges a fixed service fee and interest based on utilization of the facility
which are included in finance costs.

**_Trade Payables and Other Current Liabilities_**

Trade payables comprise amounts due to creditors, principally for the supply of Plant Oils used in the
manufacture of our products, as well as packaging and distribution costs. Trade payables and other current liabilities are
recognized initially at fair value less any directly attributable transaction costs and subsequently measured at amortized
cost. The fair values of trade payables and other current liabilities are not considered to be significantly different from
their carrying values.

**Capital Expenditures**

Following our acquisition by KKR in 2018 and our transformation as a separate business, during the periods
presented, our capital expenditures have largely been devoted to the enhancement of production capacities across multiple
regions. In the short to medium term, we do not expect significant capital expenditure needs, and expect to incur ordinary
course maintenance capital expenditure and select investment capital expenditure to support certain key growth initiatives.
Such capital expenditures would exclude any impact on our financial statements pursuant to recognition of right of use
assets as lease liabilities under IFRS 16 (Leases).

**Financial Liabilities and Contractual Obligations**

**_Contractual Obligations_**

In addition to our indebtedness, we have major contractual relationships with our customers and in respect of
our supply chain. We enter into “joint business plans” with our major retailer customers which are year-long contractual
frameworks governing the supply of products to such retailers and the participation in joint promotional and periodic
discount activities with such major retailers. Precise volumes and prices of products supplied are not typically locked into
these contracts in advance. With respect to our supply chain, we enter into cash-settled hedging arrangements with
counterparties in the commodity markets to hedge pricing risks. We also enter into physical forwards and spot or nearspot supply contracts with a range of reputable, high-quality suppliers of Plant Oils and other essential inputs. We have a
small number of long-term supply contracts with raw materials suppliers, typically in situations where a long-term
contract helps such supplier mitigate start-up risks or ramp-up/ramp-down costs, thus improving the pricing terms
available to us. Finally, we are party to collective bargaining arrangements in respect of certain of our manufacturing
facilities.

**_Contingent Liabilities_**

Contingent liabilities are possible obligations that are not probable or not reliably measurable. They may arise
in respect of litigation against Group companies, investigations by competition, regulatory or fiscal authorities and
obligations arising under environmental legislations. In many markets in which we operate, there is a high degree of
complexity involved in the local tax regimes, which could also result in contingent liabilities.

Since 2022, Upfield US Inc. (“Upfield US”), a Group company, has been named as a party in a series of alleged
putative class action lawsuits. For additional information, please see “Business—Litigation.” As of March 31, 2024, a
material loss exposure in respect of these proceedings is not probable or reliably estimable.

**Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Liquidity Risk, Credit Risk and Market Risk**

The main risks arising from our financial instruments are liquidity risk, credit risk and market risk as explained
below. Our treasury department has overall responsibility for the establishment and oversight of our risk management
framework.

The treasury department’s activities are designed to:

    - protect the Group’s financial results and position from the financial risks discussed below;

    - maintain market risks within acceptable parameters, while optimizing returns; and

    - provide adequate and sufficient funding to the Group.

For further information on the risks discussed below, please see note 19 of the consolidated financial statements
of the Company as of and for the year ended December 31, 2023.

82


-----

**_Liquidity Risk_**

Liquidity risk is the risk that the Group will face in meeting its obligations associated with its financial liabilities.
The Group’s approach to managing liquidity is to ensure that it will have sufficient funds to meet its liabilities when due
without incurring unacceptable costs. In doing this, management considers both normal and stressed conditions. A
material and sustained shortfall in cash flow could undermine the Group’s credit rating, impair investor confidence and
also restrict the Group’s ability to raise funds.

We have various credit facilities including a Revolving Credit Facility with a consortium of banks, containing
several financial covenants. As of March 31, 2024, €133 million, representing 19.0%, is withdrawn of the total €700
million Revolving Credit Facility. Compliance with financial covenants is reviewed regularly and they are reported to the
lenders quarterly in line with the requirements under the facilities. This is based on cash delivery from the business,
coupled with the proceeds from bond issuances and other sources of debt. This cash has been invested conservatively
with low-risk counterparties at maturities of less than three months.

Upon completion of the Transactions, we expect our financial liabilities at that time to comprise principally the
Senior Secured Notes, the Senior Notes and the amounts drawn under the Revolving Credit Facility and the Senior Credit
Facilities described above under “—Liquidity and Capital Resources.”

**_Credit Risk_**

Credit risk is the risk of financial loss to the Group if a customer or counterparty fails to meet its contractual
obligations. We are exposed to credit risk from our operating activities (primarily trade receivables) and from our
financing activities, including deposits with banks and financial institution and treasury instruments. Credit risk related
to the use of treasury instruments is managed on a Group basis. This risk arises from transactions with financial institutions
involving cash and cash equivalents, deposits and derivative financial instruments. We have not entered into credit default
derivatives. To reduce this risk, we have concentrated our main activities with a number of counterparties which have
secure credit ratings. Individual risk limits are set for each counterparty based on financial position, credit rating and past
experience. Credit limits and concentration of exposures are actively monitored by our treasury department.

Customer credit risk is managed by each business unit subject to the established policy, procedures and controls
relating to customer credit risk management. Credit quality of a customer is assessed based on a credit rating scorecard
and individual credit limits are defined in accordance with this assessment. Outstanding customer receivables are regularly
monitored and any shipments to major customers are generally covered by letters of credit or other forms of credit
insurance obtained from reputable banks and other financial institutions.

As of December 31, 2023, we had over 2,590 customers across 56 subsidiaries with the top 50 customers
accounting for approximately 48% of all the receivables outstanding. Not one of our individual customers had a
concentration of more than 4% of the outstanding trade receivable balance. An impairment analysis is performed at each
reporting date. The calculation reflects the probability-weighted outcome, the time value of money and reasonable and
supportable information that is available at the reporting date about past events, current conditions and forecasts of future
economic conditions. Generally, trade receivables are written off if past due for more than one year and are not subject to
enforcement activity. The letters of credit and other forms of credit insurance are considered integral part of trade
receivables and considered in the calculation of impairment. We evaluate the concentration of risk with respect to trade
receivables as low, as our customers are located in several jurisdictions and industries and operate in largely independent
markets.

**_Market Risk_**

The objective of market risk management is to manage and control market risk exposures within acceptable
parameters, while optimizing the return.

The Group’s size and operations result in it being exposed to the following market risks that arise from its use
of financial instruments:

    - Commodity price risk: the Group is exposed to the risk of changes in commodity prices in relation to its
purchase of certain raw materials. The key commodities used by us are Plant Oils. We use commodity
derivatives (future, over the counter and tradable forward contract contracts) to hedge against this risk. Our
policy is to hedge the majority of the risk within the relevant pricing window. The extend of hedging is
determined on an ongoing basis on a country and/or region basis, based on hedging volumes (open
exposure) and the pricing horizon. The hedging ratio increases when the exposure is higher and the window

83


-----

is shorter. All commodity derivative contracts hedge future purchases of Plant Oils, packaging materials
and utilities on a three to six months rolling basis and contracts are settled either in cash or by physical
delivery.

    - Currency risk: the Group’s reporting currency is the euro. Our exposure to the risk of changes in foreign
exchange rates relates to operating activities (sales and purchases), borrowings, cash and cash equivalents
and derivatives against the functional currencies of the Group companies. The main currencies that give
rise to currency risk are the U.S. dollar, pound sterling and the Polish zloty and the foreign denominated
loans in these currencies. We are also subject to currency risk in relation to the translation of the net
investments of our foreign operations into euros for inclusion in our consolidated financial statements. We
manage foreign exchange exposures by transacting as much as possible in the currencies where the
operations are situated. Remaining risks are managed within reasonable limits, mainly using forward
foreign currency exchange contracts. The aim of our approach to management of currency risk is to
minimize foreign currency risk with consideration of the cost to enter into hedge instruments. We do not
hedge the currency risk in relation to our net investment in foreign subsidiaries.

    - Interest rate risk: the Group is exposed to market interest rate fluctuations on its floating rate debt. Increases
in benchmark interest rates could increase the interest cost of floating-rate debt and increase the cost of
future borrowings. Our ability to manage interest costs also has an impact on reported results. Our interest
rate risk management approach aims for an optimal balance between fixed and floating-rate interest rate
exposures on expected net debt. The objective of this approach is to minimize annual interest costs after tax
and to reduce volatility. This is achieved either by issuing fixed or floating-rate long-term debt, or by
modifying interest rate exposure through the use of interest rate derivatives, such as swaps, caps and collars.

The above risks may affect the Group’s income and expenses, or the value of its financial instruments. The
Group’s objective in managing market risk is to maintain this risk within acceptable parameters, while optimizing returns.
Generally, the Group applies hedge accounting to manage the volatility in profit and loss arising from market risk.

**Material Accounting Policy Information**

The preparation of the consolidated financial statements requires management to make certain assumptions,
estimates and judgments that affect the reported amounts of assets, liabilities and disclosure of contingent assets and
liabilities, as of the date of the consolidated financial statements and the reported amounts of net sales and expenses during
the reporting period. Actual results may differ from those estimates.

The estimates and underlying assumptions are reviewed on an ongoing basis. Revisions to accounting estimates
are recognized in the period in which the estimate is revised if the revision affects only that period, or in the period of
revision and the future periods if the revision affects both current and future periods.

Additional information about our material accounting policy information can be found in the notes to our
consolidated financial statements of the Company as of and for the year ended December 31, 2023, included elsewhere
in this Offering Memorandum.

**_Significant Judgment_**

Utilisation of tax losses and interest carry forwards: Deferred tax assets are recognized for loss carry forwards
and interest carry forwards to the extent that it is probable that future taxable profit will be available against which the
loss carry forwards and interest carry forwards can be utilized. In determining the recognition of deferred tax assets, the
Group’s assessment of future taxable income, available taxable temporary differences, tax planning, applicable limitations
on the use of tax loss carry forwards and interest carry forwards are factors taken into account. These factors are
determined in consultation with external tax experts. If actual future taxable income is different than originally assessed,
if tax planning fails to materialize, or if limitations on the use of tax loss carry forward apply, the recognition of deferred
tax assets may have to be adjusted which may have an effect on the reported tax expense and net result.

**_Significant Estimates_**

Estimation of future rebates and other sales reductions: Sales are reduced with different type of sales reductions
and rebates to customers. Where agreements span a financial period-end, estimations are required of projected net sales
and judgement may also need to be applied to determine the rebate level earned as agreements may involve multiple tiers.

Assumptions used in discounted cash flow estimates: Estimates of future business performance, cash generation,
long term growth and discount rates are used in the assessment of impairment of assets at the balance sheet date.

Uncertain tax positions: The Group operates in many countries and is subject to taxes in numerous jurisdictions.
When there is uncertainty over income tax treatments, management is required to consider the effect of the uncertainty in
determining taxable profit (tax loss), tax base, tax losses and tax credits and tax rates. The Group’s accounting policy for
uncertain income tax treatments is consistent with the requirements in IFRIC 23 Uncertainty over Income Tax Treatments.
The estimate of the potential outcome of any uncertain tax position is to a certain extent judgmental. The main judgmental
area relates to the application of local tax laws which may be subject to different interpretations.

**Key Trends**

Upfield’s more sustainable plant-based product portfolio addresses concerns over the instability of the current
global food system while being aligned with key consumer preferences for products which deliver on sustainability, are
healthier and adapt to changing consumption habits (see also “Business—Environmental, Social, Governance (“ESG”)”).

**_Sustainability in Focus: Benefits of Plant-Based Diets_**

The way we produce and consume food has significant impacts on carbon emissions, land use and water use.
The current global food system is unsustainable: If the diets of G20 nations were adopted worldwide by 2050, it is
expected that we would require up to seven planets to support us. Furthermore, the global population is expected to grow
by over two billion over the next 30 years while 9.2% of the global population faced hunger in 2022. There is acute focus
by governments worldwide on prioritising food security and ensuring that significant increases in demand for food
resources can be met. In addition, 38 million square kilometres, approximately 36% of habitable land globally, are
currently used for livestock, despite meat and dairy overall representing a low proportion of our daily calorific intake,
which thus represents a relatively inefficient use of space for a growing population. Plant-based crops feed more people
while occupying less land. Plant-based food uses only 16% of global agricultural land, yet provides 83% of our calories;
harnessing this efficiency would feed a 2050 world more sustainably.

Plant-based dairy alternatives are the more sustainable option to meet increased food requirements as plant crops
require less land, water and other resources than dairy cows. In particular, plant-based dairy alternatives result in
significantly reduced GHG emissions and eliminate the methane emissions from animals (approximately 9% of global
GHG emissions can be attributed to cattle). Compared to their dairy equivalents, Upfield’s (i) Plant Butters and Spreads
contribute 70% less CO₂ emissions and need 66% less land and 50% less water, (ii) Plant Creams contribute 50% less
CO₂ emissions and (iii) Plant Cheeses contribute 74% less CO₂ emissions and overall have less than half the climate
footprint.

Increasingly, consumers are seeking more environmentally friendly product choices because of heightened
concern over the environment and climate change. Plant-based products contribute less CO₂ emissions, require fewer
resources to produce and have a longer shelf life thereby reducing waste. This is a priority across generations, with 50%
of consumers saying they restrict their dairy consumption. Furthermore, retailers named GHG emissions as the number

87


-----

one key ESG topic on which they evaluate their suppliers. More environmentally friendly packaging is also an
increasingly key purchasing criteria, with consumers seeking to reduce their plastic usage through all-paper packaging
solutions. In 2023, we successfully launched our paper tub packaging technology in Austria under our Flora Plant brand,
with similar launches in the United Kingdom and the Netherlands in early 2024. Furthermore, Upfield has taken proactive
steps in order to address consumer concerns regarding both health risks of palm oil and its historical association with
deforestation. In response, it has created a patented palm oil-free technology and shifted its focus on offering alternatives
to palm oil in select markets where consumer sentiment leans towards avoiding palm oil due to health concerns. Since
2019, Upfield has transitioned to sourcing certified (segregated and mass balance) palm oil, underscoring its commitment
to sustainability and actively mitigating the impact of deforestation. In 2023, Upfield achieved an outstanding score of
8.5 (out of 10) on the RSPO’s Shared Responsibility Scorecard, placing Upfield in the top 4% of companies demonstrating
sustainable leadership in palm oil sourcing. Upfield continuously explores novel recipes utilizing sustainable palm oil and
alternative ingredients through its patented palm oil-free technology. See “Business—Procurement.”

**_Health & Wellness in Focus: Benefits of Plant-based Diets_**

Consumers have ever greater access to information on nutrition and are more actively considering the health
profile of the products they eat and drink. There is increased focus on clean-label products with formulations and traceable
natural ingredients, which 33% of EU consumers look for. The food industry, particularly in developed markets and with
respect to unhealthier foods and high-fat, sweet and salty options, could also face a softer demand in the coming years
because of obesity medicines decreasing appetite and reducing daily calorie intake, thereby driving consumers who are
taking obesity medication to healthier options. Upfield’s products are focused on a limited number of natural ingredients:
for example, Upfield’s Plant Butter only contains six to seven natural ingredients without the artificial ingredients
historically used in the spreads industry.

Within the dairy category in particular, consumers are increasingly focused on heart health and are, therefore,
conscious of limiting their intake of trans fats and looking for low cholesterol products, including those which use natural
plant sterols. Upfield’s products have natural ingredients (i.e., clean label and simple formulations with traceable
ingredients) and are demonstrably healthier than their dairy equivalents, being cholesterol-free and trans-fat-free (for
example, 100 grams of dairy butter has 3 grams of trans fat). Further, 95% of Upfield’s products beat the benchmark for
saturated fats of dairy alternatives and Flora ProActiv is clinically proven to lower cholesterol by using plant sterols.

Consumers are also more actively seeking out products which have incremental health benefits and fortified
nutrition, such as added vitamins, calcium and healthy Omega 3 and 6 fatty acids. Upfield’s BlueBand contains vitamins
and Omega 3 and 6, in addition to having the lowest saturated fat content (36%) in line with WHO recommendations.
One portion of BlueBand contains 0.3g of Omega 3, which is equivalent to one portion of salmon, one glass of cow’s
milk or three eggs.

The above is not at the expense of taste, texture and affordability, which are still key purchasing criteria, as
consumers look to buy healthier products with on-par performance at affordable price points. Due to the investment and
innovation which Upfield has driven in its categories, Upfield’s Plant Butters and Spreads are, on average, approximately
40% cheaper and Upfield believes that they now have functional performance parity and almost taste parity with dairy
equivalents. Specifically, eight out of ten consumers stated that Upfield’s Flora Salted Plant Butter tasted like dairy butter,
while 92% said it baked the same, 83% said it cooked the same and 82% said it spread the same. In Poland, in 2023,
Upfield was also honored that its new Rama Crema 15% product was recognized as the best new product in dairy creams
and cream alternatives by leading trade magazine Handel. What is particularly inspiring is that Rama Crema 15% not
only outperformed another plant-based cream but also two dairy options that made it to the final nominees.

Upfield believes its Plant Creams have several health and environmental advantages over dairy creams, including
a longer shelf life (reducing waste for customers and consumers), greater volume and stability in whipping, acid stable,
heat stable and allergen free (where 100% plant-based). See also “Business—Products—Plant Creams.”

**_Changing Consumer Consumption Habits_**

Convenience and availability are increasingly important as brands are expected to innovate to meet consumer
need states and occasions, such as on-the-go and impulse, as well as the growing baking and cooking categories. This has
also caused a shift in the distribution channels through which consumers purchase products, evidenced by the increasing
prevalence of e-commerce. To this end, Upfield has developed relationships with various online retailers and e-commerce
platforms, such as Ocado, Tesco, Amazon and Carrefour online, which represent a significant growth opportunity in the
regions in which it operates, especially in Europe and the Americas. Upfield’s strong retail presence in major supermarkets
and at retailers globally means its brands benefit from over 90% awareness across major markets. Furthermore, Upfield’s

88


-----

products are available in multiple formats to meet different consumption occasions and affordability criteria, including
sachets, standard sizes and family sizes.

**_Accelerated Conversion to Plant-based Diets_**

The above trends have historically driven and are expected to drive further conversion to plant-based diets in the
future. Plant-based milk was the first category to benefit from an uplift in conversion, with the penetration of plant-based
milk in retail markets for Western Europe, the United Kingdom and the United States growing from 5% in 2010 to 16%
in 2022 (3.2 times compared to 2010) and being expected to grow to 22% in 2025 (4.4 times compared to 2010).

In 2022, Upfield’s TAM for cheeses, across both dairy and non-dairy, equalled approximately €61 billion
globally, of which €32 billion was from retail channels and €29 billion was from foodservice channels.

**Distribution Channels: Retail & Foodservice**

Upfield addresses the market for its core categories through retail and foodservice channels (see also “Business—
_Channels and Regions”). In 2022, Upfield’s TAM equalled €101 billion in retail and €50 billion in foodservice._

The current penetration of plant-based products within the foodservice market is slightly higher than in retail,
benefitting from the same trends driving plant-based dairy alternatives overall in addition to certain distinct category
growth drivers. Foodservice is a strong outlet to drive awareness about and the adoption of plant-based diets and products,
driven by customer advocacy and the requirement for suppliers to have quality products meeting increasingly customized
expectations, including frying, cooking and melting specifications, as well as taste and texture parity with dairy
equivalents.

In the retail market, Upfield anticipates significant growth in plant-based categories, particularly in creams and
cheeses, outpacing traditional dairy products. Upfield observes accelerated growth across volumes of butters and spreads,
compared to pre-COVID-19 levels. From 2022 to 2027, plant-based retail values are expected to grow 3.0% to 5.0% per
annum overall, including plant-based cheeses and plant-based creams which are expected to grow 15% to 17% per annum
and 19% to 21% per annum, respectively, while plant-based butter and spreads are expected to grow 2.0% to 3.0% per
annum.

In the foodservice market, plant-based categories are expected to out-grow the broader foodservice market:
15.0% to 20.0% overall per annum volume growth is expected for plant-based creams and plant-based cheeses in the midterm, tapering to 7.0% to 12.0% per annum in the long term, and plant-based butters and spreads are expected to grow
approximately 3.0% to 5.0% per annum, driven by a strong customer pull for the functional benefits and price advantages.
From 2022 to 2027, plant-based foodservice volumes are expected to grow 4.0% per annum overall, including plant-based
creams which are expected to grow 12.0% per annum, while plant-based butters and spreads are expected to be flat.

**BUSINESS**

**Overview**

We are a global leader in plant-based food, established in 2018, as a purpose-driven company with a clear vision:
“To make people healthier and happier with nutritious and delicious, natural, plant-based food that is good for you and
good for our planet.”

We develop, produce, distribute and market plant-based dairy alternative products in over 100 countries across
four core categories: Butters and Spreads, Creams, Liquids and Cheeses. Backed by a rich heritage and a global scale, we
are highly differentiated in the plant-based sector. Our reinvigorated iconic power brands reflect over 150 years of product
expertise and brand heritage and are trusted by consumers globally. Our scale, culture and capabilities, including extensive
food technology and innovation expertise, our community of dedicated “Upfielders,” consisting of our management team
and employees, and our 14 manufacturing facilities across five continents, provide a strong value proposition for our
customers and consumers, and ensure we are well positioned to advance the future of food.

Our products are marketed under a family of historic and iconic brands with strong recognition in their target
markets. Our products are made with natural and sustainably sourced ingredients. Our carefully selected ingredients come
from a diversified supply chain to minimize risk and environmental impact and maximize taste, functionality, health,
affordability and sustainability for our consumers.

Our operations are diversified across three regions, namely Europe, the Americas and AMEA. We hold
leadership positions in the global butter and spreads, and plant cheese segments, with leadership positions in creams in
Germany and the United Kingdom, our key creams markets. We sell our products across these regions primarily through
retail channels, such as supermarkets, hypermarkets, convenience stores and other outlets. In addition, through our
professional foodservice channel, we sell our products to commercial outlets, such as quick service restaurants, bakeries,
pizza and pasta outlets, hotels, catering and industrial kitchens, and to the social sector, such as educational institutions,
workplaces and hospitals.

During the years ended December 31, 2021, 2022 and 2023, our net sales were €2,793 million, €3,375 million
and €3,275 million, respectively. During the same periods, our operating profit was €288 million, €453 million and €570
million, and our Normalized EBITDA was €666 million, €749 million and €831 million, respectively. During the twelve
months ended March 31, 2024, our net sales were €3,209 million, our operating profit was €604 million and Normalized
EBITDA was €862 million.

**_Our Successful Transformation_**

Following the acquisition of our business by KKR in 2018, we began a journey to separate, transform and
reinvent our business, building on our existing strong foundations: a global platform with iconic power brands and worldclass knowledge.

Our journey took more than four years, with the wholescale transformational part of our journey completed in
2022. To become an independent business, we focused on separating and stabilizing our business, simplifying, renovating
and innovating our product portfolio, expanding into new product categories, investing in R&D through the opening of a
new Food Science Centre, optimizing our supply chain, building an end-to-end globally scaled and digitally-enabled
platform and building a new IT infrastructure. See “Business—History” for a detailed description of our transformation
journey.

Building on our existing strong foundations and as a result of the significant industrial, digital and cultural
transformation undertaken since 2018, we believe we are well positioned to advance the future of food.

**Strengths**

**_We are well positioned to advance the Future of Food in a large and growing TAM_**

We believe that the future of food lies in tasty, high-quality, responsibly made, plant-based food. Transforming
the food system by increasing the consumption of plant-based foods in our diets is the key to address the impact of what
we eat on climate, nature and health. As a global leader in plant-based food, offering our products in four large and
growing categories and selling into over 100 countries worldwide, we are well positioned to advance the future of food
and to meet the growing shift in consumer preferences to plant-based eating. To inspire more people to eat plant-based
alternatives, we focus on delivering tasty, high performing, healthy, sustainable and affordable products. We believe that
there should be no compromise for consumers when they change to plant-based products as compared to dairy alternatives.

conversion to plant-based products, which we are well positioned to leverage, especially given our strong position globally

the largest producer globally in terms of market share and hold leading positions across some of the largest butter and

NielsenIQ measurement data, we are the global leader in the plant cheese segment, and have leadership positions in

**_A reinvigorated portfolio of brands reshaping the future of food_**

With our portfolio of trusted brands we believe we can drive conversion to plant-based food and leverage our
strong market positions going forward. Our brand platforms are led by our power brands, our most iconic brands, which
have a long history and heritage. We believe that our power brands are deeply rooted and trusted by our consumers and
customers across a number of our markets and have high brand awareness in their respective markets. These brands
include, for example, Flora (launched in 1964), Country Crock (launched in 1954), Becel +ProActiv (Becel launched in
1962 and ProActiv launched in 2000), Rama (launched in 1924), BlueBand (launched in 1916) and Violife (acquired in
2020). In addition to our power brands, we also have a number of country or region specific brands with a strong local
heritage and brand awareness, such as Lätta in Sweden, Stork in the United Kingdom and Tulipan in Spain.

Following our acquisition by KKR, we have also reorganized and reinvigorated our brand portfolio since 2018.
We refreshed our brands around our end-to-end brand platforms, so as to provide for better harmonization and efficiencies
across our R&D and innovation pipeline, sales and marketing and supply chain activities. Our brand platforms are founded
upon key prerequisites of taste and affordability, but each platform serves a distinct consumer need and is mapped against
the key usage occasions and growth opportunities across our categories and markets.

We also organize our brands across three different price tiers: “good,” (targeting price sensitive customers)
“better” (targeting customers looking for additional product benefits at a more affordable price than a dairy alternative)
and “best” (targeting customers seeking premium products with multiple features, such as lowering cholesterol). We
assign our brands and products across these tiers which are each designed to meet distinct consumer needs and cater for
certain price sensitivities, thereby catering to various social demographic needs. We believe that such categorization
simplifies consumer decision-making and helps us strategically position each tier to appeal to a different array of
consumers.

**_Well-invested end-to-end platform_**

We operate an end-to-end globally scaled and digitally-enabled platform, in which we have made significant
investment in recent years, and through which we produce and sell our products to retail and foodservice partners in over
100 countries globally. We operate a global network of manufacturing facilities and regional cold chain distribution
centers with capabilities to support growth. Our historic strong cash generation has enabled us to invest significantly in
our global operations, ensuring we have the latest manufacturing innovations at our disposal. We own a total of 14
manufacturing facilities, comprising seven in Europe, four in the Americas and three in AMEA. These facilities produced
approximately 91% of our total production volume for the year ended December 31, 2023. Our comprehensive

Our products and customers further benefit from our internal centralized procurement function designed to
