**_An industry leading R&D expertise delivering innovation and driving conversion to plant-based food_**

Our strong innovation pipeline underpins our mission to revolutionize the plant-based ecosystem by delivering
tastier, high-quality products with natural ingredients. That pipeline is driven by our investment in R&D, oils & fats and
plant-based proteins amongst other enabling technologies, with food science at its core. We believe that we have an
industry leading R&D expertise that enables us to produce new and innovative products using key ingredient know-how,
technically sophisticated equipment and processes across our core categories and products. As an insights-driven
organization we seek to continually enhance consumer experience with respect to taste, functionality, health and nutrition,

We continuously invest in food innovation and food technology expertise from our new state-of-the-art food

specialists focus on the development of plant-based foods and sustainable packaging solutions. We are also a leading filer

With our deep expertise in plant-based and natural ingredients and proprietary knowledge of plant-based food

2020, which we have since then further evolved, offering products we aim to achieve taste parity as compared to dairy
butter. We have also developed new recipes and ingredients for our products, for example to provide consumers with
palm oil-free options through our patented technology. In 2023, we successfully launched our paper tub packaging

As well as innovating internally to achieve these goals, we partner with academia, established ingredients and packaging

our ability to scale through our distribution channels, platform and growth levers.

**_Growth levers underpinned by a resilient, attractive financial profile with high cash generation_**

Our growth levers are centered around driving conversion from dairy products to our plant-based products and
involve:

    - Creating the best-ever products made by us: delivering tastier, high-quality products with natural ingredients
in our four core categories, underpinned by a strong innovation pipeline;

    - Deploying our power brands: leveraging our iconic power brands, recognized and trusted across markets,
with clear propositions;

    - Executing in multiple channels: reaching as many people as possible by executing well within our channels:
retail and foodservice; and

    - Driving and leveraging our scale: leveraging our digitally enabled end-to-end platform and scale.

Our transformation journey since 2018 has taken place against a turbulent and volatile backdrop of events
including a global pandemic, associated supply chain challenges, commodity inflation and the ongoing cost-of-living
crisis. However, during this period, by leveraging our growth levers, we have demonstrated a track record of stable
financial performance, in particular delivered strong growth in organic net sales, gross profit and Normalized EBITDA.
Between the year ended December 31, 2021 and the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, our reported net sales increased
at a CAGR of 6.4%, our gross profit increased at a CAGR of 11.4% and our Normalized EBITDA increased at a CAGR
of 12.1%.

We have also demonstrated strong cash generation, and generated a normalized free cash flow and normalized
free cash conversion ratio of €702 million and 81.4%, respectively, in each case, for the twelve months ended March 31,
2024. We believe this compares favorably with our peers and is supported by, among other things:

    - our flexible cost base, which allows for a sustainable gross margin. We have clear, consistent and wellestablished supply chain, and hedging policies with respect to our major inputs and foreign exchange
exposures, which has allowed us to maintain strong levels of profitability in periods of fluctuations and
under high inflationary conditions;

    - our sustained profitability, with a Normalized EBITDA margin of 23.8%, 22.2%, 25.4% and 26.9%, in the
years ended December 31, 2021, 2022 and 2023, and the twelve months ended March 31, 2024,
respectively, largely attributable to our flexible cost structure, our powerful brands, our revenue growth
management capabilities and our track record of operational cost savings;

    - a favorable working capital position, as we benefit from a negative cash conversion cycle. This largely is a
structural feature of the payment terms customarily available in the raw material and finished product
markets in which we operate and our operational efficiency with respect to our inventory management; and

    - our comprehensive manufacturing network with a globally scaled and digitally-enabled supply chain and
significant spare capacity. This allows for increased net sales volumes without incremental capital
expenditure resulting in strong cash generation.

Our strong cash generation and resulting Normalized EBITDA growth has helped us to progressively deleverage.
For the years ended December 31, 2021, 2022 and 2023, and for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, our historical
leverage ratio was 8.4x, 7.2x, 6.5x and 6.5x, respectively. Our historical leverage ratio represents the ratio of our (i) net
debt, which is defined as our financial liabilities gross of unamortized financing fees less cash and cash equivalents,
excluding lease liabilities and derivative financial instruments to (ii) Normalized EBITDA.

**Strategies**

across our core categories and markets. Our clear mission and purpose forms the cornerstone of our strategy to deliver
long term sustainable, profitable and purposeful growth by bringing tasty plant-based foods to people all over the world,
and achieve our purpose “to make people healthier and happier with nutritious and delicious, natural, plant-based food

**_Our growth levers_**

_Creating the best-ever products made by us: delivering tastier, high-quality products with natural ingredients in our four_
_core categories, underpinned by a strong innovation pipeline_

Since 2018, we have reinvented our product portfolio, investing significant resources to create the best-ever
products made by us, including by harmonizing and simplifying our ingredients list and moving towards fewer, natural
and fully plant-based ingredients. We are focused on delivering our best-ever products that are designed to have the same
or superior taste, versatility and performance (cooking, baking, and spreading) as dairy products. We believe that there
should be no compromise for consumers when they change to a plant-based butter or spread, liquid, plant-based cream or
plant-based cheese, as compared to dairy alternatives. For example, our Plant Butter is specifically formulated with the
aim to match the performance and taste of dairy butter. Based on more than 50 taste profiles, we created a series of plant
butters which we strive to taste and perform just like dairy butter and that match the specific taste preferences of different
consumer profiles in key markets. Also, our know-how and expertise of natural ingredients has enabled us to simplify our
Plant Butter to contain just six or seven natural ingredients (including certain Plant Oils, water, plant protein and, in some
cases, salt) and enable consumers to swap it directly for dairy butter in any recipe.

Consumers are also increasingly focused on clean label and naturalness, and 99% of all our ingredients by
volume are natural in origin. We continue to invest in R&D to deliver products using recipes made from natural
ingredients or products that are free from artificial colors, flavors and preservatives, and without compromising on food
safety, quality and performance. In addition, as part of our commitment to be 100% plant-based by the end of 2030, we
are continuously reviewing our use of dairy ingredients where there is no compromise in taste or performance.

Aside from taste and performance, we focus on the nutritional benefits of our products, as well as their positive
contribution to health. Health is a high priority for consumers and a key reason why people choose our products. In 2022,
our team of nutritionists and product developers created the Upfield nutritional benchmarking program, based on what
science tells us is required for each different product proposition and which introduced saturated fat and trans-fat targets
for plant creams and plant cheeses. This helps us ensure that we meet nutritional targets in our products and are aligned
with international dietary guidelines and regulations. Our plant-based products contain zero trans-fats and lower saturated
fats compared to dairy alternatives.

So, whether consumers are looking for a product to bake a cake, help lower their cholesterol or containing the
nutrients to support a growing family, our products strive to provide a “no compromise” choice, that is better for
consumers and better for the planet.

_Deploying our power brands: leveraging our iconic power brands, recognized, trusted and loved over the world with_
_clear propositions_

Our business traces its origin and heritage back over 150 years and, as a result, many of our reinvigorated iconic
power brands, including BlueBand and Rama, have a brand heritage spanning over 100 years. Our power brands,
including as an example, Flora, Country Crock, Becel +ProActiv, Rama, BlueBand and Violife, are trusted in their key
markets globally and are at the heart of our future growth strategy and success.

Our power brands are well-known and have a high brand awareness amongst consumers in our markets. They
represent the platform from which we have successfully launched our product innovations and portfolio renovation.
Through our power brands we engage with both loyal and new consumers, offering people a positive choice, both as a
plant-based alternative to dairy and also for less competitive brands and private label. Based on independent brand
research, many of our power brands are among the best-performing FMCG/packaged grocery brands across our key
markets in terms of brand awareness. We believe that the high score of our power brands indicate that consumers are
more likely to choose our brands over others, which is a strong indicator of increasing brand influence and share. To
further support our power brands, we complemented the ongoing innovation across our portfolio with an increase in
strategic advertising and promotion investment. For the year ended December 31, 2023, our advertising and promotion
expenses amounted to €173 million (equalling 5.3% of our net sales for the year ended December 31, 2023 and an increase
of 22.7% compared to the year ended December 31, 2022). For example, in 2023, we launched our “Skip the Cow”
campaign aimed at informing and driving consumers towards more plant-based products. Our “Skip the Cow” campaign
pushed the uptake of Flora Plant and has proved to be a valuable resource in boosting consumer awareness of our Plant
Butter offering and also contributed to a strong positive consumer net sentiment of 86% towards our overall Flora brand.
Furthermore, following the “Skip the Cow” campaign, Flora Plant Butter experienced growth in household penetration
and share of segment in the United Kingdom. Following the success of the “Skip the Cow” campaign in the United
Kingdom, we launched similar campaigns across European markets, such as Germany and Austria, and intend to also roll
it out to other key markets such as the Netherlands, Poland or Spain, and also across other brands. To further leverage the

strength of our brands, we have from time to time considered, and continue to consider and evaluate, modifications to our

_Executing in multiple channels: reaching as many people as possible through our channels: retail and foodservice_

We also differentiate ourselves through our retail and professional foodservice channels, which enable us to
reach consumers directly through both industry channels. We sell our products to retail outlets, including to many of the

with well-known and reputable distributors. Through our foodservice channel, we also supply the professional channel,
including restaurants, hotels and industrial kitchens. This multi-channel approach gives us access to a broad and diverse

with leading global and regional retailers, we operate as the supplier of choice and/or “category captain” for certain
strategic retailers, providing in-depth knowledge and consumer insight for particular product categories to our retailer
customers.

Moreover, we believe there is considerable potential to introduce and expand our core product categories in the
foodservice channel given our current portfolio’s appeal across high-end clients who lead and influence the menu adoption
cycle to large quick-service restaurants, bakery chains and other national accounts where mass adoption occurs. Our
growth strategy in foodservice is focused on selling value-added branded products with high-demand applications to
commercial customers and driving customer acquisition through our chef-led sales approach (see also “—Sales and
_Marketing”)._

_Driving and leveraging our scale: leveraging our digitally enabled end-to-end platform and scale_

Through our end-to-end globally scaled and digitally-enabled platform we produce and sell our products to retail
and foodservice partners in over 100 countries globally. Our global footprint, scale and expertise along the value chain
allow us to leverage efficiencies through which we can derive significant advantages compared to other plant-based
competitors and dairy players. Since 2018, we have demonstrated a track record in driving efficiencies for example by
establishing product portfolio efficiencies (through the retirement of SKUs that are less profitable or of low productivity
and the simplification of our recipes), procurement efficiencies (by sourcing most of our ingredients and packaging
materials from global suppliers who can deliver locally), supply chain efficiencies (through our established local retail
and distribution network) and by maintaining a continued focus on operational efficiencies in line with our value creation
program. Establishing such efficiencies allows us to offer affordable products.

**_Continuously delivering our Purpose_**

Our purpose is “to make people healthier and happier with nutritious and delicious, natural, plant-based food
that is good for you and for our planet” and it shapes how we approach the sourcing of our ingredients, the development
of our recipes, our relationships with retailers and how we communicate with consumers. We intend to continue fulfilling
our purpose with our commitment and initiatives across our four pillars: (i) plant-based, (ii) healthier lives, (iii) happier
people and (iv) better planet, which are at the heart of our business with tangible programs and milestones.

_Plant-Based_

Actively helping the food transition and building a better, plant-based future is at the heart of what we do. Our
plant-based commitment pillar seeks to help inspire and encourage consumers to switch from dairy to plant-based options.
As we continue to improve our product portfolio, we aim to reach one billion consumers with our products by 2030. We
believe we can achieve that goal by offering consumers a range of products that meet their needs, which also includes
making sure our products taste great, perform well, and are made with simple, natural ingredients.

We believe we are in a strong position to support the transition to a plant-based diet by offering tasty, affordable,
nutritious and more sustainable products. From our Food Science Centre, we continuously invest in high performance
product formulations and reformulations to keep up with consumer needs and trends. For example, in 2023, we launched
the Violife cream cheese block in the United States which has been developed specifically to compete with leading dairy
cream cheeses on the market, following a completely new formulation and format.

To spread awareness around our plant-based products, we frequently launch retail consumer advertising
campaigns with slogans aimed at informing and driving consumers and professionals towards more plant-based products.

-----

Other efforts to boost our brands’ and products’ visibility include, for example, sponsorship of sporting events and
partnerships with celebrities and influencers.

In addition, we are also working to support the industry moving forward in terms of plant-based innovation,
which includes establishing standard parameters for plant-based products. For example, we are currently leading the
development of a new ISO standard that we expect will specify technical definitions of, and criteria for, plant-based foods.
We believe that this new ISO standard will help align the global food industry around a single terminology approach.

_Healthier Lives_

The second pillar focuses on the nutritional benefits of our products as well as their positive contribution to
health. Health is a high priority for consumers and we believe is a key reason why people choose our products. We aim
for our products to outperform their dairy counterparts with respect to levels of saturated and trans-fats. We take a sciencebased approach to establishing criteria and targets for each product type we sell, considering who uses them, how
frequently and in which applications. These targets are based on recognized external international standards and official
dietary recommendations, including those from the World Health Organization. Moreover, we have set additional targets
that ensure we can deliver the desired nutritional composition. These include considerations on how we can limit nutrients
of concern and provide essential nutrients that target some of the greatest public health areas of concern, such as heart
health and children’s growth and development. Our brands BlueBand and Becel +ProActiv are our global brands focused
on positively impacting lives across the world by offering healthy, affordable and nutritious options. In 2023,
approximately 30% of our net sales came from products providing health and nutrition benefits and that can be labelled
as such, in compliance with regulation.

Additionally, we believe the future of food lies in quality, responsibly made, plant-based foods. To realize this
future and provide consumers with healthier options, we intend to continue implementing rigorous quality and safety
standards at both our and third-party facilities, including for product design, formulation, raw material sourcing, packing,
manufacturing, storage, transport, display, marketing, communication, sales and product disposal. Moreover, we intend
to continue ensuring that our products are accessible to as many people as possible, which includes ensuring our products
come in at affordable price points. In this regard we intend to maintain a portfolio of products designed for budgetary
brackets across the market spectrum and which are more affordable than dairy alternatives, without compromising on
quality.

_Happier People_

We believe that people are happier when they are engaged and we actively promote a culture of active support. We are
committed to our community of dedicated “Upfielders.” Our approach to employee engagement is driven by three core
values: performance, care and passion. To nurture an engaged workforce, we complete an annual survey to gauge
employee sentiment and opportunities for progress. In addition, diverse businesses are likely to be more successful and
we are committed to creating a diverse and inclusive working environment. Across our supply chains, we are connected
to thousands of farmers and plant-based entrepreneurs who grow our ingredients and chefs who create and prepare
millions of meals every day. In support of farmers and plant-based entrepreneurs, we maintain several partnerships,
enabling and encouraging them to improve agricultural practices and access to markets.

In addition, we seek to reach as many chefs and food service professionals as possible to encourage the adoption
of our products into their cooking, thereby engaging chefs in the plant-based revolution. We do this by, for example,
hosting cooking workshops for chefs or participating in trade fairs where we can reach out and educate professionals on
the advantages of plant-based cooking.

_Better Planet_

With an environmental footprint significantly smaller than that of dairy products, our products can help
consumers reduce their impact, and we ensure our operations do so as well. We are committed to responsibly sourcing
ingredients, developing sustainable packaging and addressing our carbon emissions to enhance sustainability.

Our better planet commitments include our environmental targets to address our material environmental impacts
on the climate, on packaging and on responsible sourcing. For the year ended December 31, 2023, we committed to
Science Based Target Initiative (“SBTi”) and have worked on redefining our targets in line with the newly published
Forest, Land and Agriculture (“FLAG”) guidance to align with limiting global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius above preindustrial levels. In this respect, we are making multiple efforts towards reducing our emissions and reducing
environmental impact through waste and water management at our manufacturing facilities. In addition, we are committed
to providing packaging that protects products and the planet. We delivered a milestone packaging achievement with the

97


-----

launch of the world’s first paper-based tub for plant-based butters and spreads, our Flora Plant paper tub at the end of
2023, starting our journey towards our target of reducing plastic across our portfolio by 80% by 2030 (compared to a
2020 baseline). In addition, we are committed to responsible and sustainable sourcing of our ingredients (including our
Plant Oils) and packaging materials (including paper and pulp) and our “Responsible Sourcing Policy” and “Business
Partner Code of Conduct” applies to all our suppliers. Where key ingredients are identified as potentially high risk, we
maintain strong individual policies designed to address the potential risks inherent in these supply chains, particularly
focussing on deforestation and exploitation. See also “Business— Environmental, Social, Governance (“ESG”).”

**History**

Upfield was established in 2018, as a purpose-driven company with a clear vision: “To make people healthier
and happier with nutritious and delicious, natural, plant-based food that is good for you and good for our planet.”

While Upfield is a young company, our business traces its origin and heritage back over 150 years, when the
Jurgens family bought the patent for Plant Spreads. Many of our iconic power brands have brand heritage spanning over
100 years and under its prior ownership, our business evolved into one of the earliest large-scale producers of dairy
alternatives globally, focused on plant-based spreads.

Following the acquisition of Upfield by KKR in 2018, we began a journey to separate, transform and reinvent
the business, building on our existing strong foundations: a global platform with iconic power brands and world-class
knowledge. Building on these foundations and as a result of the significant industrial, digital and cultural transformation
undertaken since 2018, Upfield has established itself as a global leader in plant-based food, operating in multiple
categories with a global end-to-end supply chain.

At the outset, we formulated and adopted our Upfield manifesto, with a clear, purpose-driven vision and a datadriven mission to guide us as an independent company. During the last five years, we have invested over €1.6 billion to
reinvent our business: by simplifying, renovating and innovating our existing product portfolio, expanding into new
product categories and investing in our end-to-end supply chain while further investing and developing our IT system.

In the initial separation and stabilization phase, we exited more than 600 transitional service agreements that
were still in place from Upfield’s previous owner, built our fully digital, cloud-based Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP)
system and completed the complex separation from Unilever to become a fully independent business by June 2020.

Prior to KKR’s ownership, Upfield’s business was largely focused on margarine. As a first step, we began
innovating our margarine and spreads business by working towards clean label products and developing palm oil-free
recipes. Gradually we shifted and expanded our category focus by developing and launching our Plant Butter offering,
specifically formulated to aim to replicate the performance and taste of dairy butter. By 2019, we reprioritized our Creams
and Liquids core categories and achieved volume growth in these categories. In January 2020, we expanded into the
Cheese category following the acquisition of Arivia, a leading producer of plant-based cheese through Violife.

Since 2018, we have undertaken a significant innovation and renovation program across our product portfolio,
introducing natural, plant-based ingredients and harmonizing and rationalizing the number of SKUs and recipes to focus
on fewer but better products. For example, we have upgraded and renovated a significant proportion of our product
portfolio since 2018, with approximately 85% of our European spreads sales in 2022 being from products renovated or
innovated since 2020, to retire SKUs which were less profitable or of low productivity, such that we operate with
approximately 1,200 active SKUs as of the third quarter of 2023 (down from 2,600 SKUs in 2018), excluding Plant
Cheeses. Furthermore, we restructured our portfolio of distinct recipes from over 340 distinct recipes for Plant Butter and
Spreads in Europe in 2018 to focus on 18 chassis. We harmonized and aligned our brand portfolio into key end-to-end
brand platforms which allows continued harmonization and efficiencies across our R&D and innovation pipeline and
supply chain.

Our innovation and food technology roadmap is led out of our Food Science Centre in Wageningen, the
Netherlands, which opened its doors in 2022 following an investment of approximately €38 million. Our Food Science
Centre leads our research and reformulation programs to continue simplifying our recipes, with an aim to deliver our bestever products from natural, plant-based ingredients which are better for consumers and better for the planet.

As a result of the above factors, our TAM across our four core categories, i.e., Butters and Spreads, Creams,
Liquids and Cheeses, has increased 15 times to approximately €151 billion in 2022 as compared to approximately €11
billion in 2017. Our expansion into the Butter, Creams, Liquids and Cheeses categories, in addition to Spreads, resulted
in an expansion of our TAM. While currently the penetration of plant-based products in the Butters, Creams and Cheeses

98


-----

categories is low, and estimated at less than 1%, there is a potential opportunity of approximately €23 billion (based on
an incremental €7 billion opportunity in the above categories when assuming a 5% plant-based penetration) or €38 billion
(based on an incremental €22 billion opportunity in the above categories when assuming a 16% plant-based penetration)
(see also “Industry—Upfield’s TAM”).

We optimized our supply chain footprint, closing five of our own manufacturing facilities including in
Nassakaude Rotterdam (the Netherlands), Rexdale (Canada) and Purfleet (the United Kingdom). At the same time, we
reinvested and modernized our footprint of 14 owned manufacturing facilities to support our growth objectives across our
core categories. In addition, we introduced a value creation program, which focusses on making our business more
efficient from an operational perspective and in particular through supply chain areas including, amongst others,
procurement, manufacturing and portfolio simplification. Since the implementation of this program in 2018, we have
realized approximately €415 million of costs savings in aggregate, with €90 million of cost savings achieved in 2023
alone.

Our journey since 2018 has taken place against a turbulent and volatile backdrop of events including a global
pandemic, associated supply chain challenges, commodity inflation and a cost-of-living crisis. Our transformation since
2018 was enabled by a purpose and performance-driven culture, which is carried by a passionate and engaged community
of approximately 4,800 “Upfielders”, consisting of our management team and employees. Our community of “Upfielders”
are aligned with our purpose, and are highly motivated to make an impact, deliver sustainable, purposeful long-term
growth and advance the transition to a plant-based food future.

**Products**

We are focused on four core categories: Butters and Spreads, Creams, Liquids and Cheeses. For the year ended
December 31, 2023, our Plant Butter and Spreads, Plant Creams, Liquids and Plant Cheeses represented 81%, 8%, 4%
and 5% of our net sales, respectively. Sales outside of our core categories represented 2% of our net sales for the year
ended December 31, 2023. We compete against dairy and other plant-based offerings within these categories through our
plant-based products. These products are marketed through our portfolio of brands, comprising our power brands and
other local brands which cover a range of categories and price points across our markets.

**_Brands_**

Our brands are organized across end-to-end brand platforms which are founded upon key prerequisites of taste
and affordability, but each serves a distinct consumer need and is mapped against the key usage occasions and growth
opportunities across our categories and markets. Organizing our brands in this way also allows for continued and ongoing
harmonization and efficiencies across our R&D and innovation pipeline, sales and marketing and supply chain activities
with respect to our brands and products.

Our brand platforms are led by our power brands, our most iconic brands, which have a long history and heritage.
We believe that our power brands are deeply rooted and trusted by our consumers and customers across a number of our
markets and have high brand awareness in their respective markets. These brands include, for example, Flora (launched
in 1964 with a strong presence in the United Kingdom and increasingly other European markets), Country Crock
(launched in 1954 and present today in the United States), Becel +ProActiv (Becel launched in 1962 and ProActiv
launched in 2000 with a strong presence in European markets and Canada), Rama (launched in 1924 with a strong
presence in Germany), BlueBand (launched in 1916 and present today in the Netherlands, Indonesia and other markets
within AMEA) and Violife (which is a leading plant-based cheese brand globally, with an especially strong presence in
the United States and the United Kingdom, which are the leading plant-based cheese markets), acquired in 2020. Our
power brands accounted for the majority of our total net sales for the year ended December 31, 2023.

In addition to our power brands, we have a number of country or region specific brands with a strong local
heritage and brand awareness. Such local brands include for example, Lätta, a leading plant-based spreads brand in
Sweden, Tulipan, a popular brand of over 70 years in Spain, under which we offer Plant Butter and Spreads without any
palm oil, and Stork, which was launched more than 100 years ago and which has become a leading baking brand in the
United Kingdom.

Our brands and products are positioned across the price ladder in their markets with affordability being a key
focus. We organize our brands across three tiers: “good,” “better” and “best.” Each tier is strategically designed to meet
distinct consumer needs and certain price sensitivities, thereby catering to a wider audience. We believe that the “good,”
“better” and “best” pricing strategy simplifies consumer decision-making and strategically position each tier to appeal to
different segments. Brands that sit in the “good” tier target price-sensitive consumers in their respective markets with a
plant-based spread product and includes brands such as Imperial (the United States, Mexico), Rama (Germany), Stork

99


-----

(the United Kingdom), Delma (Poland and Hungary) and Lätta (Sweden). The “better” tier offers a broader product
offering and are therefore positioned at a slightly higher price point, attracting consumers who are looking for additional
product benefits but still affordable compared to the dairy alternative. Brands such as Country Crock (the United States),
Flora (the United Kingdom), Becel (Netherlands, Canada) and BlueBand (Indonesia, Netherlands) fall within the “better”
pricing tier. The “best” tier contains brands which offer a premium product for consumers, with multiple features and in
some cases health benefits, such as Becel +ProActiv which contains plant sterols which are clinically proven to lower
cholesterol. Brands such as Becel +ProActiv, Violife as well as some plant butter offerings in certain markets fall within
the “best” pricing tier. On average, our Plant Butter and Spreads cost 40% less compared to dairy alternatives.

**_Plant Butter and Spreads_**

We are a leading producer of plant-based butter and spreads. Our Plant Butter and Spreads are made from Plant
Oils, water, salt and protein and are suitable for key usage occasions including baking, cooking and spreading. For the
year ended December 31, 2023, our Plant Butter and Spreads represented 81% of our net sales.

Our Plant Butter is specifically formulated with the aim to match the performance and taste of dairy butter. It
contains six to seven natural ingredients including Plant Oils, plant-based proteins, natural flavourings, water and, in some
cases, salt. Our Plant Butter comes in a wrapper like dairy butter, which allows it to more effectively target the baking
and cooking occasion. Our Plant Spreads have been largely reformulated since 2018, introducing natural, plant-based
ingredients and harmonizing and rationalizing the number of SKUs and recipes to focus on fewer but better products. Our
Plant Spreads contain fat levels between approximately 20% to 75% depending on format and usage occasion. Whereas
our Plant Butter is specifically designed with the aim of replicating dairy butter in terms of both taste and functionality
for baking, cooking and spreading applications, our variety of plant spreads are more focused on specific usage occasions.
For example, depending on fat levels, our Plant Spreads may be most suitable for baking, cooking or spreading.

Our Plant Butter and Spreads cover a wide range of categories based on storage temperature, including (i) chilled
products, (ii) ambient products, which are solid at room temperature and (iii) tropical ambient products (for Plant Spreads),
which remain solid at the higher temperatures typically experienced in tropical climates. Our Plant Butter and Spreads
are also available in multiple formats suitable for a variety of occasions, including wrappers and tubs for spreading,
cooking and baking purposes, sachets for spreading and topping, as well as large format tubs and portion packs for the
foodservice industry.

Our Plant Butter and Spreads have several health and environmental advantages over dairy butter. One of their
benefits includes the higher Omega 3 and 6 fatty acid concentrations and zero trans-fat and lower saturated fat content
per serving. Additionally, the production of plant butter and spreads requires fewer resources and have a significantly
lower overall carbon footprint than dairy butter and other comparable dairy products. Our Plant Butter and Spreads
product lifecycle contributes approximately 70% less CO₂ emissions, need approximately 66% less land and need
approximately 50% less water than dairy equivalents.

**_Plant Creams_**

Our Plant Creams are alternatives to traditional dairy creams and can be used in the same way, for example, for
cooking, baking or topping. For the year ended December 31, 2023, our Plant Creams represented 8% of our net sales.

Our Plant Creams are made from Plant Oils, combined with proteins, emulsifiers and stabilizers. Some of our
cream products which are not 100% plant-based contain buttermilk and we intend to transition towards a 100% plantbased portfolio by 2030. Our creams portfolio currently includes cooking creams, double/whipping creams and sour
creams, and are packaged in a variety of formats including pots, bottles, pouches, tetra packs and pallecons for both our
retail and foodservice channels.

Our Plant Creams have several health and environmental advantages over dairy creams, including a longer shelf
life (reducing waste for customers and consumers), greater volume and stability in whipping, acid stable, heat stable and
allergen free (where 100% plant-based). Our Plant Creams also have a product lifecycle which requires fewer resources
and a lower overall carbon footprint, contributing approximately 50% less CO₂ emissions compared to dairy creams.

**_Liquids_**

Our liquids portfolio comprises culinary liquids, namely plant-based liquid margarines and sprays, which are
typically used for cooking and baking including for sautéing, frying, baking, grilling or as a topping. For the year ended
December 31, 2023, our Liquids represented 4% of our net sales. Our Liquids are derived from Plant Oils and are available
in both bottle and spray formats.

100


-----

Our Liquids contain all of the cooking benefits of dairy butter but without the commonly associated issue of
spattering. Our offering also contains zero trans-fats per serving.

**_Plant Cheeses_**

Our Plant Cheeses are alternatives to traditional dairy cheeses and can be used in the same way as dairy cheese.
For the year ended December 31, 2023, our Plant Cheeses represented 5% of our net sales.

Our Plant Cheeses are typically made from Plant Oils combined with starch and plant proteins and partially
fortified with Vitamin B12. Our Plant Cheeses portfolio covers a variety of styles, flavors, formats across hard, soft and
spreadable cheese including slices, blocks, grated, creamy and in a variety of flavors such as cheddar, gouda, mozzarella
and smoked.

Our Plant Cheeses have several health and environmental advantages over dairy cheeses, including being free
of allergens (including dairy, casein and lactose), cholesterol free and with zero trans-fats. Plant-based cheeses also have
a production lifecycle which requires fewer resources and a lower overall carbon footprint, contributing approximately
74% less CO₂ emissions compared to dairy cheeses.

**Channels and Regions**

Our operations span three regions, namely Europe, the Americas and AMEA. We sell our products across those
regions primarily through retail channels, such as supermarkets, hypermarkets, convenience stores and other outlets. In
addition, in emerging markets in which we operate across our regions, we have established a strong market channel based
on deep relationships with well-known and reputable distributors. We additionally operate a foodservice channel, which
sells products to commercial outlets, such as quick service restaurants, bakeries, pizza and pasta outlets, hotels, catering
and industrial kitchens and to the social sector, such as educational institutions, workplaces and hospitals. Retail sales
represented 89% of our total net sales for the year ended December 31, 2023. Our foodservice channel represented 11%
of our total net sales for the year ended December 31, 2023.

In the retail channel, we operate as the supplier of choice and/or “category captain” for certain strategic retailers,
providing in-depth knowledge and consumer insight for particular product categories to our retailer customers. As is
typical in the food industry, we do not have long-term contractual commitments with our key customers. Instead, we enter
into bespoke joint business plans with customers, which usually encompass pricing, trade terms, support for new
innovation, assortment, distribution and shelf space. In some markets, the agreements also include promotional activity
for the year, although in most markets it is still possible to change promotional activity and pricing during the year. We
have also developed relationships with various online retailers and e-commerce platforms, such as Ocado, Tesco, Amazon
and Carrefour online, which have seen an increase in retail market share in recent years and which we believe represent
a significant growth opportunity in the regions in which we operate, especially in Europe and the Americas.

Our foodservice business operates in 76 countries across Europe, the Americas and AMEA. Approximately 44%
of our foodservice net sales come from the United Kingdom, Indonesia, Germany, Sweden and Mexico. Given this market
concentration, we believe there is significant room to expand our foodservice geographical footprint. Moreover, we
believe there is considerable potential in the foodservice channel for our core product categories given our current product
portfolio, and in particular its appeal across the foodservice value pyramid and the menu adoption cycle. Our growth
strategy in foodservice is focused on selling value-add branded products with high-demand applications to commercial
customers and driving customer acquisition through our chef-led sales approach (see also “—Sales and Marketing”).

Ireland, and we have a sales presence in 39 European countries. For the year ended December 31, 2023, our operations
in Europe accounted for €1,599 million of net sales, representing 48.8% of our total net sales for the same period.

**Competition**

We are a global leader in plant-based food. While there are other local and regional producers of plant-based
products, we are strongly positioned in the market of plant butter and spreads, plant creams and plant cheeses. See
“Industry.” Our plant-based products face competition from alternative products such as dairy butter, cooking oils,
traditional dairy creams and animal-based cheeses and sweet spreads amongst others.

The competitive dynamics in our industry are, in particular, driven by changing consumer trends, demands and
preferences. These include dietary, health and environmental concerns and trends, such as increasing awareness of
different nutritional aspects of foods and the health effects and sourcing practices relating to specific ingredients, an
increasing preference for dairy-free, vegan and organic food ingredients, trends towards eating and baking outside of
home and concerns regarding public health consequences associated with obesity and increasing awareness of the
environmental and social effects of production (in particular those related to palm oil, which is a key ingredient in many
products across our portfolio). See also “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of
_Operations—Factors Affecting Results of Operations—Changes in Food Trends and Consumer Preferences” and_
“Industry—Key Trends” for a description of changes in food trends and consumer preferences affecting our business.

**Sales and Marketing**

We aim to solidify and enhance our market-leading brand awareness and increase penetration of plant-based
food in our core categories by leveraging our brand heritage and our products’ ability to meet key consumer purchasing
criteria with respect to taste, functionality, health and nutrition, sustainability and affordability. By building and
supporting our brands, we believe we can educate and inspire consumers to move to plant-based foods. Over the years,
we have introduced millions of consumers to our plant-based products. For example, in 2023, we reached an additional
55 million consumers based on household penetration data by country and product sales (bringing us to approximately
261 million consumers reached as of December 31, 2023), which is a significant contribution to our goal of “inspiring the
shift” and reaching one billion people with our plant-based products by 2030.

Our sales teams are organized by region and local market, with overall strategic guidance and direction provided
at a global level in line with our overall corporate strategy. Regional sales teams are responsible for regional sales and
promotional strategy, and alongside local teams plan the end-to-end sales process and activities across sales planning,
sales execution and sales promotion activities. Local teams manage day-to-day operations and execution in both retail
and foodservice channels and manage customer relationships and, where relevant, distributor relationships.

Our marketing function is led by dedicated marketing teams in each region and lead markets, with overall
strategic guidance and communications support provided at a central level in line with our overall corporate strategy. The
regional marketing leads are responsible for developing the overall marketing and strategy and work closely with our
markets units, sales, supply chain and R&D teams to support sales and operational planning, and execute our overall
marketing strategy in line with our overall objectives. This includes engaging with customers on promotional displays
and merchandising, as well as planning key marketing and promotional campaigns and providing key consumer insights
and intelligence across the business. This is supported by our interactive data visualization Power BI platform and key
consumer and market insight data from brand experts engaged by us, amongst other initiatives.

Through targeted campaigns and consumer engagement, we work to increase public knowledge of how our
products can contribute to healthier, more sustainable diets. This year, we have continued to develop new and innovative
marketing campaigns like “Skip the Cow” and the #MakeItPlant campaign to drive consumers, chefs and foodservice
providers to choose more plant-based options. Our “Skip the Cow” campaign, initially under the Flora brand, was meant
to inspire the shift to plant-based products and promote the benefits of our Plant Butter which has approximately 75%
less climate impact in terms of CO₂ emissions than dairy butter. Since the launch of the campaign at the beginning of
2023, sales volumes of Flora Plant Butter have increased by more than 59% in the United Kingdom for the year ended
December 31, 2023 as compared to the year ended December 31, 2022. Furthermore, Flora Plant Butter experienced
growth in household penetration and share of segment in the United Kingdom. Our “Skip the Cow” campaign has pushed
the uptake of Flora Plant and has proved to be a valuable resource in boosting consumer awareness and positive net
sentiment (86%) towards our Flora brand. Following the success of the “Skip the Cow” campaign in the United Kingdom,

103

we launched similar campaigns across European markets, such as Germany and Austria, and have started to also roll it
out to other key markets such as the Netherlands, Poland or Spain, and also across other brands.

**R&D**

We believe that our R&D capability and knowledge is a key enabler of competitive advantage in our drive to
continuously push for innovation in plant-based food in our categories. We believe we have an industry leading R&D
function that underpins our ability to produce new and innovative products using key ingredient know-how, technically
sophisticated equipment and processes across our core categories and products. As an insights-driven organization we
seek to continually enhance consumer experience with respect to taste, functionality, health and nutrition, sustainability
and affordability by developing relevant product and packaging innovation. We leverage our knowledge and know-how
of key enabling technologies which are relevant across our brand platforms, core categories and products.

We continue to invest significantly in food innovation and food technology expertise. In the year ended
December 31, 2023, our R&D expenditure represented approximately 1% of our net sales. Additionally, we invested
approximately €38 million in our new, state-of-the-art Food Science Centre in Wageningen, the Netherlands, which
opened its doors in 2022 and which we believe is the largest pure-play plant-based food center in the world. Our Food
Science Centre is a dedicated R&D facility solely focused on plant-based food innovation and pioneering the development
of plant-based foods and sustainable packaging solutions. The Food Science Centre is at the heart of Food Valley around
the Wageningen University and Research campus in the Netherlands, and sits at the core of a leading agri-food ecosystem
where there is a deep pool of food science talent and relevant partners across the food value chain. Our team of more than
150 food scientists, food technologists and R&D specialists, including packaging experts, have delivered an upgraded
and simplified portfolio of products that offer consumers choice and are designed to compete effectively against plant and
dairy products alike across our four core categories. Our team continues to not only develop plant-based foods but also
sustainable packaging solutions. We are a leading filer of plant-based patents, and hold 656 patents and patent
applications, with 19 new patents filed between 2018 and 2023 (with ten patent applications filed in 2023 alone) and 11
new patent families filed since 2018 across our Plant Butter and Spreads, Plant Creams and Plant Cheeses categories.

In addition, our R&D team, in collaboration with Footprint LLC, a company that develops and manufactures
plant-based fiber solutions and whose material sciences technology we have been using, have designed and developed a
paper tub that is durable, recyclable and visually attractive. In 2023, we successfully launched our paper tub packaging
technology in Austria under our Flora Plant brand, with similar launches in the United Kingdom and the Netherlands in
early 2024.

As well as innovating internally, we partner with academia, established ingredients and packaging players, startups and scale-ups whose differentiated propositions can complement our R&D capabilities and our ability to scale through
our distribution channels, platform and growth levers. In 2023, along with industry peers, we formed an industry
consortium from the total protein value chain in the Netherlands on a new project, called “the FabaFood project”, to
advance plant-based protein innovation. For the FabaFood project, which is supported by Efro Oost (a subsidy program
for Dutch companies), we will partner on developing new, food-grade varieties of the fava bean, as well as innovative
methods of protein extraction and processing. These new proteins can then be incorporated into a range of dairy substitutes
that deliver enhanced performance across taste, color, texture and cost.

We are particularly focused on leveraging these partnerships and broader collaborations across the food
technology ecosystem to execute our R&D roadmap across Plant Butter, Plant Creams and Plant Cheeses in particular.

**Strategic Partnerships**

We believe we are a key player in the food technology ecosystem, partnering across the full system from
academia and start-ups to scale-ups and suppliers. These strategic partnerships offer differentiated propositions which
complement our R&D capabilities and our ability to scale through our distribution channels, and allow us to grow our
position in the professional food sector.

produces sustainable and nutritious plant-based meat products, taking a minority stake in the company. We are partnering
with Heura Foods to develop food technology and collaborate on product definition, production, and distribution. This
partnership aims to create superior products via disruptive technology, bringing together Heura Foods’ cutting-edge
technologies and our expertise and innovation as regards plant-based food products.

**Procurement**

Our procurement function sits within our global supply chain function and is led by our Chief Procurement
Officer. We operate a predominantly centralized procurement function designed to leverage our purchasing expertise and
maximize scale efficiencies across the regions where we operate. Our procurement function has a deep understanding of
commodity cycles and risk management, and many years of experience in the oils market. Sourcing strategy, commodities
risk management, hedging and procurement value creation are designed and managed by the central procurement team,
which is also responsible for the sourcing of Plant Oils. Regional procurement teams are responsible for sourcing of other
inputs and materials and supplier management. We source most of our food ingredients and packaging materials from
global suppliers who can deliver locally, and our supply chain is aligned with our geographic footprint, enabling us to
optimize our supply arrangements and minimize logistics costs. We have developed strong, long-standing relationships
with our major suppliers of key raw materials, many of which have been in place for over a decade.

The principal ingredient in our Plant Butter and Spreads, Plant Creams, Liquids and Plant Cheeses are refined
Plant Oils (such as rapeseed oil (approximately 33% of our total Plant Oils volume and of which the majority is sourced
from Europe), soybean oil (approximately 17% of our total Plant Oils volume and of which the majority is sourced from
North America), sunflower oil (approximately 5% of our total Plant Oils volume and which we entirely source from
Europe), palm oil, palm kernel oil, derivatives and fractions (approximately 36% of our total Plant Oils volume and of
which the majority is sourced from Indonesia and Malaysia) and coconut oil (approximately 6% of our total Plant Oils
volume and of which the majority is sourced from the Philippines)), in each case, for the year ended December 31, 2023.
Additional primary materials used in our production process include other ingredients and packaging materials. Our risk
management mechanisms include the use of physical stocks. futures, forward contracts, derivatives and other financial
hedging transactions to provide certainty and insulate the business from short term price volatility across a majority of its
input commodities, with initiatives underway to expand the scope of such measures to cover packaging material costs as
well.

In addition, we are committed to responsible and sustainable sourcing of all our ingredients and our Responsible
Sourcing Policy, Human Rights Policy and Business Partner Code of Conduct applies to all our suppliers. Our target is
to be 100% deforestation free and conversion free by 2025. Since October 2019, all of the palm oil directly purchased by
us is certified (segregated and mass balance), which means that our supply chain has been assessed against strict criteria
set-out by the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO). In 2023, we achieved a score of 8.5 (out of 10) on the RSPO’s
Shared Responsibility Scorecard, placing us in the top 4% of companies demonstrating sustainable leadership in palm oil
sourcing. Beyond sourcing certified (segregated and mass balance) palm oil, we partner with independent experts like
Earthworm and use satellite technology to monitor our supply chains. This satellite technology enables us to monitor the
sources of the palm oil we purchase, which in turn allows us to address deforestation risks with our supply chain partners.
We continue to innovate and create new recipes both with sustainable palm and alternatives to palm oil, namely through
our patented palm oil-free technology. We have also taken significant steps in increasing the transparency of our coconut
oil supply chain. After joining the Sustainable Coconut Charter in January 2022, we ran a supplier assessment and policy

105


-----

review. By the end of 2022, 100% of our coconut oil suppliers agreed with our policy and started to share their countrylevel traceability with us, which gives us the visibility to ensure sustainability throughout our supply chains. Furthermore,
we continue to maintain our policy commitments for certified paper sourcing (Financial Services Compensation Scheme
(“FSC”)/Programme for Endorsement of Forest Certification “PEFC”) and ensuring soybean oil is sourced in compliance
with the Amazon Soy Moratorium Agreement.

For the year ended December 31, 2023, materials, which include Plant Oils, other ingredients, flavors, finished
goods from third-party manufacturers and packaging materials, represented 67% of our total cost of sales.

**Manufacturing**

We own a total of 14 manufacturing facilities, of which 13 are operated by us, comprising seven manufacturing
facilities in Europe, four manufacturing facilities in the Americas and three manufacturing facilities in AMEA (see table
below). The Tultitlán, Mexico facility is currently owned by us and operated by Unilever, with the operational transition
from Unilever to us in progress. These facilities produced approximately 91% of our total production volume for the year
ended December 31, 2023. In addition, we have strategic relationships with select third-party manufacturers, which
produced approximately 9% of our total production volume for the year ended December 31, 2023. Our relationships with
third-party manufacturers are predominantly focused in AMEA and LatAm and where markets are more fragmented
and/or where there is a greater distance to our own manufacturing facilities. For example, we have a long-term strategic
contract with GrainCorp, who is the only manufacturer of our products sold within Australia and New Zealand. We
believe that our global network of manufacturing facilities provides us with exceptional outreach to local markets while
maintaining quality and efficiency through scale.
